PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION) BILL 1993]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Mr Gear:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1993 replaces Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 7) 1992 which lapsed with the proroguing of the 36th Parliament. The new Bill largely follows the provisions of the lapsed Bill, but with the addition of some transitional measures for one of the proposed capital gains tax changes.

PARA.TAB: The Bill makes change in the area of the assessability and deductability of accrued leave transfer payments, so that the employer who makes the payment will be able to claim a deduction for the amount of that payment and so that the amount of the payment will be assessable income for the employer who receives it. This measure has an element of retrospectivity in it which is of interest to the Opposition, given our stated policy in that connection, and will probably end up, because the guillotine is being applied, being addressed in the Senate once again.

The Bill introduces new anti-avoidance provisions for the capital gains tax in the case of the transfer of assets within company groups to which a capital gains tax rollover applies. A number of changes are also made to the capital gains tax provisions dealing with depreciable property on crown leases. Further amendments are made to capital allowance provisions, the depreciation cost price limit rules, as well as making some changes to the dividend streaming arrangements. Again, the coalition is concerned about retrospectivity entailed in the amendments to the current depreciation arrangements contained in the Bill, while otherwise being supportive of the proposed amendments.

Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 is primarily concerned with the introduction of the various business taxation measures that were announced in the Investing in the nation statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) during the Federal election campaign. These include the introduction of a general 10 per cent investment allowance, a reduction in the company tax rate from 33 cents in the dollar and changes to company tax collection arrangements. The tax rate for pooled development funds is also to be reduced from 30 per cent to 25 per cent. This measure is significant in that it suggests that the pooled development funds legislation has not proved as attractive for investors as the Government had at first hoped and told us it would. The Bill also makes some minor amendments to the foreign investment funds legislation that was passed late last year and in a few other areas, such as fringe benefits tax.

The changes to the company tax payment arrangement reintroduces quarterly payments of tax for companies and serves to bring forward some company tax payments, particularly for larger companies. These changes we are told are designed to reduce the lumpiness of the current company tax payment system which requires that companies pay 85 per cent of their notional tax on 28 July each year, with the balance being payable on the ensuing 15 March. This represents long overdue recognition of the impact of the Government's previous company tax payments system changes on business cash flow, changes which sent many companies to the wall soon after the time they were first introduced. Those changes were designed to bring forward revenue collections to help balance Labor's Budgets, although it should be noted that these new measures once again serve to bring forward the collection of revenue from some of the larger companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Money grabbing, big spending Keating.

—Yes, eating into the cash flow. It says a lot about the Government's real attitude towards national savings and savings in the private sector, because by depreciating those cash flows in this way, of course, it detracts from the private sector savings which the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) likes to pretend he is so much in favour of.

PARA.TAB: In terms of business cash flow, the less lumpy payments system may well be more than offset by the bringing forward of tax for these larger companies, so that they are worse off in cash flow terms. Under the new arrangements, smaller companies with notional tax of less than $8,000 will make one payment of tax on the first day of the sixth month of the tax year, instead of paying quarterly as they now do. Companies with notional tax of between $8,000 and $300,000 will pay in equal quarterly statements on the first day of the final month of the income year; on the first day of the third and sixth months of the tax year, and a final balancing payment or refund on the first day of the ninth month of the tax year. Companies with larger tax bills will also pay quarterly, but the first payment will be due on the first day of the ninth month of the income year and then quarterly until the sixth month of the tax year. Transitional arrangements are to be put in place to avoid any overlap with the current company tax system for larger companies.

The proposed reduction in the company tax rate from 39 to 33 cents in the dollar, while desirable in itself, does give cause for concern in terms of the way in which it will interact with the top personal income tax rate. The considerable divergence between the top marginal personal income tax rate and the company tax rate may be distortionary by encouraging some taxpayers to incorporate, at considerable expense to them, in order to gain a tax advantage by virtue of the lower company tax rate. The Government says that the general anti-avoidance provisions of part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act will be sufficient to counter any avoidance that may be encouraged as a result of this divergence between the two tax rates.

Such anti-avoidance measures will not, however, alleviate the costly and distortionary impact from those who will be able to legitimately incorporate under the tax law but who would not otherwise have done so without the incentive of the lower company tax rate. The tax benefit of incorporation will in many cases be dissipated by the taxpayer's incorporation costs, but taxpayers can still be expected to incorporate if they can come out ahead at the end of the day, and it is as simple as that. This means that again it is the lawyers and accountants who stand to gain considerably as a result of this measure, given the high marginal tax rates of personal income tax. Of course, this is not an argument for keeping the company tax rate at its current level, but instead for reducing the high marginal rates of personal income tax to a level more in keeping with that which will now apply for companies.

We should also be mindful of some of the Government's more extravagant claims about the effects that its reduction of the company tax rate will have on business investment. Given that most company tax is passed on to consumers in the form of higher prices for the company's goods and services, it would seem unlikely that the reduction in the company tax rate will have a significant impact on company profitability or investment. But it is at least pleasing to see that the Government has come to the realisation that slugging companies does nothing to improve the equity of the tax system since these measures will ultimately be worn by consumers regardless of their own income.

When the Government talks about the impact of this measure on investment we should also remember that the dividend imputation system washes out many of the benefits of corporate tax concessions to shareholders as the gap between the company tax rate and the top marginal tax rate widens, which is the effect of this legislation. Furthermore, the benefits of the reduction in the company tax rate will accrue mainly to foreign investors rather than local residents, which is no bad thing in itself but is contrary to the impression given by Labor's rhetoric in these matters.

The Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1993, the last of the three Bills we are discussing today, introduces those superannuation arrangements that were announced last year in the Government's security and retirement statement. The provisions of this Bill largely follow those of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1992. These provisions simply give effect to the Government's various superannuation policies as originally set out in this statement to which I have referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hundreds of policies.

—There have been hundreds of amendments in the past 10 years, but that is another story. With these tax Bills the Government seems to be indicating that it intends to live up at least to some of the taxation commitments it entered into both before and during the last federal election campaign. The Government has already legislated for the promised reductions in personal income tax rates and with these Bills will provide for the reduction in the company tax rate. But, if the Government does indeed intend to deliver on these promised tax cuts, we can only be left to wonder at how it proposes to reduce the Commonwealth Budget deficit to one per cent of GDP by 1996-97 as it has also promised.

PARA.TAB: In the absence of a commitment to reduce the Commonwealth's own purpose spending we can only come to the conclusion that new taxes are on the cards to make up for some of the revenue being conceded with these Bills and some of the other taxation and expenditure commitments. All sorts of rumours have been doing the rounds on what the Government will do in this regard. It would be fair to say that the Government itself at this stage probably has only a very incomplete idea of how it intends to raise the necessary revenue.

But new and increased taxes are obviously under serious consideration within government circles and it is only a matter of time before the Government comes into this place with a swag of new revenue raising measures with which to slug the Australian people. This was amply demonstrated by the non-answer of the Minister for Finance (Mr Wills) when he answered a question by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), in this place the other day.

It is hard to listen to any member of the federal bureaucracy these days without being given the clear impression that new and increased taxes are on the way. This was confirmed earlier this week with a number of newspaper reports of a speech given by Mr Rod Sims, Deputy Secretary to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. In his speech to the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia, CEDA, Mr Sims highlighted the difficulty of meeting the Government's deficit reduction target of one per cent of GDP by 1996-97, particularly in the absence of expenditure restraint by the Commonwealth.

He then dragged out the hoary old chestnut about Australia being a low tax country, as did the Prime Minister the other day which was clearly aimed at softening up the audience with the prospect of new and higher taxes in the years ahead as part of the Government's solution to its budget deficit program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are you coming from?

—Why does the Minister not have a look at the States' taxes and include them in his feeble considerations? This was certainly the impression gained by those present at the particular address to which I refer. Given the Government's continued failings on the expenditure front and its apparent intention to press ahead with the personal income tax cuts as well as the reductions in the company tax rate, we can only come to the conclusion that new and increased taxes are on the way. This will be, of course, in complete violation of the Government's mandate from the Australian people at the most recent federal election, which was overwhelmingly for no new taxes from the Federal Government.

PARA.TAB: Not unexpectedly, the Prime Minister carefully avoided giving the electorate the opportunity to read his lips in this regard, and he gave no specific undertakings about the possibility of new taxes. I suggest they might have to speed read his lips in the very near future though. Nonetheless, the message from the electorate was loud and clear, and it is one that the Government ignores at its peril.

It is also possible that the Government will seek to renege in whole or in part on its promised personal income tax cuts or the reduction in the company tax rate. There have already been suggestions that the Government might seek to defer the proposed personal income tax cuts to help meet the Budget deficit reduction target.

Again, the Government should be reminded of the mandate it was given by the people on 13 March. The Government was voted in on a specific commitment to reduce personal income tax rates in accordance with the schedule that is already embodied in legislation. The Opposition will be working to ensure that the Government respects that commitment given to the Australian people.

As far as any new taxes are concerned there is already plenty of speculation as to what these new taxes might consist of. But we should not overlook the fact that Labor is determined to press ahead and squeeze every last drop of revenue out of the existing tax base even without the addition of new taxes.

The net result of these efforts is likely to be a considerable increase in the complexity of the tax law and its associated compliance costs but with relatively little gain to the revenue. Hence we have the horrendously complicated measures such as the foreign investment funds legislation and some of the new fringe benefits tax measures, which are dealt with in these Bills, and a host of other measures designed to ferret out revenue from every corner of the tax base.

In addition to these specific taxation measures, the Government's tax compliance and enforcement measures are aimed at increasing the resources available to the Australian Taxation Office to ensure a higher level of compliance on the part of taxpayers now operating within the current tax base. These measures take advantage of the complexity of the law to trip up taxpayers and hit them with back taxes. This was illustrated last week when it was revealed that the Australian Taxation Office finds an average error of $52,000 in its audits of fringe benefits tax returns.

Such massive errors can only be attributed to the complexity and uncertainty of the law that leads to honest mistakes by taxpayers or differences in interpretation of the tax law between taxpayers and the ATO. It is a sad state of affairs when the government of the day relies on the injustices of the tax system to plug holes in its finances. But that is what this Government is doing when it puts forward Budget forecasts which rely on the revenue generated through such compliance and enforcement measures.

Under Labor's taxation system we have nothing less than taxation by complexity, which is surely no way to run a taxation system. Nowhere is taxation by complexity more apparent than in the ATO's large case audit program of the top 100 companies in Australia. To date the adjustments to company tax returns as a direct result of the large case audit program amount to some $1 billion affecting about 50 companies. However, a huge 31 per cent of that amount is being disputed by the companies concerned.

This suggests massive and widespread uncertainty in the application of tax law as it applies in this country. This in turn suggests that some of the benefits of the reduction in the corporate tax rate and changes to the company tax payment system will be lost to the continued complexity of the tax law and the way it wastes the time, money and resources of taxpayers in high compliance costs and other wasted resources.

It also suggests that there is something seriously wrong with the large case audit program. Instead of fostering compliance with the law, which was the audit program's claimed intention, it has corporate taxpayers up in arms about the injustices they have experienced at the hands of Tax Office audit teams. If the various corporate taxpayers concerned win a significant proportion of these disputes with the ATO, then the return to revenue from the costly large case audit program will begin to look very paltry indeed. It should be remembered that companies do not take issue with the decisions of the Tax Office lightly.

Just as individual taxpayers must face up to enormous costs if they want to take on the ATO, so must companies also incur considerable expense if they want to take issue with the results of a large case audit. So these companies must think that they at least have a reasonable chance of success if they are going to challenge the outcomes of the ATO's large case audits on the scale suggested by figures supplied by the Corporate Tax Association.

Indeed, it is quite possible that the amounts in dispute would be larger if it were not for the fact that some companies would take the view that a challenge was not worth the expense in relation to the amount of money sought by the Tax Office in particular instances. Potential disputes about when tax is payable, rather than the amount of tax payable, fall into that category. In other words, people say, `If they are going to make us pay this financial year, we will cop it rather than argue the case at great expense', whereas they may not legally have to pay at that earlier time.

If anything, the available figures underestimate the extent to which the large case audit program has taken advantage of the complexity of the law to raise revenue. It is thus not surprising that the Corporate Tax Association this week attacked the ATO's large case audit program at the Australian Taxation Institute's convention held in Alice Springs.

The CTA's executive director, Mr Bob Bryant, suggests that the ATO's large case audit assessments amount to ambit claims from the Tax Office over which the Tax Office will seek to negotiate with the company at a later date. If this is true, it means that the outcome of these audits is determined in an arbitrary way by the Tax Office rather than as a result of close adherence to the letter of the law.

The Tax Office case manager in a large case audit is given enormous powers to issue an assessment more or less at his own pleasure rather than as a result of the strict observance of due process or careful consideration of the legal issues that may quite legitimately be in dispute. Taxpayers are forced into defending themselves against these arbitrary impositions at great expense to themselves and with the burden of proof falling entirely upon them, the taxpayers.

The Corporate Tax Association has argued that we should draw on the experience of the United States in these matters and adopt a more cooperative approach between taxpayers and the Australian Taxation Office. Such a cooperative approach would recognise that both taxpayers and the ATO have a responsibility to work together to ensure that the tax law is adhered to and that no-one is obliged to pay more tax than is legally due, given the fairest and most reasonable interpretation of the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not an agent of the Government.

—They have become an agent of the Government, particularly under the previous taxation commissioner. That is to say, black letter law should apply and not what the Australian Taxation Office sometimes wishes the law would be in its ideal world of maximising the tax take. It is one of the enduring features of the internal culture of the Australian Taxation Office that it sees its role not in terms of administering the tax law as it stands but in terms of maximising the revenue despite what the law might actually say in a particular case.

PARA.TAB: The Corporate Tax Association has called on the Government to adopt a more cooperative approach to relations between the ATO and corporate Australia, and the Opposition would urge the Government to respond in the same vein.

In view of these longstanding complaints against the ATO's large case audit program, it is reassuring to hear from the new Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Geoff Carmody, that the large case audit program is to be discontinued in its present form. According to Mr Carmody, the Tax Office will from now on be taking a more selective approach to auditing the top Australian companies instead of the continuous two-year audits of all major companies, which was the main feature of the large case audit program in its previous incarnation.

Mr Carmody has also said that there will be greater emphasis on clarifying the law in the conduct of the ATO's audit activities, which is also reassuring in view of previous experience and the militant rhetoric of the previous taxation commissioner. Hopefully, the ATO will live up to these remarks in its audit activities, which would mark a significant departure from the previous commissioner's sledgehammer approach.

It is important that these issues are addressed at the same time as we address such matters as the company tax rate and the company tax payments system. It is all very well to have a low rate of company tax, but not if the benefits of this low rate are to be dissipated through higher compliance costs as a result of Labor's failure to simplify taxation law.

There is plenty of scope for such simplification, as you understand only too well, Mr Speaker, which should take priority over the extraction of even more revenue from the existing tax base. Unfortunately, Labor's main priority over the next few years will be exactly the opposite, that is, to maximise the tax take so as to help reduce future Budget deficits which have blown out to such alarming proportions. This means that tax law simplification is likely to take a back seat to measures designed to raise revenue from taxpayers, regardless of the compliance costs that such measures might impose upon them. In short, we can expect the Government to continue with its policy of taxation by complexity.

TALK.START.PARA: —In following the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in a debate about taxation, I would have thought that members of the Opposition would have a bit of difficulty participating in a debate about tax issues after their past experience both in opposition and government. When they were in government last time around the tax avoidance industry grew massively and the tax system haemorrhaged dramatically and the Labor Government was faced with the important role of repairing the tax system, putting integrity back into the tax system and getting people to pay tax. In opposition, they developed the GST and all that went with that, which was soundly rejected by the people of Australia. Currently, it is fair to say that they have no idea what tax policy they may or may not have. The Opposition does not have a tax policy.

PARA.TAB: There have been assertions made about and fairly personal attacks made upon the former Commissioner of Taxation because he sought to ensure that companies paid their tax and that the tax system was returned to a sense of integrity. In the provisions now before the House, the Government is taking positive steps to create a competitive environment for Australian companies and create an environment where we can accelerate the pace of economic growth. None of those things came through in the honourable member for Curtin's contribution. Indeed, issues such as the development allowance and the investment allowance, which is part of this package of taxation Bills before the House, did not rate a mention. He made many assertions in his speech about the impact of what the Government was doing about the profitability of companies.

A number of things are clear from this package of Bills. The company tax rate will be reduced from 39 to 33 per cent and the investment allowance will be introduced at the 10 per cent rate to build on the development allowance arrangement introduced following the One Nation statement and also the provisions of accelerated depreciation that were redefined in the One Nation package.

The honourable member for Curtin was bemoaning the fact and creating a scare that the Government would have all these new taxes and would not live up to the taxation promises it made in the run-up to the election. But the package of Bills does precisely that: it ensures that the provision relating to reduced company tax is implemented as soon as possible in this current parliamentary session.

That demonstrates the Government's bona fides on maintaining its commitment to reducing the level of the company tax rate. The personal tax cuts were legislated in the last Parliament. All of those things highlight this scare which the Opposition continues to run. We had all sorts of suggestions by the honourable member for Curtin about what sorts of taxes might be applied, rather than a focussing on the potential value of these measures for the Australian economy. When we look at the measure before the House, it is important that we recognise the strength of the provisions that were in the Investment in the nation package. We had, in that package, a very clear determination on the part of the Government to accelerate the pace of economic growth and recovery, and a recognition that some of the measures that had been outlined previously needed to have further assistance from government because we wanted to encourage the pace of investment and productivity growth in the economy.

That is precisely what we need to recognise—that lowering the company tax rate is all about creating an environment where our companies can be competitive with comparable trading countries which we are dealing with and competing with. It is why having low inflation rates matters, it is why having low interest rate regimes matters and it is why having low company tax rates is so important. That is precisely what we are seeking to do through this legislation that is before the Parliament this morning. One would have thought the Opposition would not throw up this sort of phoney scare but rather would be getting behind and supporting all these measures. Clearly we only get growth if we create that sort of competitive environment.

That is exactly what the legislation is designed to achieve. All the studies that have been done recently highlight the fact that the small to medium sized companies are the ones that are going to create that growth and be the key to economic revival through this decade. It is precisely because of that recognition, in studies like the McKinsey report, that we have taken the step to introduce the investment allowance provision that is contained in these Bills.

Investment allowance is very important. I think one thing that can be said is that it would have been a good measure to include in the One Nation package. But the Government does not sit inflexible on policy development. There has been a recognition that it will be a positive stimulus at this stage to the measures announced already over the last 18 months in the One Nation statement and in the Budget of 1992. That is why I think the additional provision relating to the investment allowance is important, as it enables companies that are contemplating investment to bring that investment forward and to reap the benefits of that change. That will assist many of the smaller companies which may have missed out on the development allowance arrangement for major companies that was part of the package of measures before the Parliament last year.

When we move from that provision to the means of the payment of company tax we had the Opposition lecturing us last year about the impact of cash flow of the company tax instalment payment arrangements at that time. It is clear from what has been said by industry that the package of Bills that are before the Parliament go a substantial way towards overcoming many of the criticisms that were contained in the way company tax payments were impacting on businesses cash flow in previous times.

They removed some of the lumps, as they are referred to, in that process. This hopefully gives the companies the chance to have a more secure pattern of cash flow and a more determined pattern to consider investment decisions and so on. That will be important because we want to create an environment in which there is certainty for business investment. The measures that the Government has taken relating to pool development funds were all about creating a more strongly oriented investment ethos within our business community, and the measures relating to creating a competitive tax regime are designed to do precisely the same thing.

When we look at other measures in the package relating to more flexible arrangements on child care taxation provisions—again not a matter that the honourable member for Curtin referred to at all in his contribution—they demonstrate a positive recognition by the Government of an important item on the national political agenda. It is an important item for the women of Australia, an important item in terms of what we are all concerned about in work patterns, recognition of what work patterns are in the country today and recognition of the continuing and expanding role of child care as a mainstream political issue—something which clearly the Opposition, based on the omission of the honourable member for Curtin, suggests is not part of the Opposition strategy.

We move from those areas to the other sorts of steps that can be taken to encourage economic growth. Already it is clear that the Australian economy is growing, despite all of the protestations of the Opposition through the last election campaign and before. It said that there was going to be a double dip recession, and that there were going to be hikes in interest rates. The Opposition mentioned everything it could think of to talk the economy down. Nevertheless the economy has been growing and will continue to grow. The Government has been determined all the way through the discussion about the economic recovery to take steps to encourage that growth and to accelerate it in a constructive and sensible way. The measures contained here relating to company tax and the already legislated personal tax arrangements are part and parcel of that process.

There are other areas where the Government can ensure our economy is open and competitive. I just want to touch on a few of those measures that have tax implications, in particular relating to the potential that regional financial headquarters offer to Australia, and as part of economic recovery, the potential they offer to improve both our financial and capital base and therefore the investment potential that goes with that. These matters are currently being considered by the Government and I think it is important that early steps be taken to encourage those regional financial headquarters. The impact as far as taxation is concerned has been overstated in some cases. There are measures we can take to ensure that the withholding tax revenue does not suffer, but at the same time we get the benefits of the economic stimulus that go with having the regional financial headquarters that Australia can create and, where there is significant interest, particularly in our region, in encouraging more activity in Australia, encouraging more financial impetus in the Australian economy.

Given that some of the measures that the Government and the broader community have been concerned about involving encouraging the pool of financial resources that companies can use to invest, I think that additional measures to promote regional financial headquarters would be not only a very positive contribution to the stimulus to our economy but also be sending a very positive signal as to our seriousness about those issues as far as the region is concerned. It is clear that the other measures the Government announced in the Investment in the nation package, such as those relating to promoting the banking sector to take a stronger role in promoting economic activity, are important. The Government took steps in the Investment in the nation package to promote the banks to have more resources available for lending, both through the Commonwealth Development Bank with additional funding and also through the assistance it provided to the individual banks to have more funds because of the Reserve Bank paying market interest rates on funds it holds. All these things are important because when we look at the various measures that are needed to create increased economic growth in Australia, they come in part from businesses having the capital and financial backbone to invest themselves, but as well as that they come from their having access to the financial resources to embark on new growth and investment opportunities.

Those things can only be done with a positive direction from the Government with a competitive tax regime. That is certainly what the package of Bills which is before the House is designed to do. The financial institutions are both open and positive in taking on new business proposals which look at issues like cash flow, and really that is what business opportunity is all about rather than, as has been the case in the past, the heavy reliance on property oriented investment decisions. The impact of low inflation on our economy, the value that low inflation gives us, is very real indeed. We now have an inflation rate which is certainly amongst the lowest—I think the second lowest—of the OECD countries. That offers tremendous opportunities, but I am not sure all in Australia as yet appreciate both the opportunities and the challenge that brings. Getting lower, competitive company tax rates is clearly part of the important ingredient we need to get the real benefit of having a low inflation environment.

The Government is delivering on policy announcements it made prior to the election to create an environment that would give companies good competitive investment prospects. It will certainly send a positive signal to Australian companies, and it has the potential to show overseas companies that Australia is a good place to invest. That certainly will be one of the products of the package of Bills before the House.

When we add to those things the present growth in the economy and the fact that we will have taxation arrangements which are extremely competitive internationally, the Opposition should be saying, `Our record in opposition has been pretty lousy on taxation. We went to the people with a GST which no-one wanted and people would not buy. Amongst others, business was totally hostile to it as well. Small business could not stand the thought of all the paperwork and rigmarole involved with the GST'. The Government has been returned and is now delivering on its policies relating to taxation.

Far from the Opposition seeking to create more scares, which is all we get from the Opposition on taxation, we need the Opposition to say, `Yes, we want to have competitive tax arrangements, and a reduction in the company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent is precisely about achieving that, and the Government is rightly delivering on a key policy announcement and commitment that it made'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a brief intervention in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill, Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill. Most of the remarks on behalf of the coalition have been made by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who will be taking my place to lead a number of the debates on tax legislation.

PARA.TAB: As this is the first package of tax Bills brought into the House since the last federal election, I thought it might be appropriate if I made a few remarks about them. In responding to the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), let me remind him that it is not true that Australians—all 11 million voters—did not want the GST. Whilst we accept that the GST was the principal cause for our losing the election, there were a large number of people in the business community, people in the accounting profession, tax experts, and of course public servants who understood that that type of indirect tax system, used in almost all countries around the world, is a preferable one to the ragbag, indirect taxes we have in Australia.

What is more, in the next few weeks we are going to hear about a lot of other new indirect taxes and higher indirect taxes which will be introduced in Australia. Those on the other side of the House are going to be made to squeal all the way to the next election, because they were re-elected on the basis of a scare campaign against a consumption tax. They have a mandate not to introduce any new consumption taxes or to increase existing consumption taxes. If they have no other mandate, that is the mandate they have. If they break that mandate—and they are obviously going to; they are softening up the electorate—then we will be reminding Australians of the pain and the disadvantage that that will put this country to, in terms of its competitiveness, all the way to the next election.

There are two or three points I want to make on these Bills. I know the debate has been guillotined. That is a reflection of the degree to which the Labor Party wants to debate tax issues, I suppose. It wants to keep the debates to an absolute bare minimum. The most significant of these Bills is the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), which takes up, as others have said, the election commitments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the Investing in the nation statement. In particular, this is legislation which reduces the company tax rate from 39c to 33c at a peak cost in 1994-95 of an estimated $1.8 billion.

We are not opposed to the reduction in the company tax rate; that is certainly no bad thing. But it has to be understood in a proper context. First, we have to be able to pay for the reduction in the company tax rate. In the end, it will be paid for with a range of indirect taxes which will increase business costs. So the net effect of the cut in company tax—which is of course a tax on profits, not a tax on costs in the way indirect taxes are—on business, the competitiveness of our businesses and the attraction of Australia as a place for our own businesses and foreign businesses to invest in is not likely to be positive at all.

It would be different on its own, if we did not worry about the costs. The Labor Party did not worry about the costs in the lead-up to the election. It never worried about how much anything cost. That is part and parcel of being Labor, I suppose—never worry about the bills; just go out and tell the people all the goodies the party is going to give them. For a hundred years Labor governments, State and Federal, have been doing that. If we do not worry about the cost then the cut in the company tax rate is not a bad thing.

EPAC, which was established by the Hawke-Keating Government, has said that the reduction in company tax can deliver only very limited benefits. As I said earlier, that is because it is a tax on profits, not a tax on costs. It obviously affects the capacity of businesses to reinvest. As the honourable member for Curtin pointed out, it also increases the disparity between the top marginal rate of tax—which after 1 July this year will be, with the ever rising Medicare levy, 48.4 per cent—and the company tax rate at 33 per cent. I happen to recall in 1985, when option C was produced, the then Treasurer and now Prime Minister saying that an important objective of government tax policy was to ensure that the highest marginal rate and the company tax rate were at the same level; otherwise it left the game wide open to distortion—in other words, individuals incorporating in order to ensure they paid lower rates of tax.

Years later, after a white paper that advocated the GST, we have the Government, led by the then Treasurer, doing precisely the opposite: increasing the disparity. There is an incentive for incorporation. Therefore, it does widen the opportunities for the rorting of the tax system. The Australian Taxation Office no doubt has been forced to say that its anti-avoidance legislation will be adequate to cover this. Not many people, I have to say, agree with the Australian Taxation Office on that matter, which makes me think that officers of the Australian Taxation Office have been persuaded to pump that line around rather than that in the privacy of their own offices they quietly believe in it.

There is also a question of whether the Government is going to reactivate division 7. A lot of people in the business community are of the view that it will. If this is to be a constructive debate, I hope that we will hear from whoever is going to reply to this debate for the Government a clarification of the question whether division 7 is going to be reactivated.

Other aspects of this Bill, given that it does reduce company tax—and that is a benefit—are not quite so beneficial. One of those aspects is that the Bill brings forward company tax payments. Obviously for larger firms that reduces cash flow and is a cost. The Government claims that the revenue it will collect from the bringing forward of the company tax payments will help to compensate for the reduction in the company tax rate.

That is probably true, but it proves the point that the net benefit to companies is going to be much less than the Government is claiming. Also, small unincorporated businesses, of which there are an enormously large number in this country, do not benefit from this legislation at all. This is a measure which is good—although not very good—for the big end of town, but the vast majority of small Australian businesses, which are not incorporated, are not going to get the cut in company tax; they are going to get all the tax hikes that will come later this year and in subsequent years to finance all these election promises that were made by the Labor Party to try to get re-elected on 13 March. So the small unincorporated companies will be the big losers out of these tax measures. That is a point that we will be making over and over again.

I want to make some brief remarks about the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill. There are two areas within the very technical Taxation Laws Amendment Bill where the principle of retrospectivity—or perhaps I should say the principle of non-retrospectivity—is actually breached. One is the area of provisions relating to accrued leave payments, and the other is in the context of depreciation and broad banding. In the area of accrued leave payments, it is a retrospective benefit, not a retrospective cost. While that is not something about which we will kick up an enormous fuss, I remind the House that the notion of retrospectivity has been a controversial one in Australian parliaments since the wash-up of the Costigan royal commission in 1982. I do not think that we really want to go down the path of retrospectivity in taxation legislation. Then there is the potential cost to companies that may have wanted to move to a higher level of depreciation on a broadband basis. This legislation, therefore, potentially imposes a retrospective cost on businesses.

We do not think that is appropriate, and in another place my colleagues will be moving an amendment, which we hope will be supported by the Australian Democrats, to ensure that retrospective cost is taken from the legislation. In so far as they read the Bills drafted for them, the Tax Office and the Government must refuse the temptation to introduce retrospective legislation. We are going to oppose it all the way and I am sure we will get a lot of support from the Democrats on that point.

Finally, I draw to the attention of the Parliament the need to carefully watch a couple of these Bills—the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill in particular—for references to taxation information being provided, in one case, to the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission and, in another, to the immigration department in relation to illegal immigrants. We do not oppose the provision of such information. We do not want to stand in the way of the work of the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission and we do not want illegal immigration in Australia to be aided and abetted; we want to do what we can to support the tracking down of illegal migrants. However, there are real privacy issues involved here. I would like to think that the Privacy Commissioner will be fully involved in these measures. Perhaps the commissioner should be able to report to the Parliament from time to time about how the relationship between the Tax Office and other agencies is actually working and the extent to which privacy provisions could be breached.

I imagine that honourable members on the other side of the House share my concern about that. I hope that either the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), or the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Johns) will take up that point, and I certainly hope that the Tax Office will take note of it. I am sorry that this debate has been guillotined. There are many other points I would like to make but I know that there are others who wish to speak and I do not want to stand in their way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to concentrate particularly on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1993 because it introduces certain measures which were foreshadowed by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in his Security in retirement: planning for tomorrow today statement of 30 June last year, as well as amending other parts of certain Bills relating to superannuation. I might just say that superannuation and the broader insurance industry are now an interest and responsibility of mine, so I want to track through some of the changes introduced in this Bill as they specifically affect superannuation.

PARA.TAB: Of particular importance are the amendments to the taxation of death benefits. At present, death benefits are taxed in a complex manner. The changes contained in this Bill will mean that recipients of death benefits will know with greater certainty the tax treatment of the benefit they receive. The Bill proposes that death benefit eligible termination payments—ETPs—within the deceased's retirement benefit limit paid to dependants will be exempt. However, death benefit ETPs within the deceased's retirement benefit limit paid to non-dependants will be taxed as ordinary eligible termination payments. Dependants whose death benefit ETP represents the commutation of a reversionary annuity, together with non-dependants who are aged less than 55, will pay less tax than under the current arrangements.

I am also pleased to see amendments relating to the taxation of income derived by an annuity provider in respect of allocated annuity policies. Broadly, these changes bring into line the taxation treatment of income derived from life insurance companies and registered organisations with respect to allocated annuities and normal annuity products. This is an important change because it brings into line the treatment of allocated pensions and normal annuity-type products.

Last week I spoke about the importance of weaning Australians off their lump sum mentality and the role that these types of allocated pension products could play. It is important that we keep Australians interested in the notion of paying for their own retirement benefits. I am pleased to see that the industry itself is creating products whereby, in lieu of taking a lump sum, people will put away their money so that it can be paid to them in the form of a pension. The new products really revolve around the notion of whether a person is paid a pension or an annuity, and choice about the rate at which money is withdrawn—be it on a weekly, fortnightly or monthly basis. In a sense, there is some measure of judgment and even risk involved with how quickly retirement savings are drawn upon. I understand that many people like the freedom of that idea but, as I said, to some extent it shifts the risk onto individuals because they have to make decisions about how quickly they will draw on their pensions.

The notion of an allocated pension is welcomed by the Government. As far as taxation is concerned, we think that it should be treated the same as annuities. The spread of new products will only further enhance the notion in the retiree's mind that it is better to put away and draw on money rather than take it as a lump sum.

Another important change introduced by these amendments is the taxation of the excessive component of an ETP at 47 per cent, rather than including the ETP in the taxpayer's accessable income. In addition, there are certain changes to the notice provisions for personal superannuation deductions in the Income Tax Assessment Act. These changes were requested by the industry because the prior notice arrangements led to confusion on the part of fund trustees, and often led to too much, or in some cases too little, tax being paid.

I note that certain amendments are made to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992, and also, in part 4 of the Bill, to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act. These amendments relate variously to transferring retiree members of superannuation funds. The first amendment here is important because it allows certain retiree members to transfer their moneys into another superannuation fund. That has the effect of allowing superannuation fund members to move to other superannuation funds that might, for instance, be providing a better pension deal.

Under the arrangements existing prior to this amendment, members who wished to receive their benefit in income form had to actually be a member of the fund from which that benefit was paid before they retired. This led to the situation late last year where people who were about to retire had to open a superannuation account with a $20 deposit. In other words, they had to use a fairly transparent device in order to be able to receive those moneys. We are now making it perfectly easy for them to not use a device and have access to the money. The amendment in effect will remove some of the barriers to the efficient provision of retirement income stream products and, in addition, it will increase the opportunity for people to choose between pension providers.

The other amendments relate to the obligation of trustees where breaches of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act have occurred, the ability of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to publish certain information about superannuation funds in order to discharge its superannuation guarantee obligations, and the notice requirements that have to set the retirement benefit limits regime. In effect, these amendments clarify and simplify the obligations of trustees in a situation of breach, allow for more informed choices to be made by employers in the discharge of their requirements under the superannuation guarantee legislation, and will reduce some of the complexity of the paper trail in the administration of the reasonable benefit limits regime.

I should note that the above measures have an insignificant revenue impact. This is because, despite the prevailing fiscal conditions, the Government has not cut into its tax concessions for superannuation. Superannuation is still a preferred vehicle for the accumulation of savings and retirement benefits. Similarly, with the introduction of the superannuation guarantee charge and the consequent reductions in personal superannuation deductions, the Government tax concessions have been spread more equitably between low and high income earners. The measures also tighten the integrity and certainty of the superannuation system. In particular, the amendments relating to death and excessive benefits add equity and neutrality to the system of taxing eligible termination payments.

The way that this Government tackles the superannuation agenda is to confront these sorts of problems as they arise and to solve them, which is pretty much in stark contrast with our opponents who, in the last two years, have taken the old boiled lolly from some parts of the industry and thought that the way through this was simply to provide some tax cuts to people and induce them to put away for their own retirement benefits, which we know, and the vast majority of industry knows, simply does not work. It will not produce the dollars at the end of the day. Under our scheme of compulsion, making people put away money for their own retirement benefits, even though those moneys are held in private hands—in industry funds, life insurance funds or whatever—means that today we have over $150 billion which Australians have put away towards their own retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much are individuals going to get back from that—

—They will get more than that, because I am saying that, right at this time, there is $150 billion, which is growing. We are only part way through this exercise, are we not? By the end of the decade we would hope to have $600 billion. I do not think there is any inducement via the Tax Office great enough to get people to put away for their own retirement income. It is absolutely essential that we have a degree of compulsion where we can say, `You really need to put this away'. We might debate the speed at which we lift the levy or the guarantee charge, but we surely cannot resile from the fact that people must put these funds away.

PARA.TAB: I think one of the important exercises over the course of this Parliament is how quickly we move towards our target of having people put away about 12 per cent of their income, which we believe will be essential if they are to have sufficient income in retirement, not forgetting—I guess I should remind people of this—that there will be those who will never have sufficient access to the work force to build up funds sufficient for them to retire in comfort, or those who will never enter the formal paid work force. We should not forget that there will be a pension system in place. I think both sides of this House agree with that. In the course of the next decade or two we want to make sure that we do not place too much reliance on those government pension funds which, in fact, is what the current pension system is. To lighten the reliance on those funds, we need to have people put money away for the future.

I know there has been some criticism of the fees and charges that are made by some sections of the industry on people who are taking out superannuation. We are very conscious of that. We want to put a great deal of pressure on the industry, first of all, to reveal the fees and charges and, secondly, to make sure those fees and charges are kept at an absolute minimum so that we do not breach the trust which workers now have in superannuation. We must reassure them that it is a good deal. They will have to get used to the notion that it is a very long-term investment; it is a lifetime investment in their retirement. They cannot expect to get access to those moneys in the very short term, or for certain charges not to be made for the handling and prudent investment of their funds.

In addition to the market driven solutions to the problems of fees and charges in the insurance and superannuation industry, the Government is contemplating action on that issue. To this end, I look forward to the comments tomorrow night of Mr Ian Salmon, Chairman of the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, at its annual dinner. His comments will be important as they will show the attitude of one of the major players in the superannuation industry.

I also look forward to hearing the attitude of LIFA on such issues as dispute resolution and the conduct of agents. I think it is fair to say that in the past the behaviour of some agents in the insurance and superannuation industries has been quite offensive. They have not revealed the sorts of fees and charges that they have been making, and they have also been selling some products that are simply not appropriate to certain workers. I think there is a great deal more work to be done on that.

The comments of Mr Salmon tomorrow night will be keenly listened to so that we can see how far LIFA, as an organisation representing the industry, has come in attacking these practices. I support the Government's amendments under these taxation arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few moments I have to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill and cognate Bills, I want to pay particular attention to a few areas. The first is in connection with the reduction of the company rates of taxation from 39 to 33 per cent. The Government's intention is that this would make Australia one of the cheapest countries in the developed world for foreigners to invest in from the point of view of taxation. I want to dispute that for two reasons. Firstly, in the reduction of taxation from 39 to 33 per cent, we have to appreciate that a certain burden has been passed from the company to the individual shareholders with the imputation of dividends and the franking of dividends. I would dispute that the cost of this package to the Government has been taken into account. I will not say it will be an offsetting amount, but I would say that with this measure we have passed the burden once more back into the hands of the individual.

PARA.TAB: When we talk about cheapness of operations within Australia, it is a fairly commonly known factor that, quite apart from income tax or company rates of tax, Australian companies and businesses bear the burden—20 per cent of their costs being either State or Federal charges. We would have to look further into the effect of taxation on small business and on companies. Sales tax, fringe benefits tax and training levies—the whole lot—go some way to making Australia uncompetitive from the point of view of doing business. The reduction of taxation to 33 per cent will not alleviate that problem.

Over the last couple of days at Question Time we have heard that the Government will just transfer the burden. In the transfer of the burden of taxation there is an absolute requirement that we look at the taxation of union funds right around Australia. In the last election we saw that the unions within Australia, and the ACTU, were able to make available to the government of the day millions of dollars tax free, to fight the campaign on their behalf. Why would they not make that contribution when they know that what was probably up for grabs was the biggest inequity: the exemption of taxation of union funds. I think it is a disgrace. If there is going to be something done by way of amendment, this is the way it should be done.

PARA.TAB: The taxation laws amendment Bills before the House today continue the Government's long record of tax reform. It is a very historic day when the company tax rate in this country will be moved from 39 per cent down to 33 per cent, which will make us competitive not only internationally but, more importantly, in our region.

The Bill also gives a 10 per cent investment allowance in addition to the development allowance announced last year. It is very important that Australia makes these moves and keeps abreast of developments in the world. We want to ensure that Australian and foreign companies are able to invest in this country under a competitive tax regime. I am sure that the reforms that the House will pass today will go a long way to making that a reality. Since 1983 the Government has introduced a number of taxation reforms to both the company and the personal rates. This Bill provides for quarterly tax payments for companies. That will improve equity between different levels of industry, and it will also improve the outlook for small business.

I thank all honourable members who took part in the debate today. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) asked about division 7 tax. I can answer that question by saying that the Government will not be reintroducing division 7 tax. The reduction in rates is to allow companies to reinvest. To go back to division 7 would work counter to that.

During the debate there was some talk about retrospectivity in relation to the broadbanding depreciation measures. When these measures were introduced it was made crystal clear that the Government's intention was to change those broadbanding rates. Some people have been able to take advantage of the language in that earlier Bill, and this Bill closes those loopholes. The original intention of the Bill has been reinforced, and therefore the Government's view is that there is no retrospectivity.

I was happy to see that the Opposition recognised the benefits of the accrued leave transfer payments. This will be particularly advantageous for industries undergoing micro-economic reform, such as the waterfront where we do have employees changing employers, and the disadvantages in the taxation situation will be rectified.

The Opposition also criticised the large case audit program. The Australian Taxation Office moved in to audit the largest 100 companies in Australia. In view of the amount of revenue collected from that audit, it has been a worthwhile exercise on the part of the Government. Some people who were affected by that may disagree, but certainly it was a move that was long overdue, and possibly should be the focus for the way in which the Tax Office operates—that is, going out into industry. I am sure that, as a result of this large case audit program, when the companies are filing future tax returns they will do so in a way more consistent with the intention of the tax laws of the country.

An independent review of the large case audit program found it to be hugely successful. It is far better to use the resources of the Tax Office in this way to ensure that the taxation laws of the country are supported by industry and that the correct rates of tax are paid. The dropping of the company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent may be some compensation for those who viewed the large case audits in a slightly negative way.

I am particularly pleased that in this legislation the issue of whether donations to charitable organisations are tax deductible has been tidied up and made a lot clearer to read. People who may in the past have had some difficulty in finding out whether contributions were tax deductible will find this legislation a lot easier to read.

The Government's record in tax reform is a long one; we are continuing that. In the future there will be cause for a re-evaluation of the way in which the tax rules are applied. We never reach the end of the road. We have to be sensitive to the way in which taxes impact on companies.I think we have had a look at that. Certainly we will be conducting dialogue with industry to make sure in the future that the tax laws in this country keep pace with the developments.
