TALK.START.PARA: —The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill is to rectify an error in the Bankruptcy Amendment Act 1991. The fact that it is required at all should be seen as a consequence of the Government taking Parliament for granted. The 1991 Bill was a document of more than 80 pages which proposed quite significant changes to the Bankruptcy Act. It proposed major changes to the rights of creditors and major changes to the rights and obligations of bankrupts.

PARA.TAB: The Bill was debated in both Houses on 19 December 1991. That was a day on which the attention of government members and senators was not focused on the merits or demerits of the large volume of legislation before Parliament: their attention was dedicated to who was going to lead the Labor Party. That day was the last sitting day of the year and the Government rushed a large number of Bills through both Houses.

The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill was debated in the Senate, from second reading to completion, for 51 minutes, concluding at 12.40 a.m. The equivalent debate in this House went for 33 minutes, concluding at 2.20 a.m. It may be symptomatic of the manner in which the Government treats Parliament as the rubber stamp of the Executive that there was not one contribution from a Government member or senator to the debate.

The Opposition did support the principle of the 1991 Bill. It was designed to ensure that high-living bankrupts make a contribution from their incomes for the benefit of their creditors. However, it was proposed that a trustee in bankruptcy have power to sign a certificate having the effect of a final judgment of a court without the bankrupt ever having the right to be heard before a court.

More detailed consideration of the 1991 Bill in this House might have disclosed that what was proposed was possibly unconstitutional, its being a purported exercise of the judicial power of the Commonwealth by a person who is not a judge and not a holder of other judicial office entitled to exercise the judicial power of the Commonwealth. More detailed consideration of the 1991 Bill might also have disclosed that the procedure proposed was inherently unfair.

It was pointed out on 19 December 1991 that the Act passed that day would stand as a monument recording the accession of the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) to the Prime Ministership. Bankruptcy has continued under the Keating Government to be the thriving industry it was under the Hawke-Keating Government. In the year ended 30 June 1991 there were 13,091 bankruptcies; the following year there were 16,803. In the first three quarters of the current year there have been 11,123, and there is no end in sight.

Consistent with the pattern of treating parliament as a mere agent of the Executive, this Bill to correct the earlier error is, along with 29 other Bills, subject to the guillotine. Also consistent with the pattern is that there is no anticipated contribution to the debate at all from the Government benches. One might have thought, given the significance of the scheme for the administration of bankruptcies, that the Government might have taken the opportunity to report to the Parliament on the manner in which the scheme has operated—whether it has been successful or whether it has been a failure. My information suggests that there have in fact been practical difficulties irrespective of the challenge to the validity of the scheme. There is no information from the Government.

When the Government does not get it right the community pays the cost. We have the cost of government involvement in a constitutional challenge in the High Court, and constitutional challenges generally are matters of concern to both Federal and State governments. There is also the cost of the drafting and passing of an amendment.

The very limited time available for parliamentary debate of important issues has been restricted even more by the Government declining to call this House together for more than 10 days in the first six months of this year. We are presently focusing our attention on a matter of procedure in the administration of bankruptcies to correct an error in previous legislation. Instead of debating that, we should be considering the state of the economy and how to reduce the number of bankruptcies arising out of the current economic recession.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate on the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill for a similar reason to that of the shadow Minister and honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), and that is, of course, the effect of bankruptcies and their overall influence on small business. Firstly, I too want to look quickly at the matter of administrative competence that this particular Bill raises. The shadow Minister has just pointed out the rush and, in fact, the complete arrogance of the Executive Government in bringing this measure to the Parliament and guillotining it through. Of course, we are actually discussing this particular amendment under guillotine. So nothing has changed. The Government is back on these important measures giving no opportunity for people to draw attention to problems that might arise.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the problems are numerous. This is clearly an occasion under the relevance rules of this Parliament to make sure that the Government is made aware of the disastrous situation which is still confronting the community and of the massive growth in bankruptcy. But, again, many honourable members who would like to participate and make those points on behalf of their constituents have not even bothered to put their names on the list simply because they know they will not get the opportunity.

Is this not a nice start for a new parliament when, in the first 10 days, we are reminded of the Government's administrative incompetence in terms of the pay TV issue? We again had the absolute disaster of a Minister signing the front page, yet having no understanding of what was going on in his department or how proper process and administrative competence should be practised. Yesterday the Leader of the House, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley), got up with a stunned look on his face when he was asked what were the rules for which he is responsible relative to the transfer of Commonwealth funds to tertiary institutions—remembering of course that the Commonwealth has no constitutional right to make such direct transfers and the Government had to introduce a device into this Parliament, which is not of great significance in itself, to make such transfers directly legal.

But the Minister who brought that legislation to parliament could not even tell us what the rules were when he was asked to do so. That is a matter of serious importance. Nor was the Minister aware that in fact his department had transferred at least $900 million in a manner which is clearly either illegal or unconstitutional. If some person decided, for whatever reason, to create a situation where universities would be tipping all their students out onto the street simply because they had to give the money back, I do not know how long it would take to fix up that mess. That is unlikely to occur, but again I ask: why cannot this Government get it right?

We now have this case of a taxpayer being put to expense in the High Court. The Government has been advised that the challenge, which is set down for hearing on 7 June, may well be successful. People would not need the qualifications of the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Tangney—they could be first-year suburban lawyers—to understand that, unless this is one of the constitutional amendments the Government intends to introduce when it makes us a republic, under Australian law they cannot make some receiver in bankruptcy a judge. But that is what this legislation did. People do not have to be very smart to identify that.

On the government front bench we have a line-up of people who are there basically because of the untruths and lies which were told prior to the last election. They want to project themselves to the community as being the cream of the crop; the people with great skills. Some of them have great rhetorical skills: they are pretty good at making a speech, dodging the issue, or refusing to answer questions in parliament by giving us long history lessons. They are good at that, but that does not run the country. Straight administrative competence is required, but in one week we have had three glaring examples of the Government's failure in that regard. Two of them have been huge, both in terms of Australia's reputation and its ability to administer government and large sums of money. The real issue before us today is the inability of this Government and its new Ministers to run the country on basic, funny little administrative issues which should be their first responsibility, rather than strutting around here carrying on in that fashion. It is worth putting that on the record.

Only seconds ago another of the new breed sitting over there did not even know that it was his committee. We were sitting here confused about what was coming on next while he wanted a committee but he did not even know how to ask for it. He then said that he thought it was 1993, but maybe he was talking about 1992. I do not know how that will appear in the record. Perhaps the legislation will be back in this place at some time in the future, remembering of course that in difficult cases the judiciary is obliged to establish the intention of parliament. I am sure it has a very clear message from the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) as to the date being talked about, although he did not seem to know. He read 1992, and then presumed that it was 1993.

This is outrageous, and it is time those opposite went back to school. If there is any good reason for compressing this parliamentary debate, it might be so that those opposite can go back to school during the break to learn about their departments and to learn how to run the country, because a lot of people who are going bankrupt at the moment would like to think that the Government is in charge and that it knows what it is doing.

Another issue was highlighted by the honourable member for Tangney in his address. Whilst we are talking about bankruptcies, let us talk about the figures. The last official figures available are for the year ending 1992. They tell us that in that year 16,880 Australians went bankrupt. Very few of them are in the category this legislation deals with—in other words, very few of them are very wealthy people using the device of bankruptcy to avoid their responsibilities to their creditors but who are then seen driving around in the latest model Mercedes, et cetera.

I agree entirely with the intention of the original legislation, which was to say to those people, `If you still have those sorts of personal resources or income, at least half of it should go to your creditors'. It was a pity the Government did not get that principle right the first time. It is clear that the person who has the money to go to the High Court on this issue has quite a lot of money to protect. The simple fact is that this person has got away with it and, until this particular legislative amendment gets through the Senate, that person will not be subject to that legislation. In other words, due to the incompetence of this Government, the creditors will not receive some of that money which the law was supposed to provide.

But the situation is worse than that. We see that the number of bankruptcies in fact grew by 3,800 in that year. If the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) wants to tell me that is a decline in percentage terms, he is quite right; the base has been growing so quickly the percentages are falling. But the figure for 1990 stood at 8,552, and in that very short two-year period we have seen a 100 per cent growth in bankruptcies.

A very large number of these are small business operators who have gone broke. A number of them made investments on the strength of government promises. Do you remember them all, Mr Deputy Speaker? There was the promise that interest rates would fall when in fact they went through the roof, as well as the constant plea for people to go out and invest because the economy was on its way up. Some people believe Prime Ministers and Treasurers when they say things like that. But these are some of the people now joining the queues petitioning for bankruptcy. It is a tragedy that small business, which I have the responsibility to represent in this place, features prominently in the statistics I have just mentioned.

I already have quite a proud reputation in the area of bankruptcy law. I was able to convince—and I think against the recommendations of his own department—the then Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, to look at the situation where people could become instant bankrupts by going into the bankruptcy office and asking for advice. I understand that when the then Attorney-General went to his department and said, `Listen, it seems pretty crook that people can become instant bankrupts; they are not counselled or assisted and they do not understand what they are doing', apparently he was told that his department was in the business of bankrupting people, not about giving them advice—which is pretty tragic. But the law has been changed, to the credit of this Government and of Lionel Bowen who listened to my examples of people going to the bankruptcy office without knowing what they were about. If I have done little else in this place, I am proud that my representations at this dispatch box on that occasion convinced the Government to do something.

That raises the issue of the guillotine which does not allow honourable members the time to raise issues. Bankruptcy law does not come before this House every week. There are very limited opportunities for honourable members, under the rules of relevance, to raise issues and to bring to the attention of government side issues, if you like, which are of great importance to individuals—such as having a system whereby people can be counselled or where there may be a cooling-off period before they find themselves in the dreadful situation of facing bankruptcy, which very few understand. Considering the intent of this legislation, people must wonder when they see some of our more notable bankrupts on television driving the latest model Mercedes. But that is just another reason for such legislation.

But what is the news? What is the future for 721,000 small businesses that currently operate from 900,000 different locations in Australia—the only part of industry that is identified by all the experts as being an employment generator? Those in small business farming enterprises have not got much to be hopeful about. They are in the worst possible situation of the cyclical price cycle joining up with a downturn in the seasonal cycle, and for many it is a disastrous situation. Some of us had the opportunity in very limited time to discuss that matter last night and point out to the Government how much more help is needed.

Then there are people like small business retailers. What was the news they got yesterday: a 1.2 per cent fall in retail sales. For the information of the Parliament, 1.2 per cent does not sound like much; it was $100 million for a month. Where does that $100 million come from in terms of big retailers and small retailers? It comes straight off the bottom line. It is not well understood by many honourable members in the Labor Government that that is the problem. Business does not get anything out of its risk or its enterprise until its turnover exceeds a certain figure. It has to wait for that last little bit of turnover which turns into profit. Such falls in retail sales—might I add the third fall in the last four months—is not good news for small business. Clearly it is not good news for the potential to reduce the number of bankrupts that this legislation attempts to address.

As I stated earlier, a lot of these people are making investment decisions based on the rhetoric of the Government. We have a new group of potential small business people, those who are losing their jobs, getting the golden handshake and going out and desperately trying to buy themselves employment. They are paying $100,000 or $200,000 for things like TAB agencies. Recently I was discussing some franchising initiatives with someone and it was suggested that maybe an advertisement should be placed in the paper to try and find the level of interest. The person there, who is an expert in this field, said, `Don't. You won't be able to handle the paperwork. There'll be so many people desperately trying to buy themselves a job through the franchise market, through TAB agencies and many of those other sorts of operations'.

From my knowledge of the racing industry, it is absolutely painfully silly. Some people were actually paying $150,000 for a TAB agency that had a theoretical life of about six months because its agreement with the TAB was about to run out. Of course, that created great problems for the TAB because these people were stuck. But that is the level of their desperation. How many of them will end up as statistics on the bankruptcy lists unless something happens?

I make the point that it is wrong for governments to go out and claim economic growth, interest rate falls—you name it—no more taxes, if that is not its intention, because for those poor people it is their last chance in life. They have got their redundancy payment, their golden handshake. They are too young to be on the pension and they think, `I will make a business investment because the Prime Minister said so.' The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) is strutting around telling us that the economy is growing at 2.5 per cent. He does not tell us that the Government's own borrowings, $16 billion this year—in fact, 16 per cent of government outlays—is having a major impact on that economic growth. It is artificial.

I do not know how the two figures can be compared, but it is interesting to read and work out that a $16 billion deficit—in other words, government putting funny money into the economy—is roughly 4 per cent of GDP. If we can pick $400 billion as a reasonably sound figure for GDP it is 4 per cent, and we only have economic growth of 2.5 per cent. If that deficit were removed from the structure, if someone had the kindness to our children to say, `We are not going to keep stacking debt up on you to maintain our position of political dominance in this country'—because it is the kids who are going to pay that $16 billion that has been overspent this year—and removed it from the equation, what would be the level of economic growth in Australia? Clearly, it would be negative.

It can be argued that the Government is acting properly in propping up the economy, but what is the measure, the rule for these people going out—and there are thousands of them going out through decisions being forced on them. The total incompetence of the previous Victorian Labor Government is a classic example. We do not only find it here, where Ministers do not know what their departments are doing and do not know where the billions are going; we saw it in Victoria, and no-one would know that better than you, Mr Deputy Speaker.

Last night the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) was rabbiting on about the closure of the Midland railway workshops in Western Australia. He wants to pick this isolated issue. He chooses to ignore that the railways have been telling successive governments that if they did not get rid of the workshops, the entire rail system and all the associated employment was at risk. The simple fact was that in the open, competitive market that now exists in transport, in this case in Western Australia, Westrail could not carry the lead in the saddlebags of a $20 million-plus loss each year from its workshops and be competitive with the road transport industry. In many cases it is down to shifting less than 1,000 tonnes a kilometre along the rail system when, of course, in the north-west the iron ore producers shift 80,000 tonnes of iron ore per kilometre.

What is the point at which the switch is turned off on the lot? That is what happened in Victoria. The Labor Government sold the trams to pay the wages. It sold the buses to pay the wages and it sold the railway rolling stock to do the same. Now, Mr Deputy Speaker, your constituents are stuck with paying $800 million a year to Japanese financial institutions to rent back those sorts of things. These are the problems and this is the issue: how many more people are going to go bankrupt under such a slack administration, and how many more people will find themselves making unwise investments and going bankrupt because they believed the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he said, `Everything is okay'; a Prime Minister who believes the Treasurer when he says, `No new taxes'.

In closing, how many of these people have been bankrupted by the current tax regime? We have just finished debating a Bill to reduce tax on companies. Of course, very few small businesses are incorporated, one of the reasons being that this Government has never been able to work out a practical system of closed corporation. It brought a disaster here and it still cannot work it out, notwithstanding that there is a simple solution which I would be prepared to provide to the Government at any time and which I hope will become the policy of the coalition.

The simple fact is that that is fine if the company is making a profit, but what about all the taxes, like payroll tax? How many receivers in bankruptcy see the Tax commissioner as a major creditor? How many times is it that the Tax commissioner bowls these people over and is the first to go to court with a petition in bankruptcy? Frequently it is not income tax; in fact, seldom. It is the failure to pay payroll tax and, of course, if the bankrupt happens to be a truckie, it is fuel tax; they have paid it but it has sent them broke. The farmers of the more remote regions, the orange growers—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members for their contributions in this debate. People in the gallery might be surprised to note that the Opposition is actually supporting this measure, notwithstanding the breadth of comment made. I am actually pleased that the shadow Minister for small business, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), made a contribution. He has a strong record of interest in the area of bankruptcy reform. I note his comments in relation to the former Attorney-General, Lionel Bowen, and I am pleased that he recognises that, notwithstanding the normal circumstances that characterise debate, that is, often a debate on the death, there are occasions when good suggestions can be put forward by members from either side of the House and adopted in a spirit of compromise and good administration.

PARA.TAB: I make the point, simply for clarification, that there has been a drop in the level of bankruptcies in the last five quarters—simply to place in context the comments that have been made in relation to the overall incidence of bankruptcy. But the background to this particular legislation flows from a concern regarding the validity of measures that were introduced in order to ensure that bankrupts with a stream of income made a proper contribution to their estates.

One of the more prominent of those that might be subject to this regime is Christopher Skase. In due course his estate assessed him as being liable to make substantial contributions from income. Mr Skase did not make the payments as required and the trustee attempted to file the certificate in the New South Wales District Court under the impugn section.

Under the legislation the certificate filed by the trustee would have had the effect, and be enforced as if it were the judgment, of the court in which it was filed. Mr Skase commenced proceedings in the High Court in February this year to have subsections 1 to 39ZG, subparagraphs (3),(4) and (5) of the Bankruptcy Act declared unconstitutional in that it conferred the judicial power of the Commonwealth on a person other than a judge.

The case is expected to come on for hearing before a full bench of the court in June. The Government has been advised that the High Court is likely to hold that the impugn provisions are invalid and, accordingly, it is bringing forward this legislation to ensure that the trustees are able to initiate court proceedings to recover unpaid income contributions from persons who have refused or failed to pay them. We are pleased that the Opposition is supporting this measure and we look forward to the speedy passage of this legislation through the Senate.

As I said in introducing this measure, the Government has determined that the integrity of the important reforms it has made in the bankruptcy area is maintained, and it brings forward this Bill in order to achieve it.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Dairy Produce Amendment Bill will give the Australian Dairy Corporation more commercial flexibility in financing its arrangements by allowing the corporation to undertake future dealings with banks, although this will be restricted to hedging. The effect will be to remove uncertainty concerning the ability of the corporation to secure exchange rates and cover the financial risks involved in international trade. The powers are similar to those previously conferred on other marketing authorities such as the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Australian Wheat Board. The coalition fully supports and welcomes the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The dairy industry is an important Australian industry—a very progressive and forward looking industry that has come a long way in a short time. Export income from dairy products this financial year is expected to exceed $900 million, up from $761 million last financial year—a very strong performance in anyone's language. This year, Australia's production of milk is expected to exceed 7,000 million litres of milk, which will be the highest level of production for 20 years.

However, in contrast with several past occasions, this high level of production has not resulted in calls for cuts in production. This year the extra production has been welcomed and the only product causing some concern is butter. Australian dairy farmers have been through a vigorous restructuring program which, in some senses, is not unlike the magnitude of the restructuring program being confronted by the very troubled members of the citrus and tobacco industries.

It is interesting to note that some 20 years ago there were no less than 47,000 dairy farmers in this country. Today there are only about 8,000 dairy farmers and they are producing as much milk if not more than was produced by the 47,000 farmers 20 years ago. They certainly can hold their heads high as being amongst the most efficient, perhaps the most efficient, in the world.

In just 10 years they have achieved a 25 per cent increase in the annual amount of milk produced per cow, by better breeding, concentration on nutritional matters and so forth. In actual volumes, 10 years ago it was something like 3,000 litres; this year it will top 4,000 litres.

During that time the average herd size has more than doubled as a result of the rationalisation of the number of farmers, and at the same time sales of milk in Australia are continuing to increase. During 1991-92 sales increased by 32 million litres to 1.8 billion litres in total.

It is interesting to note that Australia's per capita consumption of dairy products at 102.9 kilograms per head per annum is still a considerable way behind many similar countries abroad, which indicates that there is still room for expansion in Australian domestic consumption. The Irish manage to eat their way through 184 kilograms of dairy product per year per head of population—

TALK.START.PARA: —And no fewer than 20 potatoes.

—In addition to all the potatoes. They certainly export a lot of beef; I do not know how much they eat at home. The Finns consume some 172 kilograms of dairy product per year per head; the Scandinavians around 156 kilograms, and New Zealanders 134 kilograms. The Danes, the Swiss and the Americans also consume more dairy product per head than we do. So there is room for expansion. The dairy industry has shown that it is capable of innovation and of clever and appropriate marketing. It shows every intention of ensuring that it is able to capitalise on that potential for further expansion.

PARA.TAB: It would be appropriate to mention that the European Community is still engaging in massive subsidisation of a range of products, and dairying is no exception. As a result, Australian dairy farmers have had to trade into highly corrupted markets for many years. And it should be noted that they do not have tariff protection in the domestic market apart from an EC tariff quota arrangement. This latter simply means that, after the European Community has shipped 11,000 tonnes of cheese into Australia, we are entitled to put on an import duty which is equivalent to the amount of export subsidy actually paid by the EC to its exporters.

In March of this year, the EC actually cut some of its huge subsidies. That is a very welcome development and has the potential of lifting returns to the Australian dairy industry by some $30 million. Regrettably, many people in Europe do not seem to realise just how much it costs them as taxpayers to keep the EC dairy industry going. But, even after these reductions in payments to its exporters, the EC still pays out moneys amounting to something like a subsidisation of 240 per cent over world prices. For example, the butter refund paid to EC exporters is $3,393 per tonne—a quite remarkable figure. For butter oil, it is $4,362 a tonne; for cheddar cheese, $2,910 a tonne; for skim milk powder, $1,212 a tonne; and for whole milk powder, $2,620 a tonne. If only we could make European consumers aware of the true cost of those arrangements we might be further ahead.

I turn my attention for a moment to AQIS and its relationship to the dairy industry. It seems important to state that our dairy exporters would be considerably helped if the Government let the industry become more responsible for its own quality control and forced the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to be more efficient. AQIS currently charges the dairy industry about $2 million a year—a not insubstantial amount of money. In round figures, 70 per cent of that money is for overheads while only 30 per cent relates to the actual cost of inspection.

There is no doubt in my mind that those figures ought to be the other way around. If overheads can be reduced to constitute just a 30 per cent addition to the cost of actual inspection, the cost of export inspection would come down by 50 per cent. That would be a very desirable objective, not just to the dairy industry but right across the range of agricultural exports. Australia is put at an international disadvantage in terms of its competitiveness not only by the level of those charges but also, in some instances, by the mere fact that they are levelled on a user-pays basis vis-a-vis the Americans, who do not face that situation at all.

The Australian Dairy Products Federation believes that the methods currently used by AQIS to recover costs and to administer this system add substantially to the overall operating costs of AQIS. For example, each individual export certificate is charged for instead of the more sensible approach of simply levelling an overall charge. It would be interesting to extract an answer from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) as to why commercial certificates have been introduced for trader-to-trader deals. If the traders do not need or want them, why does AQIS issue them? At this time, AQIS should be winding back its involvement in the dairy industry rather than extending it.

The industry is highly sophisticated. It is adopting world best practice quality management techniques at a faster rate than any other commodity groups. The dairy industry has a vested interest, which it obviously recognises, in getting the thing right. It seems to me that there is real need and justification for less interference, not more. The dairy industry would like to deregulate exports and, in the eyes of the coalition, the only time AQIS ought to be inspecting is when the importing country demands such an inspection.

In essence, why should the dairy industry be different from other processed food industry sectors such as biscuit and confectionary manufacturers? These sectors also use dairy products but they do not require AQIS inspection. On top of all of this, if we look at the situation logically, all milk produced must meet the standard set by a State milk authority. Surely, if the milk is fit for us to drink, it must also be fit for manufacture into dairy products.

There is a need then for less inspection. At the moment, milk must pass the State milk authority and then AQIS. And, as companies enter into more independent quality control programs, they are then audited by organisations such as Standards Australia. We also have the ridiculous system that, if a dairy is being modified for a dairy company which produces for both domestic and export markets, the building must be approved by both the State and the Federal bodies. Surely, this is another example of where we could cut back on both costs and red tape. For example, the Commonwealth might be able to accept a State accreditation even if it had to insist on a few extra columns in the paperwork being filled.

The cost of doing business in this country is too high and here are some examples of areas where reform could be effectively implemented. The dairy industry has led the way with value added product, but it is being hampered in its expansion by cost and closed markets. The Government has yet to properly address the issue of reducing costs. Our factory owners still pay payroll tax while their competitors abroad, generally speaking, do not. The milk tankers are still subject to a wholesale sales tax of 20 per cent; there are 18 tyres on a milk tanker and the tax on each tyre is $90 and the excise on fuel is some 27c a litre.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who collects all that?

—The Government, and it is not rebatable. The indirect tax system is not rebatable to business sectors. Transport costs are possibly double those faced by competitor nations abroad. Are we or are we not serious about becoming truly internationally competitive? Are we or are we not serious about addressing this nation's chronic trade balance problem? There is much to be done. It would be appropriate for the Government to pay more attention to bilateral trade agreements in an attempt to open up many of the currently closed markets in Asia for packaged dairy products. But the Opposition does support the legislation.

—The Dairy Produce Amendment Bill provides the Australian Dairy Corporation with greater commercial flexibility in dealing with banks and, as the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), has just indicated, the coalition parties support that sensible improvement in the ability of the Australian Dairy Corporation to do business. The Australian Dairy Corporation is an important element in the dairy industry and has a significant role to play in Australia's exports to certain countries, particularly Japan. But the major exporter in the dairy industry is not the Australian Dairy Corporation but the individual dairy companies or the specialist dairy exporting companies. I want to talk more about the dairy industry as an exporter and also the Victorian dairy industry.

PARA.TAB: The dairy industry in Australia basically has two elements: firstly, the milk for human consumption, otherwise known as city milk or market milk—that industry being based in each State—and, secondly, the manufacturing sector, the major part of the industry, the majority of which is in Victoria. Victoria produces 61 per cent of Australia's milk while having 59 per cent of the national dairy herd. It produces 75 per cent of the locally consumed manufactured dairy products—that is, butter, cheese, milk powder, et cetera—but 90 per cent of our dairy exports. In fact, the dairy industry is the largest food processing industry in Australia. It is the largest value adding agricultural industry in Australia, and one of the largest value adding industries of any type in Australia. In Victoria, the dairy industry is also the largest volume exporter of any product made in Victoria. That is quite often forgotten in Victoria and elsewhere. Just recently, the United Dairy Farmers of Victoria had a special dairy week referring to the dairy industry as the quiet achiever. Too often, no-one recognises the significance of this industry to Victoria and to exports from Victoria.

The dairy industry is quite often forgotten when one looks at our exports or compares them. One of the reasons why manufactured exports have increased is that the statistician has moved butter, cheese, whole milk, skim milk powder, et cetera—dairy exports—from agriculture to manufacturing. When we look at agricultural exports we see beef, wheat and wool and then depending on what is happening in a particular year, cotton or sugar is quoted as the next most significant agricultural export when neither of them is the next most significant export.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sugar is very important.

—Sugar is very important and cotton is very important. I certainly acknowledge that but I hope, in return, I will get the acknowledgment that dairying is more important than either of those. There is over $1,000 million in dairy exports each year and that is increasing. Over $900 million of those exports come from Victoria.
—But they don't show in the—

—That is the problem because they are not shown as a commodity export in agriculture and they are broken up into different components whether it is butter, cheese or whatever in manufacturing. When people are using some of the rather naive and superficial comparisons one hears in this place, including at Question Time yesterday, there is no understanding or acknowledgment of the fact that we are really talking about a great agricultural industry being used to bolster the exports of manufacturing products.

PARA.TAB: I am certainly a strong supporter for an increase in manufactured products. After all if fewer than five per cent of Australians, that is farmers, can produce about 25 per cent of our exports, surely 15 per cent of the employed work force, meaning the manufacturing sector, should be able to do far better than that five per cent, without fiddling the figures. I would hope that that happens. There is evidence that progress is being made in that regard.

I want to concentrate now more on the manufacturing sector of the industry. The city milk or human milk sector is controlled by State legislation, and it is the manufacturing sector of the industry that is controlled by Federal legislation. There was recent Government legislation, supported by the Coalition parties, to provide a new stability in planning and marketing arrangements, through to the year 2000. We supported that, and that was confirmed in the primary industry policy for the recent election. The coalition does fully support that policy, going right through to the year 2000.

I commended the Government when the legislation came in, and I commend the Government again now, that it does provide that stability. But I want to talk about the single most significant dairying area of Australia. That happens to be my electorate. The Northern Victoria irrigation area, of which almost all is within the Murray electorate, produces over 40 per cent of milk in Victoria, or about one-quarter of all the milk produced in Australia. If one includes the production over the river in the irrigation area in the electorate of Farrer, the electorate of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), the total percentage for Australia goes up to over 30 per cent.

As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Gwydir, the shadow Minister has indicated, the dairy industry has been through a dramatic rationalisation over the last 20 or so years. Over the last 12 years there has been a 24 per cent reduction in the number of dairy farms in Victoria. That is the same as elsewhere in Australia, but in that time dairy production in Victoria has risen by 31 per cent and in my area it has risen by 37 per cent. The productivity per dairy farm over the last 12 years in Victoria has increased by a staggering 73 per cent. I am not aware of any other industry in Australia, agricultural, manufacturing or tertiary, that has that record of productivity. Certainly, in my area, the rate of productivity is actually increasing rather than declining. That is partly because of the development that is going on there, year in year out, as it quietly becomes an even more important part of the total industry in Australia. Partly because of the confidence that is there, it is in the right part of Australia, and also the price outlook, although still volatile, is better than for other agricultural industries at the present time.

That rationalisation I referred to has not been restricted to dairy farms. For example, in Victoria, the number of companies and factories in the last 12 years has basically halved, and the average throughput of those factories is up 300 per cent. This indicates the dramatic change in efficiency in those factories as well. In the Murray electorate there is the greatest concentration of food processing or value adding factories in agriculture in Australia. There are 8 1/2 dairy—and the half is Plumrose which is both dairy and horticulture—and eight others. There are two Bonlac; two Murray Goulburn—the giant cooperatives—Tatura, the third cooperative; Kraft has two factories; and Nestle has a factory. In addition, there are seven other horticultural processing factories.

That is where the real action in value adding in agriculture and food processing is taking place in this nation. If we are to turn around our declining market share in value added agricultural products in Asia, and to expand our value added agricultural exports generally, a lot of the action will have to take place in my electorate. That means a significant amount of investment, both on the farm and off the farm, and a significant amount of investment is taking place. I will refer to that in a minute. But—and this is a great worry in the area—there is not as much investment taking place as there could be, there should be and there needs to be, particularly in relation to horticultural companies looking at New Zealand versus Australia as the best place in which to base their operations for further exports to the Asian area.

The reason why there is not the investment that I would hope there would be is, first of all Australia, unlike New Zealand and a number of other exporting countries, does not have a goods and services tax or value added tax. That, by itself, removes a five per cent export impediment or added cost that we have in this country, by the working through of the indirect tax system to which the previous speaker referred. This gives the New Zealanders a tremendous start in costs over us. Also, compared to New Zealand, the cost of putting a kilogram in a dairy factory or a can in a horticultural processing factory in New Zealand is now at least 20 per cent less than in Australia and in my electorate, because of the improvements that have taken place in work force productivity.

If one looks at waterfront costs, Owen Jennings, the head of the New Zealand Farmers' Federation was quoting here recently that the average turnaround of a ship in Auckland is $4,500 and in Melbourne it is $25,000. Another figure that the dairy industry has put up is that the net income of the average New Zealand dairy farmer has been increased by over $3,000, due to the improvement in waterfront productivity in that country compared to Australia. This gives its dairy farmers and exporters of dairy and horticultural products a tremendous advantage over us. As the Deputy Leader of the National Party also mentioned, there are these AQIS costs which are unnecessary intrusions by AQIS into the export dairy industry.

Another reason why there is not the investment that we would all hope there would be, is that there are restrictions by a number of Asian countries into their importing of value added products. Quite often the import duty, or outright restriction, will come into place the more the value adding takes place with a particular product. This is true for the dairy industry as it is for wool and horticulture.

There is also, because of those restrictions, the uncertainty about how far to go into brand development in this country. There is also the continuing uncertainty over the export subsidy policies of the European Community and the United States. The recent reduction in export subsidies or restitutions by the European Community for its dairy exports has meant strengthening in the dairy market. However, the United States has increased its export subsidies through its version of EEP for the dairy industry, called DEIP, the dairy export incentive program, and that is now having an impact in some of our markets. There is also now the uncertainty over Russia which for a number of years was quite a reasonable market for some of our product.

In spite of this, at the present time in my area there is over $200 million of investment taking place in dairy factories. Kraft, at its two factories, is spending about $90 million. Nestle, based at Tongala, is quietly spending about $15 million at a time. Murray Goulburn and Bonlac are both spending about $50 million each, and Tatura in a joint venture is spending another $40 million. There is other expenditure as well.

There are just two points I want to make about that investment. First of all, at a big function at the Nestle factory at Tongala about a month ago, it was declared the first Nestle factory anywhere in the world to be a recipient of an international quality standards award. I think it was about the fourth such dairy award made in Australia. Its commitment to exports based more and more on the northern irrigation area was confirmed. Its commitment to export quality was confirmed and it indicated that in the next three years it wanted to increase its dairy exports from $150 million a year at the present time to $250 million a year.

Nestle has indicated that it sees its brands of dairy exports into Asia as coming more and more from Australia; hence its quiet expansion all the time. It sees the amount of dairy exports coming from Europe as declining, and Nestle should know what is going on in the dairy industry in Europe given that it has its base there. That export potential is a very encouraging prospect, and not only for my area but for the industry generally.

I will also refer to Tatura where there is a cooperative factory in a joint venture with Snow brand, one of the major dairy companies in Japan. There are several advantages in having this joint venture at Tatura. Firstly, it overcomes the critical and perennial problem of having enough capital in cooperatives to be able to provide what is necessary for further processing, et cetera. Secondly, it means that the packaging and value adding is now taking place in Tatura and not in Japan. It also indicates the commonsense thinking of the management of a dairy company here which is working with another firm in another country to guarantee continuing access for Australian product to that country. What Tatura is doing is not unique; there are quite a number of other dairy companies doing the same thing at the present time.

If one looks at the dairy farms in northern Victoria, a similar investment is taking place. The efficiency of irrigation technology is increasing and at the same time the dairy farmers are overcoming the biggest problem confronting the industry in northern Victoria and southern New South Wales—the watertable problem. A tremendous effort is being made by dairy farmers because they are the major users of water in this area. They are trying to increase their productivity and reduce the access of water into the watertable by lasering and other techniques. There is a significant investment taking place in on-farm equipment which will further add to that productivity and further add to the concentration of the industry in this part of Australia.

I think it is a most encouraging story, but it could be better. I hope the Government does take into account some of those cost impediments whose removal or reduction would further add to the ability of this great industry to expand in the area that the Government and the Opposition and all of us would want it to expand in: in value adding here in Australia. It is good to hear a positive story about an industry in Australia at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Next to the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), I represent the largest dairy electorate in Australia. The electorate of Gippsland encompasses more than 2,000 dairy farmers and their families, who are largely centred on the Maffra irrigation area—south Gippsland and east Gippsland dairy districts. Gippslanders full well appreciate and understand the economic and social importance of the dairy industry to their own way of life, because so many of the smaller and even larger regional towns in Gippsland are heavily dependent on the dairy industry for their very viability. What happens to the dairy industry is of critical importance to all Gippslanders, so dairy farmers are very well appreciated throughout the length and breadth of Gippsland.

PARA.TAB: As my colleagues the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) and the honourable member for Murray have stressed, the last decade or so has been a very turbulent time for the dairy industry. This has been brought about particularly through government legislation during the mid-1980s. Over two or three years in this place we debated at great length the legislation brought forward by the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin). More recently, last year, the legislation to succeed the so-called Kerin plan was introduced by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who is at the table. There are some people who would have us rewrite history and, with the legislative changes in the 1980s that were called the Kerin plan, they so easily forget the role of the National and Liberal parties at that time.

Nobody would better remember that period than the honourable member for Murray, given that he had the responsibility of the shadow portfolio of primary industries. It was only the work by the honourable member for Murray and others occupying the opposition benches that changed very significantly several aspects of the Kerin legislation and that brought about the best possible result, given the framework of the legislation. We used the Senate to bring about those changes after the honourable member for Werriwa refused to make some of those fundamental alterations. So it was the coalition, using its numbers in the Senate, which laid the groundwork for the later legislative changes, as I say, last year. The National and Liberal parties have had a very significant role to play over the last 10 years in legislation passing through this place.

The dairy industry also has been rocked by the general economic conditions that have left nobody in the rural sector unscathed. We keep repeating a constant theme of costs, as the honourable member for Murray stressed, given the Government's reluctance to take up the battle in that regard. It is not true to say that governments can have little influence over the downturns and swings of the international marketplace and how they affect commodity prices. Governments can create an economic setting which allows our export industries, such as the dairy industry, to be so much more competitive, if they bring down costs. The honourable member for Gwydir especially stressed this point.

Whilst the dairy industry is enjoying a period of stability and relatively high returns for dairy farmers, there is no reason for complacency at all. After all, those good returns have been coming through only over the last 18 months or so. There is reason for optimism, as the honourable member for Murray rightly states, but, whilst a number of the factories, cooperatives and companies processing milk have tried to cut their own costs so as to pass on higher returns to the farmers, there is a limit to what they can do. Government imposed costs and a still inflexible and rigid industrial relations system constrain them. There is plenty of scope for the Government to do a great deal more yet so that dairy farmers can enjoy higher returns.

The dairy industry, although it has more confidence than it has had for a long time, still feels very exposed and vulnerable to sudden shifts on the international trading scene. On the best assessments available to us, there is reason for cautious optimism, but things can change very quickly, especially given the uncertainties of eastern Europe and what that means for European producers of milk. So we have to take this breathing period, if you like, grab the opportunity and fully utilise the time we have available to us to put our own house in order. It is true that we cannot blame governments for everything, and particularly not for downturns in international prices, but we can blame them or, more properly said, sheet home responsibility to them, for costs.

Dairy farmers, almost unanimously, enthusiastically embraced the National and Liberal parties at the time of the last election because they saw this as an opportunity to reduce their costs in a way that the Labor Government could never bring about. Any factory that did the calculations of abolition of payroll tax, abolition of wholesale sales tax and abolition of 26c a litre petrol excise could see how farmers would be so much better off. They could pass on to the farmers, by way of higher prices, these savings from government imposed taxes. We should not for a moment believe that dairy farmers have lost the incentive to force government to bring about tax reform. We know that this Government's orientation is towards tax cuts for middle income earners, but we must get taxes off the point of production.

The Government cannot hide at all from the demand of dairy farmers for micro-economic reform in transport and handling, in the waterfront. On all of this New Zealand does set benchmarks. Whatever the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy may think about aspects of New Zealand economic policy, the fact is that it has lowered costs remarkably. To take a specific example, in processed foods—forgive me for saying it—we are just going to be creamed by New Zealand in so many areas. Dairy farmers are in the main unprotected, particularly in regard to closer economic relations with New Zealand. Occasionally a theoretical economist in Canberra dreams up the most complex and weird and wonderful formulas to show that there is some percentage of protection for dairy farmers, but we know that, in regard to the most obvious forms of protection, such as tariffs or trade agreements, dairy farmers are quite on their own. Dairy farmers have learnt for a very long time to compete in the international marketplace without government assistance. They have to cope now with imports from New Zealand under closer economic relations, but they cannot do it while they have a fixed structure of costs that is many times more oppressive than that which their New Zealand counterparts have.

People are voting with their feet. We are losing manufacturers from Australia to New Zealand on almost a daily basis, and certainly on a weekly basis. Some of the figures are staggering. Some months ago I visited an electrical supplier to the automotive industry in the southern suburbs of Melbourne, which is where so much of the manufacturing belt resides. That supplier showed me the vast warehouse and former factory space from which it supplied the car industry in Melbourne. That supplier has moved to New Zealand. The reason for that move was simply that the per hour payment to an employee, including the government add-on costs such as payroll tax, workers compensation, land tax and the like—which are not all federal taxes, admittedly—was $17.50. In New Zealand it is $9.80 an hour.

Then I visited a whitegoods manufacturer who, in the last 12 months, has shifted from Melbourne to New Zealand. Again, I saw the same scene: an empty factory with a `for lease' or `for sale' sign out the front, with weeds growing up it. The disposal of property is another story, of course. For that manufacturer the add-on cost in Victoria, before a change of government—which I hope and expect will make a difference—was 56c. So for every dollar another 56c went in add-on costs; in New Zealand it is 19c. That is one-way traffic, but there is also traffic the other way, into Australia. That traffic has implications for a whole range of manufacturers, including makers of processed foods, and also for dairy farmers.

We take a great deal of delight in the stability and good returns which the dairy industry enjoys at the moment, but those things could disappear overnight with a sudden change in international trade. Also, let us take the opportunity to furiously drive home the need to lower costs by way of tax reform and micro-economic reform. This is not some theoretical economic debate; it matters tremendously to rural areas such as Gippsland, where the economic health of the dairy industry directly influences the people beyond the farm gate many times over.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Yesterday the Prime Minister told the House that Cabinet had been misled by submissions from Senator Collins in relation to the prospects for microwave television being up and running well before satellite digital compression technology. I ask the Prime Minister: why then did the Government introduce an amendment to part VII of the Broadcasting Services Act in November last year specifically to permit pay TV subscribers to microwave transmissions to migrate to satellite transmissions if they wished? Is it not also a fact that the tender documents issued in December for the additional microwave licences stated specifically that the licences would be available for pay TV? Can he say whether it is also a fact that Senator Collins had been publicly quite open about the possibility of the early introduction of microwave pay TV, and that on the Channel 10 program Meet the Press in November 1992 he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Microwave services are likely to broadcast the first pay-TV.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether the Opposition—I do not say this in a pejorative way—is genuinely confused about this issue or just after a bit of devilment. The point is that when the satellite was considered as the primary delivery system for pay television, in the first instance it was considered for an analogue system; that is, basically one channel on each transponder. Of course, given the fact that with that technology it would have been a much earlier introduction of services, anyone owning narrowcasting licences for MDS could have presumed to have been able to deliver services at about the same time.

PARA.TAB: But the Government changed that when it decided to mandate digital technology on the satellite; in other words, it decided to establish a standard for the delivery of compressed digital signals off the satellite. The development of that standard and the development of all the software that went with it meant that there would be a delay of some time, maybe two years, in the delivery of that system.

We have no objection to MDS as a technology playing a role in pay television services. It probably will under any model because even the satellite, under digital compression, at the end reaches what is called infill. Cable and MDS will probably play a role. The point is that it should not play a role as a primary system before the satellite—not two years earlier. That is the point. That was never intended by the Cabinet and that is what could not be permitted: we were not to have a system which could cream-skim the capital cities of Sydney and Melbourne, and maybe Brisbane, reach about 30 per cent of the community, but tie up all the primary film suppliers and, in a de facto way, cut off the broader national option of the satellite cable and MDS infill as a primary system because it had got up and started commercially. The position is as simple as that. That is the position that remains today.

As far as I know, the Opposition has agreed to pass legislation so that that would be the case; that is, that MDS does not get the jump on the satellite. That is all we are saying. There is no obscurantism here—no view that MDS is some inferior technology that cannot play a role, with the `a' underlined; rather than the role, with the `the' underlined. That is the point I was making to the Leader of the National Party yesterday—that he was supposedly telling us that he is out there barracking for rural interests, when most of the countryside would not get pay TV services under an MDS system—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's wrong.
—That is not wrong. It is exactly right. That is the point that the Minister for Communications has been making about the policy vis-a-vis the process.

PARA.TAB: The policy will deliver with a combination of digital compression, which will, I think, be the first off the satellite for a major country, the extension of cable—the cable already laid by Telecom and that to be laid by Optus and other people—and MDS, either in a narrowcasting position or as part of the infill for the broader system. This will probably give Australia, if not the best, then very close to the best pay television system in the world. That is all there to happen.

All the Opposition has been debating for the last couple of days is whether or not there was capacity on the part of the tenderers which might have been revealed by a deposit. That is a matter of process, but it is not a matter of policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Tourism aware of significantly increased interest in the United States about Australia as a holiday destination? —The honourable member for Paterson, in his former capacity as the shire president of Port Stephens, has had a very long interest in tourism. As the honourable member for Paterson his interest now extends right up the Hunter Valley, and I am sure that he will work hard for the tourism industry, not only in his own electorate but for Australia as a whole. I welcome his question.

PARA.TAB: Insomniacs, shift workers, and even one or two people in Parliament House, may have seen some of the Good Morning America program currently being broadcast from Australia throughout the United States on the ABC network—that is, the ABC network not run by David Hill. If the Prime Minister is not listening to Mahler's Eighth Symphony tonight, then at about midnight on Channel 9 he will get the chance to see the Good Morning America program.

The ATC has been instrumental in persuading Good Morning America to come to Australia. At a cost of around $300,000, the ATC has helped secure the most significant promotional coup for the Australian tourism industry since Crocodile Dundee. It is a pity that the Opposition does not have a bit more interest in that. Even if the ATC had spent its entire marketing budget in the United States, it could not have bought as much time as Australia has received on the Good Morning America program this week.

Good Morning America will conclude this Friday with an appearance by the Prime Minister—saving the best till last—after a week showing the highlights of Cairns, Brisbane, the Gold Coast, Melbourne, Ballarat, Tasmania and Sydney. If a 30-minute program is more effective than a 30-second ad, then all honourable members should see the value in having 12 hours of morning television in the United States with a viewing audience of about 40 million American citizens. That will provide a great boost to the Australian tourism industry.

To make sure that Australian tourism gets the greatest possible return from that attention, this week the ATC and Qantas have been running advertisements during Good Morning America targeting the West Coast, New York, Boston, Washington, Dallas, Chicago and Colorado markets. Those advertisements have featured a toll free number, and that number has already received more than 2,500 calls. In addition, print media advertisements have promoted special discount air fares and holiday packages to Australia.

As I said, I am very confident that these six programs will provide a very dramatic boost to the number of American travellers to Australia. Research shows that every one of those travellers spends more than $2,000, and that helps create jobs, and it certainly helps boost our tourism industry. On behalf of the Australian Government—and I hope on behalf of the Opposition—I would like to thank the Good Morning America program for providing that boost to Australia's tourism industry.

Honourable members might also be interested to learn that American viewers have been not only told about our unique environment and our wildlife but also taught a few lessons about things such as Australia's universal health insurance system and the way that we have managed to contain health costs. The other night I wrote down one figure from the program, and that was that the doctor's fee for delivering a baby in the United States is almost $2,000, whereas the doctor's fee in Australia is only $400. Of course, the big difference is that a Medicare patient in Australia does not have to pay a cent.

Finally, my only reservation about the success of the Good Morning America program is that I am a little concerned that I might have an approach from the honourable member for Cook, who represents Sylvania Waters in this House. I am concerned that he might demand that the ATC and Qantas should start taking out advertisements during the British screening of Sylvania Waters. I am not sure that that would be a good thing. If any honourable members opposite have any doubts about Noeline's judgment, certainly as a small business woman, I simply remind them that the week before the election she decided that she was voting Labor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am relieved about the doctor's fee for delivering babies. My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Yesterday he informed this House that he stepped in to halt the licence process for MDS pay TV on the ground that it could not provide sufficient coverage of the pay TV market across Australia compared with the satellite method. Is it not the case that the primary footprint of the satellite, whose qualities he supported yesterday, provides quality coverage for some, but not all, capital cities? Is it not a fact that it would not cover 75 per cent of Australia's landmass and that there is no obligation on the satellite licensees to provide national coverage and in fact take up the national beam?

—Covering the landmass is not the key point: it is covering the population. The key point is that it covers all but 10 per cent of the Australian population. It is the population we are interested in, not the sandhills in the Simpson Desert. I obviously struck pay dirt yesterday with that little answer, because here they are, the toffs, as usual, saying, `Well, look, if we have got it in Bellevue Hill and Vaucluse, or if we have got it in the lower North Shore and Toorak, who cares about Forbes, Junee, Wagga, Canowindra or rural Queensland? Who cares about the great provincial cities of Australia? Provided that the safe Liberal seats have an MDS licence and pay TV options for their constituents, who cares?'. This is in fact the reality of the argument which is being put.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the National Party opened up his question by saying that I stepped in. Let me just make this clear to him: Senator Collins stepped in. I asked for a paper from the department and, independently of me, Senator Collins made a decision about this—and, in my view, a correct one. He said that MDS will be available as a technology, but will not be available as a broadcasting system, ahead of standards being set by and for the satellite; that is, for the digital compression on the satellite. In other words, he is saying it is still available as a technology but it cannot be a primary delivery system first. There is no point trying to smother the Opposition's position on this question. It was always the case that up to about 10 per cent of the population was outside the primary coverage area of the Optus high-performance beam.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could be picked up by MDS.

—I said that yesterday. I made that clear to honourable members yesterday. MDS as an infill system at the end of the beam of the satellite is not MDS as a primary system. So let us not have a silly word game here. The fact is that the Leader of the National Party, in his ignorance, is plodding around arguing for MDS when in fact all of his country constituents would be cut dead by the technology. They would get nothing. The only way they can get MDS out there is basically from the satellite as part of an infill system, unless some operator wants to set up an MDS system in country towns. And who would want to do that at this stage?

PARA.TAB: That is why none of the licences which have currently been aggregated would have met that rural need. The only thing is to adopt a national system. The point I made in the previous answer was this: the prospects are that Australia will adopt a first-class world leading system, with digital compression being applied to a continental country and with cable. Telecom—if it were to succeed in any of this, or have its network involved with any of this—was one of the very few telephone companies in the world to fibre up parts of cities with fibre-optics to the street corners. Most telephone companies have not done that. Most television quality in the United States runs from cable companies, not telephone companies. Our telephone company made a decision that most telephone companies did not make.

The Opposition, as a bunch of obscurantists, is saying that it will not let them use it. It wants to have some line of sight system that has got limited application. Basically, the Opposition should bone up on the system. If it is critical of it, that is fine. It should listen to what the arguments are. But, for God's sake, do not do it without knowing about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the map showing the coverage area, which shows that 75 per cent of Australia is not covered. I have given a copy to the Leader of the House.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is the Attorney-General aware of community concerns about violent video games and, if so, what action is the Commonwealth taking to deal with violence in films, videos and computer games?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lavarch The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are widespread concerns in the community which have come to light most recently in relation to a number of new generation video games. I have seen newspaper reports about it and, probably like most honourable members, I have received some representations from constituents. For instance, the principal of the Esk state primary school in my electorate drew my attention to a game called Night Trap which involves five actresses being drilled through the neck and mutilated by sharp electric clamps. The principal makes the point that:

ANSWER.PARA: In a society where we are concerned about violence against women I am concerned about such a `game' being available to children. I am very concerned about the message this `game' would send to the users (particularly boys) of this game.

There are some moves already afoot on this matter. I am pleased to say that Sega, which is the company involved in that particular game, has, of its own accord and in response to community concern, indicated that the game will not be released. However, that is only one game from one company.

PARA.TAB: Currently, the Office of Film and Literature Classification does not classify video games at all. The current system that applies in relation to films and videos, with which honourable members would be familiar, would not easily lend itself to video games. These matters were considered by the Australian Law Reform Commission recently in its report on censorship administration. The commission recommended that censorship legislation should be altered to recognise computer games. Some games may be subject to banning if they offend community standards and others should be subject to restriction or carry an appropriate warning. In June these recommendations will be considered by a meeting of State and Commonwealth censorship Ministers, and I am hopeful that the Commonwealth and the States will combine on this matter to devise a regime fleshing out the proposals recommended by the Law Reform Commission.

I should just add one final point, as the honourable member also raised film classification. Honourable members will recall legislation which this House has passed creating a new distinction in the old M category, that is, the problem that used to be between a Crocodile Dundee movie being an M and Silence of the Lambs also being an M. The new categories of M and MA will prohibit some movies being seen by children under the age of 15.

While the Commonwealth, South Australia and the Northern Territory have passed legislation along these lines, and Queensland, New South Wales and Tasmania have currently similar legislation before them, the State of Victoria has not as yet passed any legislation. In fairness, though, it has been submitted for debate and will be passed next session. Unfortunately, at this stage Western Australia is still considering its position.

The Prime Minister is writing to all State Premiers on these issues, I understand this week, and he will be requesting them to move as quickly as possible with their legislation regarding the new M and MA classifications.
