No matter how passionately people might think they feel about this issue, the fact is there is not that much information about it. There have not been very clear models of republican structures ever proposed in Australia. So the thinking will not just go on on the Opposition's side of politics; it will also go on on the Labor side of politics.

PARA.TAB: As far as the Government is concerned, the instinct of the Leader of the Opposition on this—to have his party consider the issue—is correct. For the Government's part, we say to the Liberal Party, `We want you to be in this with us; that is, we want you to be part of the debate'. We do not seek to have a proprietorial grip on this issue. This is an issue which will be dealt with by the country. We will reach a time—if not now, one wonders how many years in the future—when we will not have the monarch of another country as our head of state. That seems to me to be a pretty obvious issue. It is now on the public agenda and it will be subject to debate.

I make this clear: we will give the Liberal Party every chance to come to a position on this. The honourable member for Bennelong might be groaning away over there, but the fact is that we will give him the room to think about it carefully without trying to put him into some sort of pincer on the issue. I am quite happy to make the offer and to stand by it. I say to the Leader of the Opposition: there is no super urgency on his part to come to perfunctory or rapid decisions.

If those opposite think that because we have made that offer we will give them a free ride on all the other issues, think again, we will not. But, on this issue, those people who sat down a century ago in the 1890s to think about a federal structure for Australia did so in the face of the national imperatives, looking at the things they thought and felt passionately about, and they came together in a spirit of achievement to get something done. This is something that needs to be done. As we have said, we think it desirable that it be done by the centenary of our Federation, and that is quite a number of years away.

I think that this paper published today will help focus some of the issues, but it will be the report of this committee that will help focus it. In a sense, that will be the start of the process, and the process will then go on so that we think about what process is then best, whether it be a constitutional convention, how we sit down with the States, how the parties are fully represented and how the matter is then progressed. So there is no need for indecent haste on this on the part of anybody. So I am only saying to those opposite that I think their Leader's instincts on this are dead right.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I am having trouble coping with the flattery. My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister whether he is aware of a statement made by the Queensland Premier, Mr Goss, in State Parliament last night, in which Mr Goss said:

QUESTION.PARA: We might as well abolish the Senate because it no longer represents the States.

Mr Goss has reaffirmed that statement in a news conference today. Does the Prime Minister agree with Mr Goss that the Senate should be abolished? Has Mr Goss let the cat out of the bag and exposed the wider Labor agenda behind the so-called minimalist position on a republic?

TALK.START.PARA: —I made clear that the Government would not be considering constitutional change. In fact, I was asked about it in our Caucus yesterday and I said that we would not be considering constitutional changes beyond this question of moving competently, with a proper structure, to a republic.
—The trouble is, people do not believe you.
—You don't, John. Your nostalgia is always touching, I always say. Good on you for it! Again, I do not think it ought to be allowed to hold the place back.

PARA.TAB: Could I say that Premier Goss lives in a State which has one chamber of parliament, one lower house chamber. It does not have an upper house. This has been a matter on which we have heard with pride from all major parties in Queensland. They have all boasted about it from time to time. The fact of the matter is, of course, that many of the States have attempted to remove their upper houses and we had that celebrated occasion in New South Wales when—dare I say it without being quoted again—Jack Lang appointed a whole stack of people to produce a majority to vote themselves out of office by voting away the Legislative Council. But when they got there, they decided they would stay there. We still have it today. So they are very durable, these upper houses; they are not easily removed.

Let me say—putting the mirth to one side—that I do not believe that the prerogatives of the representative chamber should be usurped by the unrepresentative chamber. But I can say categorically that I for my part and this party will not be making moves to remove the Senate. Honourable members will certainly not find in any of these papers any of that. That is not for me. Premier Goss is entitled to his view about upper houses and their role, but that is not the view of the Commonwealth Government. All States will have the opportunity to put their views on these constitutional questions in the proper way and in the proper forum. Again, I say to the Liberal Party: do not be basically dodging shadows. Those opposite have a good opportunity here to consider the issue and to make up their own minds about it, but at least consider—

TALK.START.PARA: —Big deal that is!

—There he is. Last Saturday I was reading a book on Churchill. I cannot remember who wrote it—that is right, Violet Bonham Carter—and I had Elgar's Enigma Variations running at the same time. I was really very excited about it and I thought, `I am sure if John Howard were here, my emotions would redeem me and I would be forgiven for my views'.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is the Minister aware of recent media reports of the criticism by academics concerning the national mathematics profile and, further, a claim in yesterday's Melbourne Herald-Sun of a marked decline in mathematics skills? Will the Minister inform the House on how the Government is addressing the matters raised?

—I thank the honourable member for his question and acknowledge his interest in matters educational, particularly the state of the beleaguered Victorian state education system. Unfortunately, there seems to be a degree of confusion in the minds of some academics about the relationship between the national collaborative curriculum work in mathematics on the one hand and the profiles used in the Victorian Certificate of Education on the other.

PARA.TAB: A further report in today's Australian seems to assume that the national curriculum statements and profiles in mathematics and the Victorian profiles are one and the same thing; in fact, this is not the case. The national statements and profiles were commissioned by Commonwealth, State and Territory education Ministers who established a national collaborative management structure to ensure that the statements and profiles reflect consensus between the education systems.

There also seems to be some confusion in some people's minds about the nature and purpose of the mathematics profiles. The profiles establish a common language so that educators across Australia can talk about mathematics in greater detail and cooperate in curriculum development. They also provide a broad framework for reporting on student achievement. On that latter point it is important to remember that the eight levels of achievement described in the profile are statements of expected outcomes from students. Educators in the community as a whole need to be better informed about the outcomes of schooling, and we are working with the States to achieve consensus on such reporting.

The maths profile describes desirable maths education for all students and sets a very high standard of informed numeracy. It needs to be remembered that, with more and more students staying on, the nature of our secondary schools has undergone a profound change. And I remind the House that school retention rates last year reached 77 per cent. That is up six per cent on the previous year and it is up from 34 per cent when the coalition was last in office. In such an environment we need to ensure that our schools provide valid educational outcomes for all students. The Government's agenda for schools and vocational education is aimed precisely at this goal.

The national curriculum work across eight areas of learning is a unique and ambitious effort by the school sector. It is a pity that the media has not focused on the benefits of this work for all students.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Communications. He will recall the comment by the Prime Minister about being cut dead by the technology. Could he explain to the House his policy and his Government's policy with respect to access to free to air television as a result of the change from VHF to UHF transmission and the suggestion that in some mountainous country viewers will be required to put in self-funded translators to receive pay television and no longer will be entitled to receive either ABC or commercial signals which they now receive by VHF signal transmission.

—I thank the right honourable member for New England for his question. I am not aware of the broad details which he seeks but I will get an answer for him. But there is a government policy in place, which is the correct way to do this. We are putting in place a spectrum management agency to manage that spectrum. There have been difficulties with the banding and moving from UHF to VHF and vice versa. So I will get the information for the right honourable member from the National Transmission Agency.
—Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the outlook for Australia's relations with Vietnam?

—Australia is becoming an increasingly important economic partner for Vietnam. I think many members of the House will have noticed that on 15 April this year BHP Petroleum signed a production-sharing agreement which paves the way for the $1.5 billion development of the Dai Hung oilfield in Vietnam. BHP's involvement places Australia at the front rank of investors in that country.

PARA.TAB: Bilateral merchandise trade has grown from less than $2 million in 1982 to $252 million in 1992—modest compared with some other countries, but quite a rapid rate of growth. Not only that: Vietnam is also emerging as a popular destination for Australian investment generally. In 1992, Australia was the sixth largest foreign investor in Vietnam, investing some $390 million in that country over 22 projects.

All of this points to a growing commercial and cultural relationship with Vietnam and, in order to consolidate this excellent progress in our bilateral relationship, I issued an invitation to Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet to visit Australia. I am pleased to say that he has accepted my invitation and will be coming to Australia for a visit between 26 and 30 May.

Prime Minister Kiet's visit will enable us to discuss ways in which we can build on the solid foundations we have already put in place, and it will be another opportunity for me just to emphasise the fact that Australia does see the Asia-Pacific as an area of opportunity where the prospects of closer integration are enhanced, and that as part of that we will take the opportunity of investing in Vietnam.

It is also worth saying that honourable members will be aware that we have a very large community of Australians who are of Vietnamese origin and whose relationship with the Vietnamese government has not always been an easy or harmonious one. I very much hope that those in the Vietnamese Australian community will look on Prime Minister Kiet's visit as a positive development, especially in view of the growing importance of our economic relationship, and that, as a first constructive step towards their eventual reconciliation with the Vietnamese Government, they will take the opportunity of some discussions during this visit.

I firmly believe that the community will become one of the main conduits of a mutually beneficial relationship between Australia and Vietnam. This is true because one of the things that our migration program has delivered in this country is a number of communities which are now finding that they can operate effectively and efficiently in the markets of the countries from which either they or their families came as migrants. We are seeing a growth in trade and business development as a result of their language capacities, understanding of cultures and general ability to penetrate these markets and do things with them. This would be as true of Vietnam with the Australian Vietnamese community as of any other community in Australia.

So, in preparing for the Prime Minister's visit, we will be consulting with community representatives to see whether there are other practical issues of significance to the community which we might take up with the Prime Minister. In that way we can use the visit to its fullest so that those things which are of importance to the Australian Vietnamese community can be traversed between the Prime Minister and the Government. Again, this is a step which will underline a better and closer relationship with Vietnam and consolidate that trade and investment relationship which has now been growing quite markedly over the last two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is it a fact that, according to the Australian Taxation Office's 1991-92 annual report, the net cost of its operations as a percentage of revenue collected has risen by 40 per cent over the last 10 years? What steps will the Government take this year to ensure that the Tax Office runs at the same level of efficiency as in 1981-82?

—This question raises a matter of which Australia is entitled to be quite proud, that is, that the Tax Office has over the course of the last few years established an enviable record in terms of its efficiency and the general way in which it goes about its business.

PARA.TAB: Of course, there will always be occasions when the Tax Office becomes a target for criticism, but rarely should we put up with the kind of abuse that the Tax Office has had to contend with from a variety of Liberal senators, and one in particular who attempted to continue her campaign last night in the Senate.

It seems to me that, under the leadership of Mr Boucher and with the current commissioner, Mr Carmody, then as his deputy, the Australian Taxation Office undertook a major program of modernisation to improve its operation and what it likes to call its service to the Australian community.

That is a continuing process. It is a process which is being kept under close scrutiny, through some intelligent inquiry amongst parliamentarians—we have had a joint committee working on that over the course of the last parliament—and continuing scrutiny amongst some quite sensibly motivated senators as well. This is not something that is going on without notice. It is also being kept under close scrutiny by the Government itself through the Department of Finance, ensuring that the targets which the Tax Office has set for itself will be met.

The Tax Office sees this as a continuing role of improvement but it is an ambition which it will be able to fulfil if it is without the kind of abuse, sometimes scurrilous abuse, which has come forth from some members of the Opposition. If there are any particular matters which the honourable member wishes us to pursue, he might direct those specific inquiries either to me or to the Assistant Treasurer, who has responsibility for the administration of the Tax Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. What action is the Government taking to protect the environment of the Shoalwater Bay training area and what is the current status of the Shoalwater Bay inquiry?

—I thank the honourable member for Capricornia for her interest in this area. It is a very important and significant part of her electorate and indeed of the Queensland coastline. That is the reason that the Government announced, at the end of last year, that we would have a major inquiry looking at both the ecological values of the area and the economic significance of the area.
—And the military training area.

—Of course. It has been suggested that there is considerable economic benefit to be gained from that area, and as well there are the large undisturbed areas which we believe are highly significant and have unique ecological values. We decided to conduct a full and open assessment of the environmental, economic and defence values and the whole future potential of that Shoalwater Bay training area.

PARA.TAB: The assessment will be conducted as an inquiry under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, and the Government has decided to appoint three commissioners. The chairman of the inquiry will be Mr John Woodward, who was until recently the chairman of commissions of inquiry for environment and planning in New South Wales. In his previous positions he has conducted a number of inquiries into issues that involve that sort of balance between natural resources and mining.

The two other commissioners are Miss Jennifer Hughey and Dr Ted Christie. Miss Hughey is currently our conciliator in Queensland. She is a qualified solicitor. Dr Christie is associate professor of applied ecology at Griffith University in Queensland, and is a qualified barrister. The inquiry will provide advice to assist decisions on future land use and management of the lands and waters in that area under the whole principle of ecologically sustainable development.

The secretariat of the inquiry will be based in Brisbane and has very wide terms of reference. They include natural, cultural, Aboriginal heritage, scientific assessment of the area, mining and mineral processing, fishing, tourism and how related activities could affect the Great Barrier Reef, and, very importantly, the military and defence requirements for the area.The inquiry will be of 12 months duration and it will report at the end of May next year.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The damage that will be done to low and middle income earners by the Government's proposed new tax increases.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had today the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) back on to his favourite smokescreen topic, the republic. It reminds me of a reference I read earlier today in a newspaper which said that talk of a republic—the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) will be interested to hear this—is a bit like the crew of his favourite ship, the Titanic, debating as they approach the iceberg whether the ship should have a change of name. It is not a very productive activity given the problems we face at the moment.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that that statement is very appropriate given the enormous problems this country now has as a result of Labor's spending spree at the last federal election. We are noticing, day in and day out, just here and there, little leaks emerging about not only the depth of concern in the bureaucracy over this problem but also some of the alternative taxes that the Labor Party is planning in government to impose on Australians. As far as concern in the bureaucracy is concerned, there was a very significant article on the front page of yesterday's Australian Financial Review. That article reported that Ministers have received, in particular the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins)—presumably not his sidekick, the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) or whatever he is called—a Treasury paper advising that the Government's objective of providing income tax cuts and achieving a Budget deficit of one per cent of GDP by 1996-97, to quote the paper, is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . unattainable unless it heavily prunes spending or increases taxes.

Of course, what the Government is about is not heavily pruning spending. We know that from the way it is progressively leaking plans to increase taxes and building expectations about new and damaging taxes on the Australian community. It is not interested in reducing spending; it is interested in collecting taxes. It is no wonder that the bureaucracy, the financial markets and the business community are worried about the size of the Budget deficit in this country, because if the Government's target is to be achieved, that is, to reduce the deficit to one per cent of GDP by 1996-97, depending somewhat on what assumptions are made about growth and the rate of inflation between now and then, it will have to take something like $7.4 billion off spending or increase taxes by that amount.

PARA.TAB: To increase taxes by $7.4 billion would be the equivalent of increasing the wholesale sales tax—Labor's consumption tax—by 61.8 per cent. That is basically the proposition that Australians in the next few years under this Government will be confronted with. It is interesting that we heard nothing about that during the election campaign. During the election campaign we had statement after statement—depending on the vagaries of the opinion polls—about new promises. We had a government that went around the country arguing that it did not matter how much these promises cost because they would always be financed through growth in the economy. Not only did the Government realise at the time that that was untrue but also the campaign mounted by the Labor Party at the election on this issue alone was one of the most fraudulent and dishonest election campaigns ever conducted in this country. Those people on the other side were re-elected on a fraud, and I will prove it to them with their own words.
Mr Gear interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer says, `We won it though, anyway'. He concedes that it was a fraud, and he is very happy to accept that.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I would like to point out that I did not say the words attributed to me.
—There is no point of order.

—Let us look at what the Prime Minister and his colleague said during the election campaign. On 5 March 1993—by the way, the tenth anniversary of the election of the Hawke-Keating Government—when speaking about the Budget deficit, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our stuff will whirr back towards balance, no trouble at all . . . You will find that that structural thing just disappears by about 1994-95.

PARA.TAB: What will happen is, providing that the underlying structure of the outlays has not significantly changed—and they won't have—the cyclical return of revenue will see the Budget balanced—the Budget start shifting back towards balance.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an absolute fraud. The Government offered the income tax cuts to try to match the tax cuts in the Fightback plan—$8.6 billion in tax cuts—but it had no method of funding them. It went around pretending that they could be funded through increases in revenue resulting from higher rates of growth.

PARA.TAB: We now know from Treasury documents and from advice the other side of the House has been getting that that is impossible. It cannot be done. It is a fraud. It is a complete fraud—and the Government was re-elected on the basis of a fraud in the 1993 election. On 9 March on the PM program on the ABC, the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have a deficit reduction plan.
Of course the Government had a deficit reduction plan—a plan to increase taxes after the election and not tell anybody about the regressive and damaging taxes it had in mind. He said:
. . . as the economy grows, the Budget will repair itself. That is an entirely responsible thing for us to do. It's something which, I might say, the Treasury is entirely happy with.

Wrong! The Treasury was not entirely happy with it. Even the Assistant Treasurer knows it is a barefaced lie to say that the Treasury was entirely happy with the spending plans of the Government. The point has been made in Treasury documents and Treasury submissions over and over again.

PARA.TAB: We had a government re-elected on a fraud. It promised no new taxes, and now it is softening up the press gallery and the electorate for new taxes. It promised that its policies could be funded by growth, knowing damn well all along that its policies could not be funded by economic growth. During the election campaign, we said that Labor's figures did not add up and could not add up. We were right and the Australian public was simply presented with a fraudulent policy by those on the other side.

What new taxes are Australians going to be confronted with? We have already spoken in this place about the way in which the Government is proposing not only to broaden the base of the wholesale sales tax—I understand that it is now considering applying the wholesale sales tax to airline tickets and restaurants—but also to increase the average rate of the wholesale sales tax.

Yesterday, the President of the ACTU, Martin Ferguson—a de facto member of the Government—said that the Government wanted to reduce the deficit and that, frankly, the Government could not continue to say that it was going to reduce taxes. In other words, the Government is going to increase taxes. He went on to explain how:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . one way or another, we are going to have to look at the issue of taxes over the next couple of years.
So the Government is going to increase taxes, and in the end it will increase the overall burden of taxes over the next couple of years.

PARA.TAB: The ACTU is talking about a wealth tax. A wealth tax is, of course, part of the old game; the politics of envy. But the real point about the wealth tax is that it will raise virtually no money at all. A wealth tax will not solve the Government's problems. It is not the multimillionaires of Australia, some of the Prime Minister's mates—such as Warren Anderson on whose big property out at Tipperary the Prime Minister has enjoyed pig shooting over the years—who will end up contributing to the solution to the Budget deficit problem; it will be ordinary people. The wealth tax will raise nearly nothing.

Look at the Assistant Treasurer. About the only time people notice him is during an election campaign, other than when he pulls the occasional bizarre publicity stunt, which, by the way, the Treasurer and other Ministers have told him to abandon. But during the election campaign it was the Assistant Treasurer who ran around saying, `Hey, I've got a great idea. Let's increase the Medicare levy'. What did he want to increase it to? He wanted to increase it to 2 1/2 per cent. He is now the Assistant Treasurer, so that gives honourable members a pretty clear indication of what his little mate over there happens to have in mind.

The Government also has in mind some of our old friends that we saw before the last election, such as the interest withholding tax. What is an interest withholding tax? Do honourable members remember that in last year's Budget? If honourable members read through last year's Budget papers, they would be reminded—as I was when I took the trouble to have a look at them this morning—that the Government said, `Well, if we do have some problems with a Budget deficit, we might consider introducing an interest withholding tax'. When we talked about that a bit before the election, the Government said, `Oh no, we won't do that. We have decided we won't'.

What is an interest withholding tax? It is a tax on the interest that people such as pensioners get from their very small savings. It is a tax on that interest, taken away at source by the bank. So people will be slugged. So the Government, having put up the Medicare levy to 2 1/2 per cent, having introduced its little tax of envy—the wealth tax—on some of its mates, will then introduce a new tax on pensioners, on those least able to look after themselves, through its interest withholding tax proposal. It ran away from it because of the election, because of the fraudulent campaign it was putting together. Now that the election is out of the way, it is back into it.

What about the States? This Government's rhetoric is that it has reduced the overall level of Commonwealth expenditure as a proportion of GDP during its time in office. But we should take into consideration that the amount of Commonwealth grants to the States has fallen in the life of this Government over the last decade from 9.6 per cent of GDP to 7.2 per cent of GDP.

What about the Commonwealth's Budget for its own purposes? What about the Commonwealth's own purpose outlays? They have actually substantially increased during the life of the Hawke-Keating Government. The pressure has been put on the States. The easy way to make the cuts is to cut funding to the States and then say to them, `Oh, you go and raise some of your taxes. They are very narrowly based taxes. They are actually very regressive taxes. You go and raise your own taxes'. What is the advantage of that? This is what the Government will do now. It will do that to four Liberal State governments so that it can go around saying, `Oh, look, Liberal State governments have put up all the charges. The States will have to put up their charges while we at the Commonwealth level make cuts to try to fund our fraudulent election bribes'. The fact is that those taxes that the States will have to put up will be Keating taxes. The coalition State governments will tag those taxes as the Keating Government's.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not be GSTs.

—The Assistant Treasurer says they will not be GSTs. They will be a lot more regressive than the GST proposal, because the Government gives no income tax cuts to those earning less than $20,700 a year—none. It gives tax cuts to the rich but not to those who earn less than $20,700 a year. We would have had a GST, but we would have given those people tax cuts. The Government does not have the decency to do that because it so crassly and grossly takes those people for granted. I think that, increasingly, Australians will hold that attitude in contempt.

PARA.TAB: The Government should be cutting spending generally, including on Commonwealth owned purpose outlays. That is where it should be making the cuts, so that we can bring interest rates down and stimulate investment in this country. It should not go on some sort of wild taxing spree which will penalise low income earning Australians with no compensation and will simply make our businesses, already struggling to be competitive, more uncompetitive than they already are. That is the Government's agenda, which we should never forget. Over the next three years we will tag Labor with this—but probably not the Assistant Treasurer; we will not bother too much about him—all the way to the polling booth. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was lovely to sit here and listen to the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) because it has finally dawned on the Opposition that it has lost the election. Honourable members opposite are coming in here whingeing about what might have been. In his speech the honourable member for Mayo spoke about the Titanic, and I suppose he was referring to the comments of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) last Sunday. I can tell the honourable member that whenever I hear about the Titanic I think of Fightback and the GST and how it sank on 13 March 1993. The thing that amazes us on the government side is that the captain survived and is back sitting in his normal seat. That suits us fine. We just hope they give him another shot in 1996.

PARA.TAB: The other night I listened to the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) speaking in very much the same vein as the honourable member for Mayo: whingeing about what might have been, had the Opposition won the election and brought in the goods and services tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —What should have been.

—There is a theme here about what should have been and what could have been, but what never will be because the Opposition came second. It did not win. The honourable member for Mayo spoke about my involvement in the campaign. I thought that I made a positive contribution to the campaign because out on the doorsteps of my electorate people said, `I don't understand this tax and I'm not going to vote for it'. I thought that said it all. I well remember the day in John Laws's studio when the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was asked some very simple questions on the GST and could not answer them.
—You answer them.

—No, it is the Opposition that is trying to sell it. The honourable member for Forrest suggests that I answer those questions. I am not proposing the GST; I was opposing it. The proponent of the GST could not even explain it himself.

PARA.TAB: The matter of public importance concerns the damage that could purportedly be done to low and middle income earners. They did not get much of a mention from the honourable member for Mayo. There was certainly a lot of whingeing about losing the election, how the Government is supposed to be going to bring out all these secret taxes, and how the Opposition will hound us all the way to the next election. Honourable members opposite should wait for the Budget and see how the Government addresses the problems that they were talking about.

The simple fact is that the Government has not proposed any new taxes. It is only the high taxing Liberal Party that is talking about new taxes. It was going to introduce the goods and services tax which would have raised far more revenue than anything this Government has ever proposed. Wherever a goods and services tax has been introduced—and people who have travelled through Europe know this—it is only the tip of the iceberg. Once it is in, it invariably goes up. It is to the Opposition's credit that at least it was open about getting it in. The Opposition was terribly closed about what might happen in the future, but it does raise a lot of taxes.

The honourable member for Mayo talked about people on incomes below $20,700. The simple fact is that this Government has already delivered tax cuts to those people. When we took government the lowest marginal tax rate was 30 per cent. We have cut that to 20 per cent. The top tax rate was 60c and it is now down to 47c. Taxes have been lowered. When we talk about tax reform in this country there has been only one tax reformer—this Government.

I well remember the debates in this House when we removed the tax-free lunch. The removal of the tax-free lunch was anathema to the Liberal Party. We heard from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton)—at the time, I think he occupied the same job as the honourable member for Mayo, but I am not sure—who led the charge against the terrible practice of taking away tax deductibility for business lunches. We heard dire predictions about the impact that that would have on the Australian economy, but not about the fact that taxpayers who never took a tax-free lunch were subsidising those who did. That was just the start of the tax debate here in Canberra.

We move from there to the capital gains tax. Once again, it was opposed by the Liberals both here and in the Senate. The fringe benefits tax is another example. It taxes non-cash income. Once again, it was opposed by the Liberals. We have seen the benefits of it now that it has been introduced. In actual fact, I think the industry has welcomed the fringe benefits tax system as it has removed a lot of the doubt. People know what the rules are. By and large, it has been accepted well by industry. I noticed in the last election campaign that even the Liberal Party had come to the view that it would leave that tax as it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five years behind.

—Well, a couple of years behind, as the Minister says. It is pretty hard to talk about Liberal taxes because it has been in opposition for so long. There are a couple of State Liberal governments that we can have a look at in terms of their taxing proposals. There is the State Liberal Government of Western Australia. PARA.TAB: The other thing about Western Australia of course is the disappearance from view of the Premier, Richard Court. In fact, not a lot of people around here would know that Richard Court—

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with the MPI?
—If the honourable member for Mayo is talking about relevance, not a lot of what he said—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am. PARA.TAB: I return now to the record of this Government and just point out that since 1983 the improvements in the tax system have increased the disposable income for pensioners, allowees and families on low incomes. Changes include increasing the tax free threshold, which the honourable member for Mayo was just bleating about; cuts in the lowest marginal tax rates; and increases in the indexation of rebates.

The real household disposable income per capita in December 1992 was 13 per cent higher than it was in March 1983. This is due to the tax reforms of this Government, along with social reforms. These include the family allowance supplement which is paid to people on low incomes. It, in fact, targets low income families via an incomes and assets test and is paid in addition to the family allowance. The family allowance supplement is linked to the CPI to make sure that it keeps pace with inflation. Between March 1983 and March 1993 the maximum family payment for a two-child family increased in real terms by nearly 90 per cent.

This Government has dramatically increased the number of child-care places. The number increased from 46,000 in March 1983 to 193,000 in June 1992. All of these measures, along with the tax changes that we have made, are aimed at benefiting low and middle income earners.

The MPI today purported to have a look at the proposed new tax increases. All I can say to the honourable member for Mayo is that he and the Liberals are the only people talking about them. We can understand that. The simple fact is that he is the only one talking about it. As the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) said the other day, the Government will address the problems that he outlined in the Budget this year. The Government stands by its commitments to redress the Budget situation by 1996-97.

TALK.START.PARA: —How will you?

—All I say to the honourable member for Mayo, who interjects, is that he should wait and see how we address the Budget this year. We will not be addressing it in the way those opposite would; that is, by bringing in a GST, which is totally unfair. We are just waiting for the debate on the other side; it will be a lulu, I can say that.

PARA.TAB: We also welcome the interventions of the last couple of days by the former shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who sits up there on the back bench. He is not there at the moment, but that is where he sits. I can see that the Leader of the Opposition, who has been re-elected to fill the place after losing the last election, is being looked over by the honourable member for Flinders. It will be fascinating to see how the debate finally works out.

As well as the measures I have outlined, low income earners have also benefited from other government policies. There has been assistance to carers, home and community care, the supported accommodation assistance program and the emergency relief program. If the Opposition needs more proof it can go to the ABS study on the effects of government benefits and taxes on household income. This study found that the Government's welfare system and tax system ensured that there is a redistribution of income in favour of low income earners.

The Liberal Party always talks about low taxes; it never talks about low spending, which is the sort of thing the honourable member for Mayo is talking about implicitly here today. We always have the idea from the Liberal Party that it is a low taxing party, and that taxes always have to be cut. The simple fact is that it is not a low taxing party. If we look at the way in which it was purporting to raise taxes at the last election, and all the utterances since—and even when it was in government—the simple fact is that taxes go up under the Liberal Party.

If we have a look at where Australia stands in relation to other countries, we see that we are not a high taxing country. Of the 24 members in the OECD, we are either the second or the third lowest taxing country. When we became a government we were the fifth lowest. So in the last eight or nine years we have actually gone down the league when we compare how much tax we pay as a percentage of GDP relative to other countries. We are quite proud of that record.

The simple fact is that we do not talk about high taxes or low taxes: we talk about appropriate taxes. We will raise the appropriate amount of taxation in a way which we believe is fair so that we can undertake the sorts of programs that this Government has introduced and maintained—things that are taken for granted in this country. When people in other countries find out about the social security systems and the income support systems in our country, they can only marvel at them. People who come here from other countries actually marvel at the sort of income support we give people who are unemployed, aged or sick. These are the sorts of programs and the sort of social net we have in place in Australia, supported by a decent tax system.

Out in the wide community, before the last election, I never heard any great chorus from anybody in my electorate asking to change the tax system. I never heard anything from anybody, apart from people in the Liberal Party, that we had to turn the taxation system on its head. It is obvious to us now, after 13 March 1993, that a majority of Australians agreed with us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in Western Australia, George.
—I said Australia. Western Australia is not Australia, thank goodness! The simple fact is that federal elections are fought right across Australia—
—You said in your electorate, didn't you?

—Let me go back to it. I said in my electorate there is no great change. I can only speak for my electorate. The simple fact is that when the Australian people, that is, all people in Australia, had the chance to have a look at the Opposition's proposals, they rejected them. The Government does not support this matter of public importance. As I have outlined, the Government does look after low and middle income earners, both by way of the taxation system which we have in place and the social security network which underpins it.

—Having listened to the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) in his lame defence of the Government's taxation policy, I am really driven to ask the obvious questions: if government taxation is so low, why are the pockets of Australians so empty? If taxes are so low, why are middle and low income earners suffering so grievously? If this Government is such a great manager of our economy, why is the Budget deficit $16 billion? If this Government is so compassionate, why are 700,000 children living in poverty and why are there record personal bankruptcies? If this Government has a tax policy that is so wonderful, why are Australian industries moving overseas? If this country is so successful, why are there one million unemployed and why is there so much misery everywhere?

PARA.TAB: The Assistant Treasurer quoted some of the tired old Labor statistics. They remind me very much of the old story which likened statistics to bikinis: what they reveal is interesting, but what they conceal is vital. The clear fact is that Labor governments are the great taxers. Labor governments have been the biggest taxing governments in our national history. Under 10 years of Labor, total tax has more than doubled, from $40 billion to almost $100 billion. Individual tax has almost doubled, from $23 billion to around $50 billion. Company tax has more than trebled; sales tax has trebled; customs duties have doubled; superannuation fund taxation has increased from $25 million to $1.2 billion; fuel excise has increased sevenfold, from less than $1 billion to over $7 billion.

But it is not just the increases in all of those taxes; Labor has made an art of inventing new taxes. There have been scores of them in the history of this Labor Government. When Labor came to office no-one had heard of a Medicare levy, a prescribed payments system, fringe benefits taxes, the capital gains tax—in fact, we now have the world's toughest capital gains tax—the superannuation levy, the training levy, the tertiary education tax. We have had new tax after new tax. This Government shows extraordinary dexterity in inventing new taxes to meet its bills. Labor has been the grim tax reaper.

That taxation net stretches into every transaction in the country. The Government taxes fruit juice and flavoured milk, bathrooms, toilets, soap, refrigerators, stoves, stationery, bedding, workers' tools—but not the Italian suit, of course—car parking spaces and everything else that it can find.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about antique clocks?

—I do not think there is a tax on antique clocks, but do not dare suggest it to the Government because someone might get the idea. The Government taxes every item in every store. Every time there is a transaction in the country, the Government has its hands in the pockets of Australians. Australian families meet the tax man every day they go to the supermarket, the shop, the restaurant, the fuel bowser. This Government has set up tax offices in every corner in every place as it grabs more and more revenue from the Australian people. If our taxation policy is going so well, why is it necessary for the Government to impose a whole new range of taxes? Whenever Labor sees something in good working order, its first reaction is: `Let's tax it'. Never dare in this country to succeed because your reward will be more taxes! Instead of encouraging initiative, Labor taxes it. Labor has been extraordinarily creative in inventing new taxes. If it were half as good at solving the country's problems as it is at inventing new taxes, we would not need the taxes that it creates.

PARA.TAB: At every election the Government comes to the Australian people with a promise of lower taxes, but it never delivers. Each government collects more taxes than the one before it. When the Government announces tax cuts, in reality it collects more tax. It uses words like `simplify', `reform' or `streamline' as smokescreens to actually raise the tax burden. The classic recent case was the amendments to the wholesale sales tax system, which we were told would relieve so many people from tax burdens and simplify the system. The reality is the Government has now admitted that it will collect hundreds of millions of dollars in extra tax as a result of what was supposed to be a tax cutting mechanism.

The Government seems to believe that families and businesses simply exist to provide extra tax revenue. The Government has not yet learned that it is not government that creates wealth—money is not made in the mint; it is produced in the businesses, farms and factories of our country. Instead of rewarding those people who have put in the extra effort, Labor resorts to taxing them. So Australian families, low and middle income earners, are particularly disadvantaged as they work that little bit harder to try to provide some benefits to their families.

Instead of higher taxes, the Government should be axing programs. But Labor is never likely to axe the grants to the trade union movement, the political lobby groups, the Medicare advertising programs or make cuts to the bureaucracy. It is easier to provide more taxes, which is what the Government is on about at the present time.

Indeed, in recent times the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) seems to have acknowledged that he is searching around for more taxes. He has to do that because he has to fund promised tax cuts, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) told us are cast in concrete. That promise should not be taken too seriously—remember, we were not going to have a capital gains tax either, but it did not take Labor long to forget that. So we have to have new taxes to help fund tax cuts.

The key thing to remember about these tax cuts, as the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) so ably pointed out, is that not one cent will go to people earning less than $20,700. That includes most women, most families, and all farmers in the current circumstances. Those people will get no tax cuts. Looking at Labor's proposed taxes, those low income earners will have to carry the biggest share of the burden. In his response today, the Assistant Treasurer again would not deny the Government's intention to introduce a range of new taxes. All he could say was, `Wait and see'. In the language of this Government that is the nearest one will ever get to a confirmation before the axe falls.

What sorts of taxes does the Government have in mind to impose in this new Budget? According to the Assistant Treasurer's response, no-one is talking about it apart from the Opposition. That is nonsense. Lately I have been making notes about some of the taxes that various government people are proposing. We should start with the Assistant Treasurer himself who said he had made a positive contribution during the election campaign. He started off in a very positive way by proposing a higher Medicare levy of 2.5 per cent. Yesterday the ACTU—hardly a friend of the opposition parties—also proposed new taxes. It wants a wealth tax. ALP leaders are on record year in, year out wanting to reintroduce death duties.

Last year the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories proposed a new energy tax to penalise those who live in the country and those who do business in faraway places. The office of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) has been a fertile source of new tax ideas. Last year it proposed a new tax on home owners to subsidise renters. What about his bobby-dazzler, the new tax on babies, that he had to quickly withdraw after his office floated that idea?

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy is currently advocating a tax on fishing. Last year the Government's Resource Assessment Commission proposed fencing off all the beaches and taxing anybody who visited the beach. Last year, the environment department floated the idea of a super tax on food and clothing to help pay for the environmental damage which it claimed was caused by farmers.

What about the Treasurer himself? There are no limits to his imagination: he wants to extend the prescribed payment system to tourism, taxis, doctors, pharmacies, farmers and all interest earnings. The Prime Minister has been full of imaginative ideas over the years. After all, it should be remembered that he once said it was impossible to have a fair tax system without a GST. So now we hear proposals to extend the WST system so that it covers tourism, accommodation and a whole range of other measures. Yesterday the former Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), laid down another suggestion: an extra tax to help the unemployed. That sounds rather like the Australian Democrats' ludicrous idea during the election campaign for a special tax on jobs.

Those are some of the goodies the Government has in mind, on top of the increased charges, the cost recovery programs, the efficiency dividends and all the rest that will increase the burden on low income earners and Australian families. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is only one party of taxation reform in this Parliament and that is the Australian Labor Party. There is only one party that stands for a fair taxation system and that is the Labor Party. The Liberal and National parties were in power for three decades and they let the system fall down: it was discredited and corrupted. People could drive a BMW or Mercedes Benz right through their tax system and it got to the stage where only ordinary wage and salary earners in this community paid tax. For the rest of the people it became optional.

PARA.TAB: When the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) were Ministers in this House, they presided over the rorting of the tax system for years and did nothing about it. It was left to the Labor Party to come into government and fix up the taxation system; it was left to the Labor Party to inject a degree of fairness into the system; it was left to the Labor Party to bring a capital gains tax into the system; and it was left to the Labor Party to repair the taxation system in this country.

One of the reasons the conservatives were thrown out in 1983 was that the only people paying tax were ordinary wage and salary earners; for the rest of the people in the community it had become optional. That is why the conservatives were thrown out and why they are so discredited when we look at what they have said here today. The Liberal and National parties went to the last election proposing a new 15 per cent goods and services tax on every item, on all goods and on every service in the community. The Opposition wants to go back to the bad old days of the 1970s, the days of the bottom of the harbour schemes; to the system where the ordinary wage and salary earner paid all of the tax in this country and where the people it represents—the well-to-do and the rich—paid nothing.

That was what the GST was all about. What these people on the other side of the House hark back to are the days of Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher. What the Opposition wants for this country is a flat tax system where, irrespective of how much income a person earns or of a person's circumstances, everyone pays the same amount of tax. That is the sort of tax system that the Opposition stands for—a flat tax system—and that is why it went to the last election with a 15 per cent GST.

For the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) to come into this House today and suggest that those on the other side of the House stand for a fair taxation system is simply laughable. This is the same man, along with the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), who had to be told by a market research company at the end of last year that a GST on food was unfair. This is the same man—a spokesman for the Liberal Party in the last election—who could not go out into the community and find out that a GST was unfair; he had to ring up Andrew Robb and say, `What does the market research company say? They think a GST on food is a bit unfair. We better drop it'.

What sort of credibility do the Opposition parties have in this House when talking about tax? None at all, because in their heart of hearts they still stand for flat taxation. They still stand for a 15 per cent tax on all goods and services including food. They cannot come into this House and credibly talk about tax and Budgets when they now have at least a $22 billion hole in whatever program they want to put before the people of this country.

The Opposition does not have any revenue raising measures any more; that is good to hear. I am pleased it has admitted it has no revenue raising measures because that means it has no policies. If the Opposition cannot raise the money, it cannot implement any programs. The Opposition parties have no credibility on tax or across the whole issue of government programs and the raising of money.But some people in the Opposition do have some credibility. I noticed in the press this week that the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) said that he thought that the GST had been too high; that 15 per cent was not an appropriate rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was around his neck.

—That is right. He said that they should have looked at an eight per cent rate. Whilst that is a commendable piece of honesty from the honourable member for Flinders, it still indicates the deep attachment of those sitting on that side of the House to flat taxation. Whether it is eight per cent, 10 per cent or 15 per cent they still believe in the principle that we pay the same amount of tax irrespective of how much we earn. That is why they brought forward the GST. What Labor had done in the 1980s in this country was bring in a fair system of taxation, where we paid tax according to how much we earned and that hurt the Liberal and National parties. It is one of the reasons why we continue to be in government in this country. Australians have made a lifestyle choice. They want to live in a society which is fair, which has the capacity to deliver social programs so that ordinary people in this country can achieve, irrespective of the background they come from. But honourable members opposite sit there representing privilege and they have not moved away from that.

PARA.TAB: They still are attached to a flat rate of taxation, still attached to a GST, which is why they so vehemently opposed the measures that we brought in to fix up the taxation system that they corrupted in the 1970s and 1980s, schemes that the honourable member for Bennelong let go through, like the bottom of the harbour and so on. That went on right through the 1970s and the 1980s. Let us just talk about some of the reforms that fixed up the taxation system, that they could not handle—the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax. All of those have been essential measures to introduce a degree of equity and fairness into the finances of this country. But equity and fairness are not words that honourable members opposite understand. They are only words that Andrew Robb can tell them about over the phone after he has spoken to the market research company. After they dropped the GST on food, they did not turn around and say, `We will not have it on water'. No, it is fair to have a GST on water. It is fair to have a GST on clothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —You tax water now.

—Nonsense. The ignorance of the people on the other side of the House is simply appalling. It demonstrates why they will remain in opposition for a very long time. They cannot hope to govern this country unless they have a coherent framework of policies, which relate to the good of the ordinary person in the community. They have not got a tax policy, except a hidden belief in a GST. They have not got a commitment to any of the social policies that we have brought in for this country, which benefit low and middle income earners. They have not got a commitment to a health care system that gives ordinary people access to health care. They have not got a commitment to a social security safety net. They have not got a commitment to things like the family allowance and family income supplement. They have not got a commitment to increasing pensions, so that people who have retired get a decent standard of living. They have got none of those commitments. We have increased the real level of pensions in this country by 14 per cent since 1983.

PARA.TAB: If honourable members opposite think that they have some alternative proposals to finance this country, let us see them. There is no way in the world with their proposed taxation system that we can continue to maintain the retired population in this country in the way that we have done in the last 10 years. They have no social policies because the only policy they believe in is the policy that greed is good. For greed to be good, the Opposition needs a flat taxation system. That is why honourable members opposite are struggling, fumbling and bumbling around this House, trying to pretend that taxation is a problem for this Government.

Taxation is a problem for that side of the House. They have got to find something that is publicly credible and acceptable to replace the GST. At this stage, they simply have no credibility whatsoever. Sitting here listening to the debate I could not believe that they thought they had lost the election. This Government has a credible set of social programs, which are funded by a fair system of taxation. That is why we have been elected for the previous 10 years. That is why we were elected on 13 March and that is why we will continue to be elected in the years ahead.
