DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the Inaugural Meeting of the Asia-Pacific Parliamentary Forum

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask for leave of the House to present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the inaugural meeting of the Asia-Pacific parliamentary forum, held in Tokyo from 13 to 15 January 1993, and to make a short statement in connection with the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about the delegation. I thought my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) would be in the chamber. If he comes later he might add to my remarks.

PARA.TAB: The delegation, as the report will show, comprised the honourable member for Bradfield, me as the leader, and the President of the Senate. We were accompanied by the Clerk of the House of Representatives and Ann Stewart who was my senior adviser at the time. I would like to thank the delegation members and the officials for the support that they gave me as the leader of the delegation and for the job that they did for Australia at that conference.

The Asia-Pacific Parliamentary Forum has an interesting history—a history of participation for which Australia can take great pride. The proposal to set up this forum, which is a parliamentary body and which will generally follow the work of the APEC ministerial council and provide a parliamentary perspective to the work of APEC, was an idea of former Prime Minister Nakasone of Japan. His idea was that we should have a wide forum that works in the Asia-Pacific region to provide contact at parliamentary level.

It is interesting to note that when honourable members go to conferences in Europe they find that there is a plethora of parliamentary bodies that overlap each other in Europe, North America and South America. But in the Asia-Pacific region—which is the most dynamic part of the world, and the part of the world where Australia's future lies—although there is the fledgling ASEAN group APEC, there is nothing which brings together a wide range of politicians from the various parliaments in the region to talk about matters of interest to the region.

Australia got very strongly behind this proposal because we believed it would be an excellent vehicle for us to have an input at a parliamentary level in the region, and an excellent vehicle for those democracies and mature parliaments in the region to provide some impetus for the movement of democracy in our part of the world. The proposal had been around for a couple of years. Finally it took some form at a meeting that was held in Singapore in August 1991. At that meeting I asked the Australian delegation to propose Canberra as a forum for the next meeting of the organisation, which was held in Canberra in December 1991.

At the Singapore meeting 10 countries from the region participated, at the Canberra meeting 15 countries participated, and at the meeting in Tokyo in January this year 15 countries participated. I think we have seen with this organisation the very successful birth of a body for which we can take a lot of credit. If it had not been for the persistent pushing by the Australian delegation at both the two preliminary meetings and the final meeting, I think we might not have seen this body get off the ground. We circulated a number of papers both at the preliminary meetings and at the meeting in Tokyo, which I think very much added to the form that this body will take.

Australia was elected to the executive committee. The honourable member for Bradfield and I were both elected as members of that executive committee. We will have an ongoing interest in the way the Asia-Pacific Parliamentary Forum evolves. The work that was done and the logistical assistance that was provided by the office of former Prime Minister Nakasone showed the awesome logistical work that the Japanese parliamentary groups can provide when they set their minds to it. Nothing was spared to ensure, from that side of it, that the conference went well. From the point of view of the Australian Parliament, this organisation should be one of the most important bodies that we participate in. It is the parliamentary vehicle which will allow us a window into the region. It will show the other parliamentary groups in the region that Australia—not just at a governmental level but also at a parliamentary level—wants to stake a claim to this part of the world.

Over the last few years the Parliament in outgoing delegations has started to shift its focus from one that had almost entirely a European perspective to visiting countries in the region and, importantly, to becoming affiliated with parliamentary organisations in the region. Our participation in the ASEAN parliamentary group has been upgraded to the extent that Australian delegations now attend the ASEAN inter-parliamentary union meeting and are given observer status.

I think this new body can claim very widespread support in the region and Australia is there at the beginning as a fully fledged participating parliament and as a parliament that is seen as taking a very strong position in ensuring that this body gets off the ground. We are not riding on anyone else's coat-tails here: we are one of the initiators.

I thank the honourable member for Bradfield and Senator Sibraa for the support and the work they did on the delegation. I particularly thank the Clerk for the report that he has provided. I thank Ann Stewart, who was my senior adviser, for the work she did in all the toing-and-froing in the run up to both this meeting and the meeting in Canberra. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would also like to be associated with this report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the inaugural meeting of the Asia-Pacific Parliamentary Forum, which was held in Tokyo in January 1993. I would also like to commend the former Speaker, the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), for the substantial role that he played in the development of the concept, especially at the Canberra conference of last year and also at the inaugural meeting.

PARA.TAB: I would briefly like to go back to the genesis of this concept because I think it is almost a matter of amazement to us that in such a short time—a mere three years—we were able to get together a not inconsiderable number of representatives from parliaments of some 15 nations. As a result of the Tokyo conference we have also received applications from Russia, Mongolia and Peru, as well as Taiwan. The first three countries have been accepted as members.

The APPF is the first organisation of this nature which, in a Pacific context, has on its eastern rim now all the nations of ASEAN, with the exception of Malaysia, all the nations of north Asia, all the nations of North America, and clearly there is a growing interest on the Pacific rim of South America. That is demonstrated by the fact that Mexico first attended the conference in Canberra. Peru has now applied to join and we would anticipate that probably Chile and some other states will join in due course.

The fact that this has been achieved in less than three years demonstrates more than conclusively that we struck while the iron was hot. Although there was a clear perception in the Asia-Pacific region that the time had come for the development of a truly Asia-Pacific parliamentary forum, it was not the universally accepted position. For example, I have detected a tendency for people in IPU circles to ask, `What is wrong with us? Why can't we represent the parliaments of the world?'. Part of the answer rests with the fact that its conferences attract over 900 delegates. That speaks for itself. The IPU has reached a size where it is very difficult for Australians to feel that we are in a regional structure in which we have a role to play.

It is interesting to note that in April 1990 the then Secretary-General of the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party was in Australia. The delegation included Mr Tatsuo Ozawa. He outlined to the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, a proposal for a Pacific parliamentary league for educational, cultural and economic cooperation. I think it is fair to say that the idea was not fully developed at that stage. Nevertheless, the Japanese were prepared to take the initiative, and the former Prime Minister Mr Yasuhiro Nakasone should be given full credit. I went to Tokyo in July 1991, quite independently of the Japanese initiative. At that stage I was not aware of it although I had spoken in this chamber of the need to take the initiative in this particular area. In my discussions in Tokyo with Mr Ozawa I found that we had a considerable degree of mutual understanding about the direction in which we wanted to go. I offered to prepare a background paper on the subject, which subsequently formed the basis for the first informal conference held in Singapore in August 1991 attended by delegates from nine parliaments..

One of the basic thrusts of my paper was that, while APEC—which was still a fledgling organisation—had been given substantial governmental support through most of the region, it was fair to say that the communities of the countries represented in APEC were totally unaware of its existence. It was a ministerial council with considerable public sector involvement. That was the beginning and end of it. It had no public persona at all. It certainly did not involve the representatives of the people. As the honourable member for Watson has rightly pointed out, when one looks at other assemblies such as the Council for Europe, one can see the obvious advantages in having a parliamentary organisation which links into the EEC, as with the annual conferences of the Council of Europe and the European Parliament.

While I do not suggest at this time that APEC will grow into some sort of EEC, one cannot discount the possibility of closer relations in the future. Even at this early stage there are very real advantages in having a parliamentary assembly which has essentially common, though not necessarily exclusive, membership with APEC and ASEAN on the one side and the APPF on the other. For example, representatives of APEC can come to the annual conferences; give reports on the progress of the region and policies for the economic, and other developments taking place in the region; and allow the parliamentarians representing the people of the region the opportunity to be involved in the overall process. We must establish a two-way communication which is clearly not there at the present time. That was the initiative that I put into the development of the APPF concept. It was also thought worth while to add other organisations, such as PBEC, the South Pacific Forum and other organisations active in the region.

The Canberra informal meeting in December 1991 saw these matters developed further, leading to the Canberra declaration. Subsequently, last January, we had the first full meeting in Tokyo with representatives from some 15 nations. We have gone from strength to strength.

I want to commend the honourable member for Watson for the role he has played in establishing the forum. There can be satisfaction for both of us because it is fairly rare that a member of parliament has the opportunity to say that he played a not inconsiderable role in the birth of a new organisation. I trust that future generations of Australian parliamentarians will add to the foundations we have endeavoured to lay. This is the first time that a regional organisation of this nature has been established linking Japan in the Northern Hemisphere with Australia in the south and most nations in between. The APPF is an additional indication of the growing relationship between our two countries and our mutual desire to see a community of interest in the Asia-Pacific region further developed.
Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Mr O'Keefe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to address the House on the Telecommunications Amendment Bill. This is a Bill to support and strengthen competition in the telecommunications area. It does so in an uncontroversial way and we see ourselves supporting it. However, the principle of competition which the Bill purports to support, and does make a contribution towards supporting, albeit in a relatively minor way, is a principle which is important for the House to consider in the context of telecommunications policy because it is a principle which the Government has had enormous difficulty in applying. I propose to make a few comments about the specific amendments in this Bill and then address the broader issue that the Bill raises—that of competition in telecommunications.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Bill is to provide the three mobile telephone carriers with land access powers which are presently not available to those carriers under the existing legislation. The present Act does not extend to the mobile telephone carriers—Telstra Corporation Ltd, Optus Mobile Pty Ltd and Vodaphone Pty Ltd—access to enter privately owned land in order to inspect, evaluate, install or construct telecommunications facilities for the provision of general communications services.

In addition to extending land access rights to the mobile carriers, the amendments to this Bill also impose the same obligations on the mobile carriers that currently apply to general carriers: for example, giving reasonable written notice to the owner of the land prior to entry. The amendments also include new provisions of a land access code which should further safeguard the interest of property owners through the regulation of powers given to both general and mobile carriers. In essence, the Bill places the mobile carriers on the same footing as the general carriers.

During his second reading speech, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr O'Keefe) described the Bill as ensuring greater competition in the industry. He said that competition was the focus of the Government's telecommunications reforms. Having witnessed, over the last two weeks, the extraordinary twisting and turning of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) in the Senate and of the Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall) in the House, and a similar performance from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the House yesterday and today, one could be forgiven for doubting whether competition is indeed the focus of the Government's telecommunications reforms. That statement by the Parliamentary Secretary constitutes yet another of the manifold contradictions that have been apparent to honourable members of this House whenever the Government speaks on telecommunications policy.

The Minister for Communications, who sits in this House—the junior Minister in this area—was reported in the press this morning as seeking to back away from the Government's commitment to competition in the telecommunications area. In the Australian Financial Review the Minister is reported as having:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . raised new doubts about the Federal Government's long-term plans for the telecommunications industry by suggesting that extra carriers may not be allowed after the industry is deregulated in 1997.
The reporter commented:
The Telecom-Optus duopoly has widely been expected to give way to open competition after 1997.

But the Minister for Communications is alert to the desire of the officials, the experts, in his department to encourage competition, and he for one will not go along with them. He presented a paper and made comments to the conference of the Australian Telecommunications Users Group which seemed to dissociate himself from the views of his department. He said:
Indeed, my department might find this a bit of a revelation.

Apparently, the department had not been informed by the Minister before he made those remarks of what he intended to say to the Australian Telecommunications Users Group conference. Indeed, the Minister is full of muscle with the new ideology of the Government, an ideology which expresses grave doubts about the significance of competition. He said that he believed a `deliberately forged and active partnership between government and business' was the best way to achieve industry development. Just to make sure that nobody confused him with Senator Collins, he said:
But ministers are entitled to have a different opinion to their departments.

Of course that is true, but it is also the responsibility of Ministers to make up their own minds and, if they do not agree with the advice offered to them by their departments, they are perfectly entitled—indeed they ought to; they have a responsibility—to reject that advice. That is not what Senator Collins did and is not what he says a Minister's role is.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Communications will not be drawn into that whirlpool of controversy that has been stirred up in the relationship between Senator Collins and the department. He will come out and say that he is a person with a mind of his own and that he differs in his view from that of his department. As we know, he also differs from the bulk of the telecommunications industry in his view as to the value of the licences that have been applied for and are currently under examination by the winning bidders in the process that Senator Collins initiated on 19 January. The Minister for Communications is a man of his own mind and his own determination. He differs from his department and the industry, and he is proud to say so. Unfortunately, the respect in which he differs is that he is much less convinced than the officers of his department of the value of competition in the telecommunications industry—the very matter with which this Bill is concerned.

It has been the Government's unwillingness throughout the whole development of policy in this area to commit itself clearly and within a defensible framework which everyone in the industry understands to a competitive structure for telecommunications in Australia. The Government has been through a series of the most extraordinary U-turns in enunciating policy in this area. No-one has been more responsible for this than the Prime Minister himself, the Government's self-appointed expert in telecommunications, a person who has contradicted himself again and again in this vital area and who is unquestionably personally responsible for the chaos that is now apparent in policy and in this area of the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —A cheap shot.

—The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who is at the table, says that this is a cheap shot. Let me just inform the Parliamentary Secretary of the statements that the Prime Minister has made on policy in this area. On 31 May last year, the Prime Minister—and people listening to this will consider this comment with great interest in view of the Prime Minister's answers in the House in the last two days—said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I've been quite uncomfortable about the fact that we're about to exclusively nominate satellite television as the only vehicle for Pay-Television between now and the year 1999, particularly when other technologies are available, like fibre optic cable and MDS . . .

In this famous interview with Laurie Oakes on the Sunday program, in which the Prime Minister gave us that little touch of excitement by throwing policy in several areas into complete confusion, he said:
We've kept the slate clean on pay but at the eleventh hour—
and he warned his colleagues—
I believe we look like choosing a very limited technology—
that is, satellite technology—
and denying to ourselves the right to at least choose alternative, and maybe superior, technologies.
In June, just shortly after that, he made it quite clear what he thought. He said that regulation:
would have closed off to Australia the higher technology of fibre optics and MDS—
multipoint distribution services or microwave television—
in favour of plastic dishes and satellites for a decade. I was never prepared as Prime Minister to shut that technology off.

Of course, the Prime Minister will now say, `Well, we have not shut it off. It will still be available after it has climbed over all the hurdles that we have now constructed in its place'. But let us look at what happened after the Prime Minister made those public remarks. The Government embarked on a very clear public process—and, as it appears from documents which have become available, a very well understood private process within the Government and within the Cabinet—to permit the development of alternative pay television technology besides satellite. It adopted a very clear policy to do this. A number of actions were taken, which I would like to remind the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Dr Theophanous) about, to implement this policy. There is no question whatever that the Government clearly contemplated that microwave pay TV could provide a viable system for broadcast pay TV technology.

PARA.TAB: Following the Prime Minister's edicts in May and June, Senator Collins—this poor Minister who now finds himself in such confusion as he tries to work out what on earth the Prime Minister wants in this area—was in no doubt about what was to happen. He lauded the Broadcasting Services Act—the Broadcasting Services Bill, as it then was—in his second reading speech for the support that it gave to technology neutrality. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The technology neutrality of the Bill is no more apparent than for Subscription Broadcasting Services. Licensees are encouraged to use whichever delivery mechanism suits their commercial needs.

That is a clear statement of the Government's support for neutrality. Did the Prime Minister jump on Senator Collins at this stage and demand that he retract this statement about technology neutrality when, as he now knows—and presumably he knew then since he is the universal expert in this area—this is an inferior technology? There was not a word about it. Instead, the Government went on. When the Broadcasting Services Act came up for amendment in November it was amended to allow subscribers to microwave pay television services to migrate from those services to satellite pay television services if they were not satisfied with microwave pay television services—MDS.

PARA.TAB: This amendment contemplated the fact that there would be MDS pay television services operating alongside the satellite transmitted services. Is the Prime Minister going to say to us that that will still be so some time down the track after all the hurdles put in place have been climbed? But that was not the intention then. What happened was that the Government established a tender process to issue licences to those involved, or who might become involved, in the industry to undertake microwave pay television services. This tender process began in December last year, and the tender documents make it absolutely 100 per cent crystal clear that these licences were to be issued for the purposes of subscription pay television.

So there is no ambiguity whatever. The evidence is absolutely overwhelming that the Government was heading down this track, and known to be heading down this track. If there is any final doubt, there was a note to the Minister from the secretary to the department, written prior to a meeting between the Minister and Mr Steve Cosser, and it said:

SPEECH.PARA: You are meeting with Steve Cosser in your office at 8 p.m. on Wednesday, 11 November, to discuss his business plans for participation in pay TV using microwave (MDS) technology.
Then the officials went on to say:

We have talked with Cosser on several occasions about his business plans. He is also known to have consulted on the regulatory aspects with other Cabinet Ministers and Caucus members, the Opposition and the ABA, and he is to meet with the Trade Practices Commission later this week. He has exposed to us some highly commercial-in-confidence aspects of his business plans to ensure that he is doing nothing that would breach the spirit or the letter of the Broadcasting Services Act, and has invested considerable capital in pursuing MDS options for subscription narrowcasting and subscription broadcasting services.

When this document was issued under FOI there were some blank spaces in it. But when the document was produced in court proceedings it did not include those blank spaces. It is very interesting to see what was left out of this document. I will read from the document as it was issued under FOI:

Availability and use of other technologies such as MDS and cable for pay TV from the outset have been transparent features of each pay TV model since Part 7 of the original Bill. It was a central plank of the Prime Minister's position in June.
A blank space then follows, but these were the words omitted:
. . .and was clearly reaffirmed in the latest model when it was put to Cabinet.

So the whole process was clearly reaffirmed, and it was known that microwave MDS TV was an alternative technology. The Government was operating on the basis that it was neutral as between the technologies. There was no doubt because, according to this note, Mr Cosser had been fully open with the department about his intentions in relation to these licences.So the Government knew exactly what was happening.

PARA.TAB: Then the process proceeded through January with the press reporting mounting pressure from applicants for satellite licences to halt the process for the allocation of microwave licences for fear that they might be too competitive with the satellite technology. At this time there were negotiations going on between Australian Consolidated Press and Mr Cosser's Australis Media for the purchase of Mr Cosser's existing microwave licences.

In this context of mounting debate and concern, it emerges that there was growing concern in the Prime Minister's office; something was twigging that office. One wonders what it was that was alerting it to some problem here. On 25 January Mr Don Russell called Mr Roger Beale, the acting secretary to the department, to indicate his concern about the stories circulating on the interest being expressed in MDS for the purpose of the national pay TV system. He said, `This does not seem consistent with Cabinet's decision on pay TV'. It is a very strange comment to have made, given the note that had been provided to Senator Collins by Mr Graham Evans. But there is no doubt that this mounting concern continued, and on 27 January negotiations between Australis Media and Australian Consolidated Press broke down, and Mr Cosser said he would not be selling his MDS licences, even though the contract was right there in front of him to sign.

What happened then? There were stories in today's media that the Prime Minister had further discussions with representatives of Australian Consolidated Press, but in Question Time the Prime Minister said that they had no foundation, so I will not repeat them. What we do know, and what is uncontested, is that the day after those negotiations broke down the Prime Minister phoned the acting secretary to the department and said that Cabinet had been notoriously misled in this matter. Today, in the House, he said that Senator Collins then stepped in and took independent action. The word `independent' would bear careful scrutiny here. Of course it is possible that Senator Collins was at more than arm's length, that he was completely divorced from all this manoeuvring that was going on around the Prime Minister's office and within the industry over the applications for the MDS licences.

The Prime Minister says Senator Collins took independent action. That is not quite how I read a minute, which was produced in court proceedings, written by Miss Christine Goode, who has since stepped aside. The minute said that it had been decided and approved by the Prime Minister that the tender process was to cease the following day. Of course, the Prime Minister's sudden concern in this area has thrown the process into complete chaos. It is interesting to note that it is in this very context that on 19 January, not nine days before the halt was called to the MDS tender process, Senator Collins approved the cover note but not the contents of the determination issuing the rules for tenders for the satellite pay TV licences. Senator Collins was obviously concerned about what was going on, because his defence is that he wanted to keep at arm's length; he was worried that the Government might be seen as acting in relation to pressures from certain groups in the industry, and he did not want that to happen.

His effort to dissociate himself led him to make a colossal blunder in relation to the guidelines for the satellite pay TV licences. He set up a process which he himself now says was flawed and which the Government is now seeking to change by rushing retrospective legislation through the Parliament.

What we have in January is the most extraordinary mess and chaos in this area that one could contemplate. The universal expert, the Prime Minister, the person responsible for this chaos, now tells us that he always knew that microwave pay TV technology was an inferior technology. Let me say that it was not at all clear on 28 January whether the problem with microwave technology was that it was too competitive or that it was no good. The Government's statements on this matter sometimes seem to suggest that the problem with MDS was that it was going to compete with satellite pay TV transmissions and that this could not be allowed. The Prime Minister is now trying to tell us that the reason he stepped in is that it was not any good. But if it was not any good and it was not capable of establishing a national service which could so readily be established by satellite pay TV, what was the problem?

The Prime Minister has completely failed to explain to the Parliament what was the basis of the Government's concern. He told the House yesterday that satellite transmitted pay television can provide a national service. But is this correct? The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) asked the Prime Minister in the House today whether it is not a fact that the primary footprint for the satellite covers only four of the capital cities. Is it not a fact that the satellite does not deliver any direct service via a 60-centimetre dish to any area other than the east coast to Adelaide and Perth, that there is in fact no service except via a nine-metre dish costing around $100,000 to most of regional Queensland, to New South Wales, to South Australia, to Western Australia and to Tasmania with no coverage at all in the Northern Territory? This is the Prime Minister's national service.

It was the persuasiveness of this claim that satellite television could offer a national service that apparently induced him to step in. Then he was asked, and he did not answer—and I think we have got to underline that point—a direct question from the Leader of the National Party concerning whether there is anything in the tender conditions that require the successful licensee to offer a national service. The answer to that question is that there is not. There is nothing in the tender conditions that require the licensee to offer a national service. So the Prime Minister has clearly misled the House on this point, and he has misrepresented once again what the situation is in relation to government telecommunications policy—
Dr Theophanous interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a fairly weak response, and not the response that is called for at this time from the Parliamentary Secretary at the table. It is clear that the Prime Minister has told the House that there will be a national service when that is not the situation especially when one looks at the technical features of the satellite television licences.

PARA.TAB: In all of this the department which has supported competition in this area, which this Bill before us today is supposed to support, has really copped it. The department has been criticised by its senior Minister in the Senate and, of course, a senior officer of the department has been forced to step aside. The junior Minister has taken courage and is now dissociating himself from the department. Those in the department would be really surprised at the revelations that he handed down yesterday to the telecommunications users conference; and, of course, the Prime Minister has given it to them in the neck.

Despite all the rhetoric, there is no commitment by this Government to establishing a proper framework for competitive services in subscription television. The Government in this area, as in every other area, has been moved by the pressures of interests and lobby groups because it is not a government of principle. It has ended up not pleasing anybody. I remind the House of a comment in this morning's Australian Financial Review by Mr Conrad Black—a person whom the Prime Minister, I think it would be fair to say, likes to oblige:

SPEECH.PARA: In a serious country that is not really the way to hand out licences. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that at the conclusion of his speech the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) made the statement that we are not a government of principle. I find that very strange, quite frankly, coming from any member of the Liberal Party or the National Party of this country.

PARA.TAB: I come from the State of Victoria. The honourable gentleman says that we on the Labor side have no principles. The honourable member for Goldstein walks out of the chamber and does not want to hear the very simple fact that anywhere in the State of Victoria today one can walk down any street and publicly say that the Premier of Victoria is a liar. We can say that publicly, loudly, clearly, anywhere and be totally safe from any action for libel. Why is that the case? It is because truth is always a defence to a charge of libel.

In Victoria we all know that those who fly under the banner of the Australian Liberal Party have to bear the odium of that simple fact. So if people on the other side want to come into this place and make allegations that I belong to a government or a party that has no principle, just let them look at the State of Victoria; let them look at Charles Court in Western Australia; let them look at Fightback; let them look at the way they ran the campaign leading up to the election of 13 March; then let them come into this House and say to any of us who stand here that there is no principle in the Government.

I have a great deal of interest in this Bill. I am aware of the reputation of the honourable member for Goldstein. I understand, of course, that he is a noted academic from Monash University in the area of economics; indeed, he might well be interested to know that he lectured my son when he went through the economic faculty at Monash and graduated. I am pleased to say he is a Keynesian economist rather than the dry right wing type that the good professor tries so hard to produce there.

I thought this was my first chance to sit back and listen to the good professor, the honourable member for Goldstein, put forth his views on where the Opposition sits on telecommunications policy. Initially he spent three minutes on this Bill. He then spent 27 minutes explaining where he says the Government is wrong. Not once did he tell us where the Opposition stands. I find this a rather strange debating tactic.

On the one hand we have this very highly skilled academic, a professor of economics, who is highly regarded by the Opposition, who goes almost straight onto the front bench and who is put into this major debate to attack the Government's position on competition policy and telecommunications policy. He spends 27 minutes in a careful and one would say studied way and yet at the conclusion, what do we have? We still do not know where the Opposition stands on anything. I would have thought it is fairly fundamental that, if people want to be critical, they put their own proposition forward first. If the honourable ladies and gentlemen on the other side wish to come into this place and debate matters with us—and we are happy to debate them any time, anywhere, as they well know—surely they should start with a positive proposition on where they stand.

Today at Question Time I thought the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) quite clearly stated the rather simple fact that technology in this area is probably changing at a faster rate than we as politicians have the capacity to draft legislation. We are always behind the eight ball in terms of where technology is leading us. I would have thought what the Government said is quite truthful. I know that the honourable member for Goldstein did not really disagree with the proposition.

In terms of this policy, this House should produce the best service for the country in the long term; it should not jump in quickly, pass legislation and produce a result which will need rapid change as new technology comes in down the track. That is exactly what the Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall) said. He said that we have to change because technology is changing. The Prime Minister clearly put that view at Question Time today.

I must admit that I do not fully understand the various methods by which one can beam out signals through the airwaves. I understand, for example, that the microwave system is a line of sight system. One does not have to be an Einstein to understand that if there is a hill or valley in the way of that particular type of signal it cannot be received. In the electorate of McEwen, which has a few hills here and there and some wonderful mountains as well, I have noticed that when I am using a mobile telephone—which I am told is similar technology—on many occasions the conversation I am having will be cut off as I drive down a hill. That being the case, it makes an awful lot of sense—to me at least, with my rather technologically unskilled brain—for us to look at ways of getting better technology and a better method to give more people a chance to beam in to pay TV.

Are those opposite opposed to this approach? Did I hear the shadow Minister for communications, the honourable member for Goldstein, say that those opposite are opposed to it? I ask any honourable member in this House: has anyone on the opposition side said that he or she does not want equal competition in technology? I have to say that I am a bit disappointed that the professor of economics, who has probably sat down in various theatres at Monash University and spent months lecturing young, eager students on what we mean exactly by competition in an economic sense, did not really define what he meant by competition. Is he saying that each individual type of technology capable of delivering pay TV to a house should be equal in competition terms or equal in technological terms? Where do we go with competition in this sense?

Surely the reality is this: if I am a consumer of this product, wanting to sit at home and pay my money to buy pay TV, and if there are various technologies which will deliver a better service to me wherever I live, then I should be entitled, in competition terms, to choose the technology which best suits my purposes. Surely I should be entitled to that choice. I do not know whether the Opposition supports that.

At the conclusion of his speech I am sure the honourable member for Goldstein left this House totally bemused as to where exactly the Opposition stands. I guess there was a real attempt to put a case against the Prime Minister and against my colleague the Minister for Communications, who is sitting at the table. There was a similar attempt to put a case against Senator Collins in the other place. But it was a rather tedious and lengthy attempt and I must say, as a lawyer, that at the end of the case I felt like shouting out, `Nolle prosequi; no case to answer, your worship.' I thought it was a rather poor attempt to mount any sort of attack on the Government.

The other thing I noticed over the last few days, in the rather heavy communications debate that has gone on here, is the Opposition's attack on the broadcasting legislation. It accepted this legislation in this House and in the Senate, and it was this legislation which gave rise to the tendering processes which have now caused so much pain and anguish. It seems to me that if people really believe in open, unlimited, laissez-faire competition—as I understand the term—there should be no restrictions on tender whatsoever. The marketplace should be told, `We have a service we want to provide. We ask you to put in your cost and your vision as to how this service can be provided and there will be no strings attached as to who can apply'.

I would have thought from the viewpoint of the honourable member for Goldstein that that was free, open competition—no restrictions, no hedges, no bars. In that sense, people would not have to be Packers or Murdochs to compete for one of these licences; they would not have to have a huge merchant bank or multinational behind them somewhere. Anyone would be able put in an application and apply for a licence. The process down the track should then be that someone who was first considered for one of those licences ought to satisfy the Australian Broadcasting Commission that he or she can do the work and provide the service. That party would also have to satisfy the Trade Practices Commission that the process was not anti-competitive under the requirements of the trade practices legislation.

Is there anything fundamentally wrong with any of the tenderers who tendered for the licence having paid-up capital of only $500,000, $100,000 or $500? In competitive terms, is there any reason why anyone could not have applied for that tender and, if successful, gone into the marketplace and said, `I have the right to provide this service; can I raise the money and float a company'? Could potential players not go to the market to raise the capital to deliver the service? What is wrong with that? Is that anti-competitive, or is that the most open form of competition one could possibly have?

Somehow or other I get the view that the honourable member for Goldstein does not like that kind of competition. It now seems he is saying that in order to get a licence one must have a sufficient capital base to put up a fair slice of cash before a tenderer can go down the track to the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Trade Practices Commission. The number of potential players in the scene is reduced right away and the process is loaded in favour of the people with the big cash, who are the only ones who can play that kind of tendering game.

I have been a bit surprised by the Opposition's approach to this issue. After all, those opposite are the free enterprise people—the laissez-faire economists—who say `Let's open it up to everyone to have an equal and fair go'. But perhaps I was wrong. Maybe what I heard during the last election campaign about competition and where the Opposition stands on opening up the marketplace was a dream. Maybe the Opposition threw out its views on competition with most of Fightback and the GST.

In a sense, I suppose this legislation is an omnibus Bill in that it is quite basic and simple in what it will do. I agree totally with the honourable member for Goldstein when he says that it is designed to foster competition in the delivery of mobile telephone systems. I certainly have a great interest in getting better facilities for mobile telephones as soon as I can. As I have already explained, there are certain parts of my electorate where, when going up and down hills and mountains, it is rather difficult to pick up a signal over the mobile telephone.

I will watch with interest the proposed code which will come out of the legislation. I recall my days in local government and in legal practice when I always had a fairly fundamental concern about government resuming property, by legislation, from private property owners—albeit for the good of society as a whole. I have always had some faint concern about the way governments can, through legislation such as this, say to a private owner, `Look, this Act allows us to come onto your property, take some of your land and install something on it'. Obviously, in this case it is a mechanism for beaming out a signal—probably a tower with the allied equipment on top.

Quite often private citizens feel rather threatened by bureaucracy and rather threatened by the power of governments to do this. Anyone who has served in local government, or who has been close to ordinary people in the community—as we always are on this side, although one is not too sure about those on the other side—can identify closely with their concerns. I hope the Minister can tell me when the code is prepared that we will give people the right to consultation. I hope we will give adequate consideration to their concerns as we go down this track of compulsory takeover, if you like, of their properties for the purpose of a common good with which I, for one, would not disagree.

The other concern that I have in these areas is the question of fair and adequate compensation. I do not think there are many members of the House, some of whom have been around politics for a long while, who have not had one constituent, with beating of breast and very heavy breathing, accuse government, be it State, federal or local, of ripping him off by a compulsory acquisition of land for some government purpose. I would ask the Minister to make sure, if we go down this track, that certainly any person in the electorate of McEwen who may have a particular parcel of land which is required for a facility will have his or her concerns properly approached by the bureaucrats concerned, that they will not be treated as just a simple cipher and that any consideration paid for the compulsory acquisition is proper and reasonable and will, in fact, include loss of future income if it is a farming area.

I note that the code which will apply under this legislation will require governments and organisations to give written notice to the occupier of intention to inspect and enter and, if they do in fact exercise their rights under the legislation, they will be required to give full restoration to the surface of the land and to the removal of material. I am pleased to see also that there is a fiat there that all reasonable steps must be taken to ensure as little damage as possible.

As more of these towers pop up around our countryside—and I suppose all of us driving around the place have seen them popping up here, there and everywhere with their spiky little antennas sitting on top of them—we are all increasingly being inundated with concerns by many residents as to the electro-magnetic radiation aspects of these various electronic and microwave devices. I do not profess to have any simple answer. As a lawyer I am sometimes rather bemused by the technology we are now talking about, with compression and heaven only knows what else, and I am glad it is the Minister, and not me, who has to handle these things.

There is, I suppose, an increasing concern about the consequences to health of many of the electro-magnetic devices and signals now coming through our countryside. From my reading and from the research that I have been able to uncover I believe that people should not be concerned, that in fact the evidence at this stage is certainly fairly clear that electro-magnetic radiation is not as guilty as some people would like to believe and that the level of electro-magnetic radiation emissions from these mobile facilities is well within Australian standards. I am pleased to see that in fact the legislation will ensure that the Australian standards will be met in relation to all emissions from these facilities.
I have been out of this place for three years, having a bit of a holiday, I suppose, and talking to more normal people than one would traditionally meet in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a pity that you did not come back more refreshed.

—We are happy to have you.

—I am certainly happy; I am not too sure about honourable members opposite but I appreciate their concern. I must say that some things really do not change. I am happy to applaud this Bill and to applaud the Minister for Communications for presenting it to the House.

—I must compliment the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) on his return to this Parliament. He obviously has not lost the capacity to talk under water—he is drinking it now. He is welcomed back as a good friend. I missed him in the three years that he was out of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: May I address some of the concerns raised by the honourable member for McEwen, particularly the land access code proposed in the legislation. It is envisaged that the land access code will address issues such as responsibility of carriers with respect to private property owners or occupiers; obligatory consultation procedures between landowners or occupiers and carriers; the possibility of carriers sharing facilities to minimise the proliferation of the infrastructure—which the honourable member referred to—recourses available to property owners or occupiers of land; and, of course, the aesthetic considerations of the towers that are springing up. The code will apply across the board to all carriers' activities in accessing land, thus giving private property owners or occupiers more safeguards than they currently have.

I would also like to refer to some of the comments made by the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp). The majority of his speech was taken up with pay television, which is not dealt with in this Bill, but I reiterate that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) again clearly enunciated the policy of the Government in Question Time today.

I want to talk to the issue that he raised in relation to the Australian Financial Review article of today and perhaps reassure the honourable member about some of the concerns he raised about that particular article. The first paragraph of the article said that I, as Minister for Communications, had raised new doubts about the Federal Government's long-term plans for the telecommunications industry by suggesting that extra carriers may not be allowed after the industry is deregulated in 1997. Today's Financial Review has misrepresented comments I made at the Australian Telecommunications Users Group conference yesterday about the telecommunications industry arrangements to apply after 30 June 1997. The Government announced in November 1990 that the duopoly will end on 30 June 1997. This decision stands and has not—I repeat not—been changed.

This decision is considered to provide a strong incentive to Telecom to restructure and for Optus to become established as a credible competitor. The review that I referred to in my speech is a review that has been scheduled for some time to determine the regulatory arrangements to apply after competition is opened fully in 1997. It is not a review about whether there will be open competition, but about, in fact, the nature of that competition.

To give industry certainty about future regulatory arrangements, it is proposed to have the review well under way before the end of this Parliament's current term in 1996. The scope of the review has not been determined. It is expected to be broad ranging and cover such issues as whether any economic regulation is necessary at all, whether licensing is appropriate, and the powers, the rights and responsibilities of carriers, such as land access power and universal service obligations. This is itself not an exhaustive list. There will be full consultation with the industry during the review and we hope that the Opposition will play a very constructive part in this discussion process which will take the term of this Parliament.

The Government is very proud of what it has done in terms of providing competition in telecommunications. It has introduced a regulated duopoly that expires in 1997. This model is now being reviewed by many countries, to see how they can break down their own monopolies and move towards open competition. Many South-East Asian nations are visiting us on a regular basis to have a look at the Australian model, and it is something that we can be very proud of.

The legislation we are debating today shows another element of the competition that we have put into telecommunications. We already have Telecom and Optus operating mobile phones. The third carrier, Vodaphone, will be in operation by the end of this year. It will be a very competitive environment for mobile phones, and one that I think will be the envy of many countries. Certainly, telecommunication companies in the United States clearly say that the models the Government has put in place in Australia for competition between the two carriers, Telecom and Optus, are models that they wished they had taken on.

Let me also stress that competition is not just between the carriers. The carriers basically control the networks. Already we have a large number of resellers who are in the market providing telecommunications competition to all that equipment that hangs off the network. This is indeed one of the great policies that this Government has put in place; one that I am particularly proud of and very proud to be administering for the next term of this Government. Despite all the histrionics that go on in this place, I am sure that policy has bipartisan support and provides the most important element of competition. We see that on a daily basis with the reductions in the cost of telecommunications and reductions in the cost of telephone calls, providing the Australian consumer with the real benefit. Competition is no good unless it provides the consumer with the benefit. I am very pleased to commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I take this opportunity in the spirit of generosity of congratulating the Speaker on his appointment and you on your appointment. This is the first opportunity I have had as the member for Berowra to formally speak and to offer those pleasant remarks. But they will not be the last that I will utter on social security matters where the Australian people, particularly the elderly and the unemployed, have been so grievously let down by this Government.

PARA.TAB: The Social Security Amendment Bill 1993 gives effect to a small number of the Government's election commitments which were announced prior to the 1993 Federal election. The Bill also mirrors some technical amendments necessary due to changes in the area of migration law. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) took the opportunity in his second reading speech to make some broad-ranging remarks about the Government's intention in relation to this legislation. It is timely to recall what he had to say:

SPEECH.PARA: On Saturday 13 March the Australian people clearly indicated that they shared the Government's belief that this nation must advance together. By advancing together not only will we build a strong economy but a fairer society that pays particular attention to the special needs of groups such as the aged and the unemployed.

It is to those remarks of the Parliamentary Secretary that I intend to direct my comments in this speech tonight. I am disappointed that in the first two weeks of this Parliament we are subjected to a guillotine which constrains the debate and which ensures that there is limited time to comment on matters that I wish to raise. Few of my colleagues will have the opportunity to comment.

PARA.TAB: It is a great pity that the functions of the Parliament are diminished—it is little more than a tabling office. We are also privileged to have the Parliamentary Secretary in the chamber. It seems that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), who carries primary responsibility, will not deign to join us in this debate. That is another sign of the importance attached by this Government to issues affecting the elderly and the unemployed—fine words, but its actions speak louder.

The Minister's speech fails to mention that there were several election commitments and promises made by this Government that have not been captured in this legislation. Indeed, some have already been jettisoned as the Government struggles with the enormous difficulty—and I admit that—of dealing with the cost of promises that it made in the knowledge of the economic circumstances of this country, and the enormous economic difficulties that we face. The fact is that the Government's promises and commitments were made in the knowledge that was before it and not given to the Australian people. Before I progress too far, I move:

That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its failure to address the special needs of the unemployed and the aged, noting:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)the comments of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training that the number of long-term unemployed would inevitably rise to between 400,000 and 500,000 in the next 12 to 18 months;
(2)the abandonment of the promise to remove pensioners from the taxation system by 1995;

(3)the Government's failure to guarantee the extension of full Commonwealth fringe benefits to all long-term retirees beyond the remaining three months of 1992-93, even though the Prime Minister made special mention of this `promise' in his campaign policy speech;

(4)the Government's failure to rule out major increases in taxation and to outline a planned program of expenditure reduction to enable responsible implementation of its campaign commitments in relation to social security matters;
(5)further changes and tampering with the assets test for pensioners, adding further confusion and insecurity to their retirement plans; and
(6)the need for a full and complete review of the inter-relationship between income and asset tests for better integration of the taxation and social security systems".

A number of comments have been made in recent days which should be of great concern to the Australian community. The principal point I want to make about the plight of the unemployed is that the Government held out during the election campaign that its policies and programs would create additional employment opportunities. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) spoke glibly about the creation of an additional 500,000 new jobs. He was disparaging about our longer term commitment to growth in the Australian economy through significant taxation and other reform that would produce two million jobs by the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: Immediately after the election the Government now wants to speak about the reality that it was unprepared to acknowledge in that campaign. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) announced that the number of long-term unemployed would rise to between 400,000 and 500,000 in the next 12 to 18 months. That is disastrous for those people who will be left in that predicament.

At the end of each period of recession from which Australia has suffered the number of long-term unemployed has remained high, and this recession will be no different. The hardship of that outcome will be faced by this country for generations. According to the Minister, where it is now unacceptable, where it is going will be even more unacceptable. They are fairly glib words. It is already clear that the Minister is trying to trade on his honesty in admitting after the election that this would be the result. Of course, he fails to be more honest and admit that this miserable position is a result of the policies of the Keating Government—a government which has been in office for nine years and whose record is one of record unemployment affecting so many Australians.

As I said, it is a great pity that the Minister did not exhibit a similar degree of honesty during the election campaign when the disparate state of the Australian economy was hidden behind what can only be described as shameless lies, distortions and half-truths by Ministers. This statement he is now making is even more fatuous in light of his statement that it is reasonable to say to the long-term unemployed, `You are the loser', and put them on the scrap heap. It is a disgraceful utterance.

This Government ought to be thoroughly condemned for corrupting its obligations and duties to the Australian people and then call them losers as the Minister has. Worse than that, having claimed that the long-term unemployed will take up a massively increased share of the total number of unemployed, the Government still has no solution to this worsening tragedy. It has no plan to reduce unemployment, no plan to effectively stimulate the economy—no idea what to do next. It is a government which has run out of ideas except for distractions, and we see an occasional grin from government members when distractions are mentioned.

When looking for ideas we need to go to those members who have been relegated to the backbench. These ideas seem to come from the former Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett). He has said that he does not believe that we will find a solution to this problem. He was not saying that before the election. The honourable member for Bonython told us in his Evatt lecture that high levels of unemployment and increasingly high levels of long-term unemployed are a permanent feature of the Australian landscape and not just a temporary aberration produced by the pulling of the wrong economic levers. He says that we must throw more money at the problem and that we need to have a bigger social welfare program. I do not see any commitment coming from the Government to that other than the `generosity' of the programs that are now in place.

The honourable member for Bonython was a senior Cabinet Minister for most of the time that this Government was in power, yet he laments this catastrophe. He was part of the responsibility. Undoubtedly, this Government will have to find more money to provide income and welfare support for the large numbers of people affected by the recession that the Government told us we had to have. That is an outcome of the Government's policies. The Government has not told us where the money will come from, but we are getting fairly clear pictures of that now after the election as government members talk about increased taxation. This is happening in the context of the Government legislating for tax reductions before the election and campaigning against anybody else who suggested there may be a case for taxation reform.

We have reports that the Government will raise existing taxes or levy new ones. It is based upon a proper assessment that, unless the Government is prepared to reduce its expenditure in some way, it will have to address the ballooning deficit. It will be a ballooning deficit because of the social welfare commitments to the increasingly large number of unemployed people.

The Government is talking about broadening sales tax, doubling Medicare levies and introducing an energy levy. There is a retraction of the policy to reduce the tax obligations of those who have a pension entitlement. All of these measures the Government is now talking about in a desperate effort to rein in the Budget which it has allowed to bolt.

In 1989 this Government made a commitment to remove all age and service pensioners from the tax system by 1995. This promise was first released by the then Minister for Social Security as part of the Government's retirement incomes policy. It is not as if the matter passed without notice. The Government was questioned time and time again on the costing and implementation of this promise. The Government was tested on it. We were told it was not possible to give us any details of that measure until it was close to its implementation. We were fobbed off.

Of course, then the Labor Party had its election launch and as part of that launch it released a document called Australian Labor Party: election 1993: policies for older Australians. This was handed out by Labor candidates across Australia and utilised by senior Cabinet Ministers such as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in his electorate. I have a copy of a pledge—a pledge, mind you—called, `Labor pledges new benefits for senior citizens', and the subheading, `Tax', which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Remove all age and service pensioners from the Tax System by 1995.
At the bottom of the document it states:
Printed and authorised by Simon Crean 6 Atherton Road Oakleigh 3166.

Senior Ministers were putting this out in marginal electorates to get themselves elected to this place, reliant upon a document distributed at Bankstown, in the Prime Minister's name—Labor's Policies for older Australians. There could not be a clearer statement under the heading Tax Reform. It states:

Labor's commitment to removing all age and service pensioners from the tax system by 1995 will benefit pensioners paid at the part rate as well as providing some assistance to retirees with incomes beyond the pension cut out point.
Labor is working on details of implementing this proposal.

Working on details of implementing! They were hidden in the cavern at Bankstown, working out how they would lie their way out of this issue after the election. That is what they were on about, working out how they were going to lie their way out of it after the election. That is exactly what we saw. After the election the Federal Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) stated:
It is certainly not an undertaking we have renewed and I certainly do not feel under any obligation to follow through with it.

How outrageous! I do not know how any Labor Party member could come into this House and hold his head up with any degree of dignity and speak about the needy, the aged, and the unemployed when Labor Party members have dealt with them like that.

PARA.TAB: I assure every Labor member that we did not go out making glib promises of things that we did not believe we could implement. We made honest statements upon which we sought to be judged, but we certainly did not make lies as policies and walk away from them within three weeks. That is what the Labor Party is about and that is its record. I want to assure members that, as the shadow Minister for social security and Parliamentary Secretary, I will not allow the Prime Minister to forget that undertaking throughout the life of this Parliament.

Not one promise that he makes in the future will have any credibility, when he makes a glib promise of that nature and expects to be able to get away with it. I certainly will not let his Ministers get away with it. I am sure I will gather up more evidence of Ministers, like the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, making statements of that sort to their electors. I will not let his Ministers forget it.

We are now on the path to witnessing the Government walking away from further commitments that it made in these policy documents. Another policy of the Government, blatantly exploited during the election campaign, was the promise to extend full Commonwealth fringe benefits to all long-term allowees beyond the remaining three months of 1992-93. Yet we had the Minister, in his second reading speech, introducing weasel words because what he is now suggesting is that a commitment, that in this document was so clear, is not a promise. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: From April this year retirees who receive as little as one dollar per week in pension will also be eligible for the full range of Commonwealth and State provided fringe benefits for services such as hearing aids, electricity, rates and transport.
It did not say for three months. It did not say for the balance of 1992-93. It was held out that this was a promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not for three months.
—Let us look at what the Minister is saying now.
—It was I who said it.

—No, the Minister said it. It was the Minister's speech. It was in the name of the Minister for Social Security. The honourable member may have delivered the words for him but they were his words. The Minister is responsible. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: First, the Government recently extended full Commonwealth fringe benefits to all pensioners and older long-term allowees and agreed to compensate the States in 1992-93 for the cost of extending verified State concessions to this group.

That is where the money is being provided. When we go into estimates and ask about these matters what do officers say? They have to answer these matters honestly. In the Senate estimates committee hearing the officers made it quite clear. This is what was said:

Question: Has the Commonwealth given a commitment that it will acknowledge that it has made a prior commitment that anticipates further extension of its program in the next year's budget and subsequently.
Answer—
this was by the officer—
No, I believe the answer is no.
Question: It may well be a three month only program.
Departmental Answer: I suppose that's theoretically possible. If negotiations break down . . . that's possible.
Here we have a situation in which the Government has no agreements with the State beyond the end of June.

TALK.START.PARA: —We only promised the Commonwealth ones.

—Only promised Commonwealth ones! These are the weasel words. Where is the Commonwealth only responsible in relation to—to pick up the speech—electricity, rates and transport? It did not say, `We are only responsible for Commonwealth ones'. These are the words `electricity, rates and transport'.
—Look at the Constitution.

—I know what the Constitution says. The Government held out that it would be making arrangements with the States to ensure proper compensation to provide those fringe benefits. I have got people ringing my office now asking about rates for this year. What are they told? There are no arrangements in place. Why did one of the Government's own members stand up here and ask a question which the Minister could not answer about the subsidisation of rates? The arrangements are not in place. People pay rates for 12 months. They do not pay them for three months. No arrangements have been made with the local government authorities. That is the situation. It is quite clear. It is beyond doubt. The Government has let them down. Now the Minister comes up with these weasel words. We will let everybody note them very clearly. The Government is walking away from this commitment.
—No, we are not.

—The Minister says, `We are not'. Let us be clear. Do these words mean that for retirees who receive as little as $1 a week we are providing a full range of Commonwealth and State provided fringe benefits for services such as electricity, rates and transport.
—We are negotiating with the States.

—We are negotiating with the States! So there is no obligation. They are walking away from the obligation as fast as they can in exactly the same way as they did in relation to integrating pensioners into the tax system. There might be financial implications and we might have to be responsible about the financial commitments that we make. I do not run away from that but we did not make these promises; the Government did. The Government had the knowledge. It was privy to all the material that can be provided by Treasury and Finance. It had the calculation. It knows what the assumptions are. It can make the judgments but it wanted to deceive the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: The Government wanted people to vote for it on the basis of a promise. It cannot walk away from those commitments. It will have either to accept the responsibility and find the resources and accept the odium that brings, or it will have to accept the judgment of every elderly person, every retiree and every allowee that its word cannot be accepted, that it will break it at the first term. The Minister said, `Some of these people are called losers, thrown on to the scrap heap'. When the Prime Minister spoke about the victory of the Labor Party being for true believers, what is he saying about the pensioners and the unemployed who, in good faith, voted for a government in the expectation that it would honour its promises.

We have other matters. This Bill introduces changes to the pensions assets test, which will apply from 20 September this year. This issue was said to help over 40,000 non-pensioner and part-pensioner retirees at a total cost of $44 million to several portfolios. We have also seen a rash, particularly at the end of last year, of so-called cost saving measures. Some of them are most unreliable, looking at the assumptions upon which they have been made.

What the Government is doing increasingly is introducing a series of new anomalies between groups of people. We all agree that the assets and income testing arrangements need to be carefully targeted, to ensure that people who benefit from the provision that the Government makes to assist the needy are those who have a genuine need. We also need to ensure that the arrangements are fair.

As honourable members know, I will shortly be introducing a private member's Bill dealing with one aspect of this matter. But there are other areas in which these matters arise. I think it is clear that the Government will have to look very carefully at this issue of the relationship between the assets and the income tests to ensure that genuine fairness is introduced. A complete review of this inter-relationship between the two systems is necessary.

Several other areas need to be addressed. In the area of social security we have the Government's treatment of unrealised capital gains, particularly in relation to shares assessed as income under the income test rather than under the assets test. This is in stark contrast to the way in which these issues are dealt with elsewhere, particularly in relation to taxation. There are areas where the Government can, I think, look legitimately at reforming the social security regime. It is a great pity that we are seeing these matters dealt with in this ad hoc way, coupled with the very clear breaking of promises to the elderly and the needy.

I assure the Minister that he ought to take on board all of the promises and commitments that the Government has made in relation to these matters. He can rest assured that I will be closely monitoring every one of them. He ought to ensure that the commitments are honoured thoroughly and properly to the benefit of those people who voted for this Government in the expectation that they would be honoured.

We have supported this legislation generally. Some of the policies were ones that we had also argued for; some were not. But where the Government has a mandate from us it will have that mandate endorsed. We did not embark upon irresponsible promises in this area, and that ought to be noted very clearly.

I want to raise one other matter. I referred this Bill to a number of organisations which have an interest in social security legislation. One of them was the Australian Council of Social Service. I am grateful for the observations that it offered in relation to the Bill, and I thank it for that. I note that other organisations to whom I wrote have not had time to respond. It ought to be understood that people have only one week in which to comment on this legislation.

The Australian Council of Social Service has made some comments about the adequacy of the administrative arrangements in place between the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Department of Social Security in relation to the six-month waiting period now imposed on new migrants before they are eligible for benefits, unless of course they are refugees or obtain access under the humanitarian program. They were important qualifications, but it appears to a number of the organisations which are offering advice in this area that those people who are refugees and humanitarian applicants are not being advised of their entitlements. I hope that the Minister will take that on board and ensure that people are not being misled in this way.

I thank the House for giving me this opportunity to speak. I have shortened my remarks, although not by as much as I would have liked. If it were not for the challenge that was issued in relation to the Government's commitments I might have been able to deal with this legislation in a shorter fashion. But I hope the honourable member who follows will endeavour to reconcile the Government's promises and commitments with the walking away from them we are seeing now.
