—May I open my remarks on the Social Security Amendment Bill and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill by congratulating the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) on his election to that seat and on his elevation to the position of shadow spokesperson on social security. Despite some of the comments I will make about his address, I find him to be an honourable and decent man and I am pleased to see that he has secured this position in the important social security portfolio. I know he will bring particular interests and qualities to that position.

PARA.TAB: However, I wish to take issue with some of his comments. I remind the honourable member that the election is over and that the Australian people once more placed their trust in the Australian Labor Party—and what a wise decision that was. It is very understandable why they made it. We need to remind the House of some of the commitments and promises that the coalition made coming into this election campaign. When one listens to the honourable member for Berowra one would think that those opposite had such an incredibly generous policy towards social security and the unemployed that we on this side of the House are the evil forces. We need to set the record straight because I am afraid that the honourable member for Berowra has engaged in a little bit of rewriting of history.

I remind honourable members of three major points in the coalition's policy agenda. They are very important to remember, particularly when we look at the amendment moved by the honourable member. In this amendment he is claiming that the Government has failed to address the special needs of the unemployed and the aged. Let us not forget what the Opposition proposed to do to the unemployed and the aged. First and foremost, those opposite were going to slash $10 billion from social security—and they talk about Labor not being committed to the care of the aged. In every single Budget since Labor came to power we have increased in real terms the amount of money we have spent on social security and on care for the aged—unlike the coalition's proposal to slash $10 billion. So let us not have any poppycock from the honourable member for Berowra about the great compassion that those opposite feel for the aged.

Let us also not forget the fundamental and major aspect of their policy platform, which was the imposition of an inequitable goods and services tax on all people in this country. What would have had a more draconian impact on the quality of life of pensioners and the unemployed than such an evil tax? It would have impacted on their quality of life and standards of living every single day. It would have affected their capacity to feed and clothe themselves and their ability to get around in the community. So let us not have any hypocrisy about the Opposition's care of the aged and the unemployed.

When one does a detailed assessment of the Opposition's economic and social programs it becomes clear that employment would not have increased by two million as the Opposition claimed, but, as most economists have assessed, unemployment would have increased, particularly in the first three or four years of its policies. How would those opposite have reacted to that increase in unemployment? Another plank of the Opposition's program was to slash expenditure on training and assistance in labour market programs; that is how it would have cared for the unemployed. So let us treat this amendment with the contempt that it deserves because it certainly is no true reflection of the policy agenda of the coalition—the policy agenda that was so soundly rejected by the Australian people on 13 March.

The honourable member for Berowra said that we are now intent on breaching election promises and that this legislation does not contain many election promises. He said it had a couple, but he asked what had happened to the rest. I remind the honourable member that most income expenditure measures that governments introduce are introduced in the Budget. He should await the compilation of the Budget before he makes any further criticisms of this Government's intention to implement its election promises. This legislation sees the implementation of a number of election commitments, and I can assure the honourable member that many more will be contained in future legislation to be introduced in the Budget sitting.

The honourable member has also railed against the Government's breach of promise in relation to a couple of other measures. He made a particularly noisy claim that we will be going back on our word with regard to the extension of fringe benefits to part-pensioners. The honourable member has considerably distorted the Government's position and he has ignored our constitutional authority.

The Government has committed itself to the introduction of a range of fringe benefits in areas for which it has responsibility. It is extending fringe benefits to part-pensioners from 1 April to include items such as hearing aids, the health care card, and transport on national rail lines. It does not have direct responsibility to provide pensioner discounts for services such as electricity and rates. It has already provided a compensation package to the States for the remainder of this financial year, and it is negotiating with the State governments to extend that into the next financial year. It is the responsibility of the State governments to come up with a fair and reasonable package, to recognise the real cost of these matters and to put a fair package to us. As I said, we are negotiating with them at the moment. There is no intention on the part of the Commonwealth to abrogate its promises in that area. Any statements to the contrary by the honourable member for Berowra are quite misleading.

The Government has a strong commitment to the extension and improvement of the provision of services to our aged community, whether full or part-pensioners. Only this Government has demonstrated any real compassion for the aged. If one looks at the range of programs we have introduced over the years we have been in power, one would recognise that the fundamental plank of our social justice policy is the care of the aged—to improve their health care, income support, housing and rental assistance, transportation; to improve the full range of services that the aged require. Let that put an end to the poppycock from the honourable member for Berowra.

Although we are in cognate debate, I will be concentrating my words this evening on the Social Security Amendment Bill. I would like to make some brief comments about what is contained in that Bill. Firstly, there are a number of provisions which will benefit many ordinary Australians, who I know will welcome the measures contained in that Bill. The first measure introduces an additional free area of $30 a fortnight for earned income for single recipients of jobsearch allowance and sickness allowance. For recipients with partners, the free area will rise from $30 to $50 a fortnight.

The Bill also adjusts the pension assets test. If a person has assets in excess of the assets value limit, the pension is reduced by only $19.50—down from $26 at the moment—for every $250 in excess assets. The Government has, therefore, taken note of the concerns expressed by the aged community about the impact of the assets test, particularly on those retired people who could be described as assets rich but income poor—a result of the declining interest rates and a consequent declining capacity on the part of those pensioners, part-pensioners and superannuants to earn sufficient income from their assets. The Government has recognised that situation and is extending and expanding the assets test to take account of it.

Also in this legislation the Government is rationalising certain ordinary waiting period provisions applicable to jobsearch, newstart and sickness allowances by consolidating them under one rule. That rule will provide that an ordinary waiting period will not have to be served by a claimant if the claimant has been in receipt of income support for the previous 13 weeks. That measure has been strongly supported by the welfare community. It is also a measure strongly supported by the Australian Council of Social Service, and which it put to us some months ago. The Government picked up on and committed itself to that measure and is now introducing it through this piece of legislation.

It is important to note that one of the reasons why the Australian community supported Labor rather than the coalition in the last election was this Government's commitment to social justice, and its delivery of social justice in policy and practical terms. People knew that the Australian Labor Party had a basic commitment to justice, equity, fairness and caring for the community. They knew that only Labor would be able to implement policies based on those principles and practices. They were correct in making that judgment. With this legislation, and with the other legislation we are to debate today, this Government is putting into practical effect the promises that it has made.

It is also important to note that, through another clause in this legislation, the Government is trying to expand the opportunities for seeking part-time employment to those on unemployment benefits. At present, it is difficult for those who work part-time to be eligible for the full newstart or jobsearch allowance. One of the amendments to the legislation will allow a single recipient up to $30 per fortnight extra income before their payment is reduced. That means people can continue to have some contact with the work force, even if it is on a part-time basis, thereby maintaining their skills and improving their prospects for employment. That is another measure welcomed by the Australian Council of Social Service.

The Government is helping not just those looking for work but also those who have finished their time in the work force—as demonstrated by the changes made to the assets test and the effect that will have on age pensioners. At present, to be eligible for a pension payment, people must have less than the prescribed amount of assets—currently $112,500 for a single home owner and $160,000 for a married home owner—before the asset test takes effect. Although, in effect, the rate will not increase, the maximum threshold before a person is not able to claim even a part-pension has been raised. It is expected that, initially, some 8,400 non-pensioner retirees, and a further 1,300 people presently excluded from other social security pensions on the basis of their assets, will become eligible, while a further 40,000 part-rate pensioners will also gain pension increases from this measure.

The other benefit about which we have talked is the consolidation of the waiting period provisions. That will ensure that claimants for jobsearch, newstart and sickness allowance will better understand what the provisions are. The provisions will become simpler to administer by the department, and clients will more easily understand what they need to do to comply with the provisions. The new provisions replace a number of existing conditions where the ordinary waiting period could be waived. Rationalising these provisions will improve incentives for recipients of those pensions to participate in casual or part-time employment.

The other area on which I would like to briefly comment this evening relates to an issue raised in the amendment moved by the honourable member for Berowra—it has been commented upon recently—and that is the changes to the Social Security Act relating to the treatment of shares. As a representative of a reasonably aged population in the electorate of Moreton, it has been of some concern to me that a lot of hysteria, fear and concern has been built up within the aged community about the impact of the changes that we introduced late last year to the treatment of shares on the aged population. As the honourable member for Berowra knows, the Opposition supported that legislation when it went through both Houses of this Parliament. It accepted that it was a fair measure and that it was bringing equity to the treatment of shares as compared with other forms of investment.

We have now had an orchestrated campaign by the financial planning industry in this country about the impact of this measure to build up as much fear and phobia as possible amongst the aged community. It has been a disgraceful campaign and adds further evidence to that which has been stated in this House by me and other speakers about some of the motives of the financial planning industry, their experience and what they are actually trying to achieve.

The financial planning groups, or some people in the financial planning industry—I should make that distinction, because not all financial planners are engaged in this plan—have seen that their income will be potentially cut by some pensioners getting out of the shares area and moving into other forms of investment. There is nothing that motivates people more than the possibility that they might lose a bit of income, particularly from a gravy train that they perceive pensioners to be. So some people in the financial planning industry have decided to orchestrate a massive campaign around this country which has put a lot of fear into the hearts and minds of many aged people. They have been distorting the true impact of the shares measure and have created a lot of anxiety. I think they should be ashamed of themselves for engaging in that campaign.

I know that my colleague the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) has been involved in trying to explain in a reasonable and rational way to pensioners and aged care groups the true impact of this legislation. He knows, as I know, that none of the fears and phobias that pensioner groups have about this legislation will come to pass. We are bringing in equal treatment for shares and other forms of investment.

For too long, people who had their assets in the shape of shares were given very favourable treatment whereas pensioners that did not engage in speculative action through shares but had other forms of investment were having all of their real value counted. Shares were not being counted. But there is no difference. In fact, there is probably a more favourable benefit in owning shares as compared with other investments because people can realise the real value of their shares almost instantly whereas with many other investments they cannot. The honourable member for Berowra well knows that pensioners who own shares are able to realise the real value of those shares almost instantly and that their real asset value should be counted at their current value and not at their value when first purchased, which could have been many years ago. It is unfair to treat shares differently from other forms of investment.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) and the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) in this debate on the Social Security Amendment Bill and, as it is a cognate debate, also the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. I say to the honourable member for Moreton, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) and others that what Labor was about with its disguised mechanism of last year—which is now codified in legislation and, after review, we quite properly seek to repeal under the good submission of my colleague the honourable member for Berowra—was a notional capital gains tax. These proposals were going to apply to pensioners after 30 September this year. It is a notional capital gains tax.

PARA.TAB: At the moment—I have no argument—dividends from shares held by pensioners are taken into account, as honourable members agree, in the pension and incomes test. But buried in the small print—it is the thin end of the wedge—is the possibility of pensioners not trading on the stock exchange in the course of any particular calendar year but holding shares purchased some time ago losing their pension and being hit by a notional capital gains tax if the value of those shares went up after 30 September. That is a pernicious piece of legislation and is striking down the very core of freehold title, in one sense, and the ownership and encouragement to own shares.

After our careful review, Labor has now been fully exposed: the legislation is about a notional capital gains tax to apply initially to pensioners holding—not trading and not acting as speculators—their portfolios. Because share markets tend to go up and down—Westpac shares and the like go up and down—there will be a form of notional capital gains tax. It would be interesting to know how much capital gains tax would be payable in respect of trading in the notorious Westpac shares. In the public interest, I think that is a fair and legitimate question to ask.

Senator MacGibbon, in the Senate, will provide more detailed comment, discussion and debate on the assets test aspects of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, which my colleague the honourable member for Berowra has handled very effectively in this House. The coalition will not be opposing the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill in the House of Representatives. The Bill seeks to vary the service pension assets test by moderating its application. It also alters significantly the eligibilities and certain entitlements of our peacekeepers in Cambodia, Yugoslavia and Somalia. I will deal with each of those in turn.

In respect of Cambodia, there is now a beyond border authorisation of some 50 kilometres into Laos and Thailand. In many ways history is repeating itself. In one sense, what set out as a limited exercise in peacekeeping to Cambodia and Cambodia only obviously now involves an extended activity across border. Given the fluid nature of some of those borders in that part of Asia and South-East Asia, it is a practical extension and one which the coalition accepts. However, I warn that the security conditions facing all Australians in Cambodia—not only the peacekeepers and the diplomatic staff but also non-government officers, some of whom have been there many years, and those who have arrived in more recent times at places such as Siem Reap near Angkor Wat and elsewhere—have deteriorated in recent weeks following the withdrawal of the Khmer Rouge from its headquarters in Phnom Penh and its more strident and shocking activity most recently in derailing and mining a section of the railway line in Cambodia. There is not much operational railway line in Cambodia. There is a little bit less now; the Khmer Rouge has progressively blown up sections of it. Worse still, those escaping from the wreckage of the derailed train were attacked by machine-gun fire and rocket fire in classic Khmer Rouge style of the worst kind about which we learnt in the five years of the Pol Pot Khmer Rouge regime of yesteryear.

It is year zero activity of the worst kind. In Cambodia we have some very brave peace-keepers carrying out their jobs in very difficult circumstances. I note the additional commitment of 100 extra personnel and helicopters. I understand the personnel will be covered by the clauses in this legislation, as are the other peacekeepers, and that they will receive full eligibility under the declaration of operational area for Cambodia. I wish all Australians in Cambodia, and in the areas around the borders in Laos and Thailand, safety and well being during this critical period leading up to and beyond the election, and I hope for their earliest possible return. I hope the election will be able to be held against the odds, but I warn that it is a very delicate situation and one which the Federal Government must continually and closely monitor in all the circumstances.

I turn now to part 4 of the Bill, which relates to the area previously known as Yugoslavia. Atrocities have clearly been committed by Croats, Muslims and Serbs almost every day and night in very sad circumstances in this civil war in Bosnia-Herzegovina. It is a bitter pill for those involved that some 75 years after the war to end all wars—a description of World War I—that part of the world from which World War I arguably originated is at war again. On this occasion there is probably more blood being shed in a horrific way in the area previously known as Yugoslavia.

The legislation before the House provides for an operational area declaration for the purposes of the Veterans' Entitlements Act to pick up the service of ADF personnel who are serving with United Nations forces, and that will constitute qualifying service. That is as it should be, and I certainly support it. This is a rare opportunity for this Parliament to make direct comment with regard to that conflict. I equally support and hope for the application of a workable early cease-fire as a result of negotiations that have taken place. It is to be hoped that the parties can reach a conclusion that will allow safe haven areas to be established, for the killing to be stopped and for a resolution of the other matters without the loss of additional bloodshed, of human life and without the involvement of surrounding countries in a way which could deteriorate very rapidly.

Some have said that we should not say a great deal about this; that we should be absolutely even-handed in our comments. I cannot be even-handed in looking at that horrific conflict. We have to ask who started it, in the light of what has happened in the last year or two, and I particularly have to note the role of the Serbs. The sooner it all ends and a sustainable cease-fire is imposed, the better. That part of the legislation is supported by the coalition.

It is Government policy to be even-handed in a related part of the world, and I refer to the Middle East—to the Israel and Arab equation. The Middle East is watching developments and is very disappointed with the treatment of Muslims in Yugoslavia. How even-handed is it for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to be making representations to Asian countries on behalf of Israel in relation to matters various? There are legitimate questions to ask about how even-handed that type of activity is. These are matters that have to be assessed very carefully. I am concerned for the Israeli deportees to Southern Lebanon. Recently, I had the opportunity of meeting the Deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs in the Israeli Government. I make no apology for having expressed my concerns to him in a brief and informal meeting. This is an area of the world that is extremely volatile and in which Australia has legitimate national interests, which I will always seek to pursue.

I am always open to gaining more knowledge of the trading opportunities in these areas in my other capacity as shadow Minister for trade. I take this opportunity to reveal to the House that in the winter recess I plan to visit the following countries, schedule commitments permitting, in this order: Japan, China, Tibet, Pakistan, Iran, Syria, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia and Thailand. I shall make particular reference to trading opportunities, especially for the wool industry and Australian manufactured goods. I will be visiting China with a number of other National Party colleagues as part of a National Party delegation exploring those trade opportunities and ways and means of accelerating the wool pipeline.

I come back to another part of the Bill, and I refer to Somalia. Australia's commitment has been very successful. It involves principally the 1st Battalion Royal Australian Regiment. The legislation declares Somalia as an operational area, and the ADF personnel serving with the UN in Somalia will have their service regarded as qualifying service. I welcome that. I salute the work of the 1st Battalion Royal Australian Regiment—my old unit—in Somalia. I am concerned to learn that during the course of that commitment there have been over 30 accidental discharges of weapons. This would seem to be an unusually high number. It reflects, perhaps, the security of patrolling, necessitating those patrols to be conducted with safety catches off. It might also be an outcome of lack of training budgets over a period of time. Whatever the real reason, that is an unacceptably high level. But when we look at the commitment given by the 1st Battalion Royal Australian Regiment, and by the related personnel from the Australian Defence Force in Somalia, including those involved in the support roles of the Royal Australian Navy and the Royal Australian Air Force, I have nothing but praise for the overall activity, and the coalition supports that section of the legislation.

The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill is not opposed by the coalition. It does ease the burden of the assets test and does provide for our peacekeeping forces in Cambodia, Yugoslavia and Somalia. Australia also has peacekeepers in Pakistan, whom I hope to see as part of my visit to the Middle East. We also have peacekeepers in the Sahara Desert and in part of Israel. I say to all our peacekeepers, keep up the good work and we hope that you return safely to Australia; you now have the confidence and knowledge that that service is recognised as operational in terms of veterans legislation and related legislation, and that is as it should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Amendment Bill and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill go some way towards ensuring that some of the promises that the Federal Government made prior to the election on 13 March are put in place. While the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) did make some disingenuous comments about the nature of these Bills and the extent to which they are producing a response in the community, I would point out that the electorate of Richmond has a high level of unemployed, plus a high number of aged people and people with veterans pensions. PARA.TAB: The proposed changes in the Social Security Amendment Bill—both the increase in the additional free area for the recipients and the reduction in the waiting period—are matters which, although not crucial, certainly go a long way towards helping people who are on unemployment benefits or social security of some sort remain on their feet. Unfortunately, I have to admit there is a high level of unemployment in my area. As the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) so aptly pointed out, these benefits help these people to keep in contact with the work force so that, when the economy does pick up and the opportunities are there, they will not be out of touch and will have the skills to step straight into a job. I do commend the local councils in the electorate of Richmond, with its present unemployment situation, for the work that is being done there through the capital works program money which is being used to create jobs.

The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill is also of very significant interest to me and to many of the veterans in my electorate. The portfolio Bill gives effect to the Government's election promise to reduce that assets test withdrawal rate from $104 to $78 per annum for each $1,000 above the assets test threshold. This will increase the amount of assets that a person will be able to have and still qualify for payment of some service pension.

It also extends the benefits under the veterans affairs legislation to a number of Defence Force personnel serving with the United Nations peacekeeping forces in Somalia and in areas comprising the former Yugoslavia. The Bill will provide that such service will be regarded as operational and qualifying service. The Bill includes an amendment to extend operational service in Cambodia to areas in Laos and Thailand that are no more than 50 kilometres from the border with Cambodia.

As a result of the changes designating Somalia and the area comprising the former Yugoslavia as operational areas, the Bill contains consequential amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Public Service Act 1922. These amendments will ensure that income tax concessions on certain Commonwealth employees compensation payments, and certain conditions of appointment and employment in the Australian Public Service, apply to members of the Australian defence forces who serve or have served in these areas.

It is encouraging to the many veterans in my electorate to once again see that it is a Labor Government that is prepared to make these changes and to listen to what they have to say about veterans needs and in turn act upon their suggestions. These amendments mean that many veterans with assets above the assets threshold will either get more veterans entitlements or will qualify for the very first time. It is an appropriate response, I feel, to the needs of the veterans community at this time of very low interest rates.

As I mentioned in my introductory remarks, there are a large number of veterans and elderly people who live in my electorate. Obviously, it is a great place to live. So, with time on their hands, why not live on the far north coast of New South Wales. It is probably just a little bit better than the areas around the seat of Fadden, I might say.

—Good on you. It is a great place and I know the honourable member will appreciate its qualities. PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Berowra did make some comments—and I notice that he is back in the House now—about the situation with regard to the extension of those fringe benefits and the agreements with the States to have those fringe benefits available.

I might point out that one of the big bonuses of this decision was the extension to all part-pensioners of the reduction in municipal rates. With a slight indulgence on your part, Mr Deputy Speaker, I might also point out that this Friday, 14 May, is an important day for veterans in my electorate. It is anticipated that some 5,000 veterans, their families and friends, will come to Point Danger on the New South Wales-Queensland border to witness the unveiling of a monument to the tragic sinking of the Australian hospital ship Centaur. Concurrently with that unveiling, a walk of remembrance in memory of the lives lost through the sinking of 41 ships off the Australian coast will also be unveiled.

The Centaur was sunk off Stradbroke Island on the morning of 14 May 1943. I might point out to the House a small amount of history on this sinking. The ship was steaming north from Sydney on her second voyage to New Guinea as a hospital ship. On board were some 75 merchant navy crew, the ship's army medical staff, comprising eight officers, 12 nurses, and another 45 other ranks, and 192 members of the 2/12 Field Ambulance. The latter troops were passengers travelling to New Guinea to set up medical units in that country.

In the pre-dawn of the third day of that voyage north, whilst fully illuminated in accordance with the Geneva convention, a torpedo from the Japanese submarine I-177 struck the Centaur on its portside near its oil bunkers. A tremendous explosion rocked the ship and fire broke out. Most of the personnel at that time of the morning were sleeping and many were trapped when the ship foundered. Fewer than 100 found themselves floating on the surface when the ship disappeared.

It sunk in just a matter of minutes, and many of the people on board went down with the ship. A total of some 268 merchant navy seamen, army nurses and doctors, and members of the 2/12 Field Ambulance lost their lives. There were only 64 survivors. The torpedoing of the Centaur marked the greatest loss of lives ever in Australian waters. It was a tragedy that shocked the Australian nation.

All branches of the Australian military were involved in the tragedy or during the rescue of the Centaur survivors. The army was involved through its medical and ambulance units aboard the ship. The RAAF, with its Avro Anson patrol aircraft from Amberley airbase, was first to sight the 64 survivors on rafts and to radio the first news of the sinking. The RAN swept the area looking for survivors, with HMAS Lithgow and HMAS Echuca and the Fairmiles. The merchant navy manned the vessel, and our American allies on USS Mugford rescued the survivors. Fewer than 20 survivors remain today. Nine of these survivors will attend Friday's ceremony.

The Prime Minister at the time, John Curtin, was so disturbed by the sinking of the hospital ship Centaur he described it as `a deliberate, wanton act violating all principles of common humanity'. So it seems appropriate that our community is reminded of this tragedy of war.

I thank the Centaur commemoration committee, chaired by Mr Warren Keats and his secretary, Mr David Jeanes. Through their very hard work, we will have an inspirational reminder of this tragedy and other shipping tragedies off the coast of Australia.

On Friday, the people gathering, including the nine survivors of the Centaur tragedy, will see the fruits of the Centaur commemoration committee's work. It is a $110,000 monument pointing to the sea and the Centaur's grave, which is 47 nautical miles off the coast.

Thanks must go to Mr Keats, Mr Jeanes, and other members of the Centaur commemoration committee, including Donald Johnstone, Harold Wright, Alan Smith, Dee Searle, Elizabeth Randerson, Alan Hook, Harold Pearce, Esme Woodford, Ina Tranter, Graham Lapthorne, Ken Fulford and John Maher. They have all worked tirelessly. The committee's efforts have brought the tragedy of the sinking of the Centaur to the attention of the Australian community. This will be reinforced further this Friday with the unveiling of the monument by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner).

Funds have been raised through the sale of a book detailing the history of the ship. Fundraising concerts were held, and governments, private sponsors and individuals came to the committee's aid. The Commonwealth Government has donated $5,000 toward the project, and I am pleased to have been able to assist the committee in its efforts to secure this funding. The Centaur memorial will serve as a reminder to all Australians for many years to come of this tragedy.

The sacrifices made by our veterans, those who lost their lives in the Centaur, must be acknowledged by governments, and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 acknowledges the need for regular review of veterans entitlements. As well as extending veterans entitlements to those veterans previously ineligible as a result of existing means testing, it also extends those benefits under veterans affairs legislation to members of the Australian Defence Force serving with the United Nations peacekeeping forces in Somalia and the area comprising the former Yugoslavia.

Recently I had the privilege of travelling to Somalia with the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), Senator David MacGibbon and the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson). The Australian Defence Force has restored some order to Somalia and, in the process, earned the respect of the Somali people. I saw this first hand when visiting an orphanage in Baidoa where CARE Australia's acting team leader, Anne Morris, described the changes brought about by the presence of the Australian troops as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Baidoa is now a city of life instead of a city of death.
It is a very short statement, but anyone who has been to Baidoa and met the people—the troops, the caregivers and the local people—would understand exactly how significant that short statement is.

PARA.TAB: An interpreter in Baidoa, the son of the Baidoa chief elder, Ali Haji Mucketer, has said that the Australian troops were the only national force to live up to the title of the UN mission—Restore Hope. The people there do have hope for their future, but for many months they felt lost and did not have direction. They have been able to achieve that with the assistance of the Australian Defence Force, which certainly deserves our commendation. The Australian troops have proved themselves to be a professional force, although I was somewhat disturbed to hear reports of a lack of coordination by the United Nations of the initial relief efforts. To some extent there was evidence of that still going on when I was there just one month ago.

There is now some civil order in Somalia, but there remains no civil infrastructure. Whilst this Parliament has at times been described as containing a `rabble', if I could use that term, the Somali parliament building is itself rubble—a monument to the very hard task that country faces in its return to order. With the efforts of the Australian Defence Force and other personnel in that area there is certainly some hope and the people are looking forward to growth. This Government has, at the same time, wisely decided to stick to the timetable for the return of our troops. Some have returned home already; the rest will return home in a very short time.

This Bill also includes an amendment to extend operational service in Cambodia to areas in Laos and Thailand that are not more than 50 kilometres from the border with Cambodia. I commend this Government's clear commitment to the peace process in Cambodia and join with my colleague, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who made similar comments. Australia's contribution to the establishment of a means to conduct democratic elections has been acknowledged around the world and certainly heralds a new age of Australian diplomacy. This new diplomacy is not the manifestation of some quasi-British outpost; it is work that reflects Australia's position in the region—our regional priorities. It reflects our concern for our neighbours and our strengths as a nation ready to embark on its own course as a republic.

The financial implications of the Government's promise to reduce the assets test withdrawal rate amounts to some $6.5 million in 1993-94 and $8.3 million in 1995-96. The cost of providing the benefits for operational service in Somalia and the former Yugoslavia over the next three years are negligible, and the financial impact of this decision will not be very significant for the compensation component of the benefit. This is because the total number of service personnel involved in the area is relatively small. In relation to the provision of service pension benefits, virtually no costs will be incurred until these service personnel reach retirement age. There are no additional costs associated with the proposal to extend the area of operational service in Cambodia.

My constituents, particularly the veterans, are very pleased to express their gratitude for the extension of the fringe benefits assets test. I know that a number of people, particularly in my own town of Mullumbimby, now qualify for a part pension, and they are very pleased. I guess I should not get too particular about these things. I commend the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I congratulate you on your appointment. I have no problem with the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell) giving his Government a pat on the back for its actions in respect of the assets test, but it reflects on the unrealised capital gains on pensioners' share portfolios which not only impinges on this matter but also impinges to some extent on the Social Security Amendment Bill and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill we are debating concurrently tonight.

PARA.TAB: How will the honourable member react to pensioners—whether they be veteran or social security pensioners—who are making him aware of the effect that will have on their pensions? As I said in a debate here previously, the Government has got this completely wrong. It is totally beyond my comprehension that the Government cannot see that. To argue on some basis that it is consistent with the treatment of something else may be technically correct, but clearly the effect of this is disastrous for people who have shares. For instance, I do not know how a pensioner will live on a reduced pension in a situation where this mechanism applies. It is simply beyond my comprehension. Nobody has explained to me, or to anyone else, it seems, what pensioners will do for their weekly groceries when their pension is reduced. Do they take their share scrip down to the supermarket with them and say, `I'm sorry, I don't have any cash but my shares increased in value last year under this formula'—however it applies? It is beyond my comprehension.

The Parliamentary Secretary at the table, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), is obviously aware of the ramifications because he is not stupid. How far does this go? When will the Government start to value a pensioner's home or a pensioner's car on an annual basis? Why do we discriminate just against pensioners? Why do we not extend this unrealised capital gains situation to everybody?

TALK.START.PARA: —Careful, they will.
—The point is that this has horrific ramifications. I cannot see anything that commends that particular approach.
—Ever heard of equity?

—Certainly the uproar that it has created amongst pensioners and veterans eventually, hopefully, will get through to the back bench members of the Government so that some change can be made. I am very pleased that the Opposition has decided to move to repeal that particular provision as it is clearly wrong.

PARA.TAB: I take an interest in veterans affairs and had quite a number of matters to raise here tonight. Unfortunately, it is not worth making a start because of the way the Government is dealing with this legislation. I asked what was the point of the guillotine the other night. We are paid to come here to do a job. It is a job I take seriously. I take part in the debates, and I wanted to make a number of very important points about veterans and about this legislation, but it is clearly a waste of time because I will be cut off before I even get started. I will not even bother to deal with the matters I really wanted to raise.

The honourable member for Richmond talked about the Centaur. I will also be attending the ceremony on Friday. I am not sure where the memorial will be held, but it is close to the border of my electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister going?

—That is an interesting question. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was invited. As the honourable member for Richmond has correctly said, it is a very significant event—it was the biggest wartime loss of life in our country's history. The Prime Minister should be there. I observe in passing that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Faulkner, whom the Prime Minister is sending, has not made a very good start, but I do not have time to go into that. The Prime Minister should be there. He is probably not prepared to front veterans anywhere in this country as everything he has said has offended veterans.
—He does not have a very good knowledge of history.

—His knowledge of history is distorted. I think, in kindness, we could say that he has a distorted view of history after his comments about what happened in Singapore. The Centaur was sunk. It was lit up like a Christmas tree. It was the blatant act of the Japanese.
—Was there a flag on it?
—There was a cross along the side.

—It was clearly marked as a hospital ship. There were crosses along the side. It could not have been mistaken. When we talk about the Prime Minister's view of history, it also brings us back to the Singapore situation, which he has obviously misunderstood. I have just finished reading a book about the British role in the fall of Singapore. A lot of British soldiers died there. They defended the island, in the case of some units, to the last man. The Prime Minister denigrates the British activity there. In doing so, of course, he denigrates the efforts of the Australian 8th Division. Many Australians died defending Singapore.

PARA.TAB: Subsequently, of course, many became prisoners of war, and that brings to my mind the question of reparations. We talk about what the Japanese did to the Centaur. They murdered over 8,000 Australians prisoners of war on the Burma-Thailand railway. They treated our Australian prisoners of war deplorably. The books that I have read on it brought tears to my eyes; there is no other way to describe it. Many more British and Dutch prisoners of war were treated similarly and died in captivity. Reparations have never been made by the Japanese Government for that.

An issue for the Prime Minister if he wants to get into something that is of concern to veterans is to take up the matter of proper reparations for our living POWs—and I can assure the House that many of them at this stage, in the twilight years of their life, are only just living. But the Japanese Government has never made reparation. It has never apologised for what it did to Australian prisoners of war, most of whom became prisoners of war after the fall of Singapore, which I think was on 15 February 1942. There has never been an apology. There has never been any indication from the Japanese Government of what it did between 1942 and 1944 to Australian, British, Dutch and, indeed, Thai nationals—never any acknowledgment, never any proper reparations. I challenge the Prime Minister to take that on board.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I make those remarks in the context of the remarks you made about what happened to the Centaur. I am disappointed that the Prime Minister is not going to be at the unveiling on Friday. I really believe that he just does not take veterans seriously. They are not a big population these days; they are a diminishing population. There are 40,000 Vietnam veterans still alive in Australia—a significant number—and we are now, as has been noted tonight, giving veteran status to those who have served on various peacekeeping forces. In the context of this legislation, it is very correct that we should do so.

Overall, the veterans community is diminishing in number. The Prime Minister has managed to offend them so easily and almost, one imagines, purposely. He does not seem to think that they matter in political terms. They certainly matter to me and tonight I wanted to take up a number of matters but, as I say, very little time has been set aside for this debate and I am very disappointed about that.

I was also disappointed that the honourable member for Richmond criticised the United Nations effort in Cambodia. Things are never perfect in these operations. I note that he had the opportunity to observe that operation in Somalia; as most honourable members know, I saw it in Bosnia. It is not perfect. It is very difficult for the UN to operate in those circumstances, not the least reason being that there is a full-scale civil war going on in Bosnia, as there is in Somalia, and the job of the United Nations in distributing aid is made very difficult because of that. So I would not be too harsh in my criticism of the UN. My observation, as I say, of it in Bosnia was that it fell very short of being perfect, but they were doing their very best in extremely difficult circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the spirit of the cognate debate on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, I want to make some comments about the Government's quite extraordinary decision to include unrealised capital gain in the pensioner income test. It is perfectly reasonable to include the value of shares in an assets test. Indeed, that happens, and so also should any capital gain be included in that assets test, but most observers regard it as absolutely unconscionable to include in an income test capital gain which may or may not ever actually be realised. Those who have their pensions cut as a result of these new provisions will not be able to access their unrealised capital gain to meet their day-to-day expenses, pay rent, buy groceries or clothing. One simply cannot live on unrealised income.

PARA.TAB: There is also widespread criticism that the Government has decided to arbitrarily value all shares as at a predetermined date rather than recognise their real purchase cost. This decision means that many pensioners will be assessed as having received a capital gain when, in reality, the value of their share portfolio could actually be lower than its purchase price. The Government also fails to take into account any administrative costs associated with maintaining a share portfolio. The Government introduced deeming provisions in an attempt to maximise pensioners' income.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it worked.

—I say to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security: if the Government really believes that, why on earth does it now introduce measures which will reduce pensioners' actual incomes by encouraging them—indeed, forcing many pensioners—to actually dispose of their shares? They may even be required to dispose of their shares at a capital loss, putting them at an increasing disadvantage personally, resulting in a greater dependence on our nation's welfare system.

PARA.TAB: I have written to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) and the Parliamentary Secretary replied. A number of the excuses that he put up for this quite indefensible action seemed to me to be extraordinary. The first was: it is designed to simplify the social security income test. How on earth can the Parliamentary Secretary justify that? The administration of this new system is extremely complex. It will involve thousands of calculations and the employment of scores of extra bureaucrats. If that is the way the Government intends to simplify the system, it has certainly got the numbers wrong. The Parliamentary Secretary also says the test is fairer. What is fair about this particular system? The capital gain on shares is to be taken into account, but a multi-million dollar house on the North Shore of Sydney with enormous unrealised capital gain is not taken into account. Shares only have been singled out for this unfair treatment. The test will be made more unfair, not fairer.

He then goes on to say that unrealised capital gain on shares reduces the real need of a person for social security assistance. What absolute rubbish. People cannot live on unrealised capital gain, they cannot buy food with unrealised capital gain. Yet under this Government they are required to do so.

Then he said that the reduction in the pension by the Government will be offset by the extension of eligibility to fringe benefits. But that is available to everyone, irrespective of whether they have shares. So in no way is that compensation for this particular group of people. The Government's action is unjust. It should support the Opposition's private member's Bill to repeal this section.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF THE SEA (OIL POLLUTION COMPENSATION FUND) BILL 1993

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
PROTECTION OF THE SEA (IMPOSITION OF CONTRIBUTIONS TO OIL POLLUTION COMPENSATION FUND—GENERAL) BILL 1993
PROTECTION OF THE SEA (IMPOSITION OF CONTRIBUTIONS TO OIL POLLUTION COMPENSATION FUND—CUSTOMS) BILL 1993
PROTECTION OF THE SEA (IMPOSITION OF CONTRIBUTIONS TO OIL POLLUTION COMPENSATION FUND—EXCISE) BILL 1993]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Mr O'Keefe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are having yet another in the series of debates that we have had in this House over the last couple of years relating to the potential of the shipping industry to pollute the sea. As has been the case with similar legislation in the past few years, the Opposition will support the Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Bill.

PARA.TAB: At the commencement of this debate it is worth making the point that in the life of the last Parliament the Opposition, without exception, supported all reasonable endeavours by this Government to do the right thing to protect our maritime environment and to ensure that potential damage and the costs involved can be minimised. All honourable members would recognise the potential for damage if an accident were to happen at sea in which a large quantity of oil was lost and that oil floated around in the ocean until such time as it either destroyed sea life or washed up on the coast and destroyed the coastal life and the potential tourism income generated by that coastal life. This Bill is part of the process of trying to correct the potential losses of a ship disappearing and the oil spilling into the ocean and doing tremendous damage.

I am reminded of a number of attempts over the years to minimise potential damage. One that immediately springs to mind and has been brought to my attention in the last few days was the Government's legislation for compulsory pilotage through the Great Barrier Reef. The Opposition supported that legislation. Indeed I spoke, and the then honourable member for Pearce, Fred Chaney, also spoke as our shadow Minister for the environment at the time, supporting the legislation. That legislation would have added costs to the operation of ships through that part of the world, but we supported it and the industry supported it because we recognised the importance of ensuring that everything possible was done to protect from any damage one of Australia's greatest natural assets, namely, our Great Barrier Reef.

The application of that legislation is now well and truly a part of life. Now, all ships that travel through the Great Barrier Reef have a pilot on board; somebody who is expert in the ways of the Great Barrier Reef, who understands the ins and outs and can skilfully steer those ships through the reef. As a result, we have not had any accidents and, hopefully, that will be the case in future. The Opposition supported that initiative at the time.

In recent days we have been urging the Government to do whatever it can to investigate every possibility of ships avoiding passage through the reef. A number of arguments suggest that the Great Barrier Reef is the safest way for ships to get from the north to the south of the east coast of Australia and that putting ships outside the reef places them in greater danger because, in many instances, the waters are uncharted and the seas more dangerous.

The barrier reef itself is a very safe place to travel through, as long as one knows one's way and is careful and diligent. Putting ships through that passage can be much safer than putting them outside the reef where they have to travel in more dangerous waters. Also, the currents and winds that operate in that part of the world are such that if a ship did go down outside the reef, the oil would be carried onto the reef and probably cover a larger section of the reef than would otherwise have been the case had the ship gone down inside the reef.

Whilst old salts argue to maintain shipping passage through the reef, in recent weeks I have been urging the Government to look at every possibility of taking ships outside the reef if it can be proved that this would make it safer and reduce the risk to our Great Barrier Reef. At the same time, I have been urging the Government to ensure that we have the speediest and the most effective means of dealing with any accidents that may occur not only in the Great Barrier Reef but anywhere around Australia's very large coastline.

The Australian Maritime Safety Authority has a number of depots around Australia in various port authorities where there is on-site equipment to deal with oil spills. However, it is questionable whether we can deal with a major oil spill regardless of the equipment located at various destinations around Australia. So in the last few weeks I have been calling on the Government to re-evaluate the potential damage and our ability to respond to any eventuality on the Australian coastline if a ship were to go down.

All honourable members would remember the Kirki that went down off the west coast of Australia not so long ago. On that occasion we were just lucky. On other occasions the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), who will shortly speak in this debate, has spoken about the sinking of the Kirki. When that ship sank we were very lucky indeed. The oil broke up and evaporated, the winds were favourable and the oil did not blow onto the coast. Generally speaking, on that occasion we got off very lightly. But had the circumstances been different a major slice of our western coastline would have been damaged, which would have caused all Australians a great deal of concern. So on the basis that we have been lucky to date, we cannot presume that we will be lucky forever. It is important for this Government to ensure that we have the best possible means of responding in the best possible fashion to very large oil spills.

We also supported legislation that went through in the life of the last Parliament dealing with such things as the possibility of oil being discharged into the ocean, what quantities of oil can be mixed with water and so forth. We also supported legislation relating to the dumping of ballast water in Australian waters and the need to improve the various means by which ships get rid of their ballast water.

It is worth while remembering that ships often come to Australia empty in order to pick up a load and, in order to travel safely and efficiently, they fill their holds with sea water. That helps the ships to travel properly. On many occasions they pick up that sea water in an Asian port. When they get to Australia they deposit their ballast, and along with it various organisms, sea life and so forth. There has been evidence to suggest that this is having a damaging effect on some aspects of our marine life, and legislation that came through this House during the last Parliament designed to minimise the potential damage was also supported by the coalition on that occasion.

Whilst the coalition has been keen to support these types of responsible legislation, so too has the Australian shipping industry. I have found that on matters such as this our maritime industry has in the past acted, and is now acting, in a most responsible fashion. Indeed, in many cases it has initiated the measures taken over the last few years to minimise potential damage. Whilst congratulating the Government and ourselves for being prepared to initiate and support these types of measures, it is also important to recognise the role of the maritime industries in Australia that have also participated in a very responsible way in dealing with these problems.

It is also worth our while to remember that many places in Australia could be damaged by an oil spill—not just the Great Barrier Reef. We often hear people—and I am probably as guilty as anybody else—talking about the potential damage that can occur to Australia as a result of a large tanker spilling its oil into the sea. We often relate that potential experience to the Great Barrier Reef. But it is not just the Great Barrier Reef that tankers travel through and where serious damage can occur.

I am reminded of Port Phillip Bay—a rather insular maritime environment which is not flushed out by the ocean on a daily basis. Indeed, if an accident were to occur in Port Phillip Bay it would be very difficult to deal with because those waters are not replenished from the ocean on a regular basis. So an accident in Port Phillip Bay would be of a very serious magnitude to the economy of that part of Australia and also of course to the maritime environment. Let us not fall into the trap of using examples relating only to the Great Barrier Reef when we talk of the possibility of damage to the ocean.

This legislation is designed to deal with some of the financial aspects of an oil spill. This legislation establishes a fund to insure against the costs related to an oil spill in our waters. Of course, when there is an accident at sea and a tanker goes down, the costs involved in cleaning up the mess are horrific. Many millions of dollars are involved in mopping up the oil, trying to make it disperse and trying to get rid of it so that it does not affect our maritime environment.

But there is also another cost involved in this type of accident which occurs in the form of losses in potential revenue by people affected by that spill. For example, if an accident were to occur on the Great Barrier Reef, tourist operators would obviously experience financial loss as a result of the bad publicity generated by the oil spill. Under this proposal, those people would be able to claim—for the first time as far as I can recall—against this insurance fund which is being set up to deal with the potential loss of revenue that they might experience as a result of an oil tanker breaking up and spilling its oil.

This legislation should be welcomed by tourist operators, fishermen and other people who draw their income, in one form of another, from a maritime area which may be damaged as a result of an oil spill. This is good legislation, firstly, because it does that for the first time. Secondly, the insurance fund that Australia is participating in as a result of the implementation of this legislation also covers Australia for the cost of recovering the oil that is lost at sea and for the cost of cleaning up the mess. So there are two sides to this legislation.
Mr Peacock interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad the honourable member for Kooyong has come into the House because he has something that will be quite interesting to the House which I will mention in a few moments. This legislation covers not only the cost of cleaning up the damage but also any financial losses that are incurred by third parties.

PARA.TAB: This insurance fund will be run through the International Maritime Organisation and Australia will have a representative on the council. The premiums will be paid by oil companies receiving approximately 150,000 tonnes or more of oil per annum. These companies will pay the premiums and, if my memory serves me correctly, that will total about $95,000 for Australia this year. However, in the second year it will increase to about $500,000.

Nine companies in Australia import more than 150,000 tonnes of oil per annum. Those companies have been acting in a voluntary scheme to insure against the sorts of losses and costs that I have already referred to. On their own volition, these nine companies have been participating in this voluntary scheme by paying premiums to insure against any possible losses. That scheme will be wound up in February of next year. This legislation is before the House today to ensure that Australia and Australian oil companies are not left in the position of having no insurance against the cost of oil spills.

A few moments ago I mentioned that that noted environmentalist, the honourable member for Kooyong, had come into the House. He has a particular interest in this debate because he has a world-first which I am sure he would like to speak about. He has demonstrated to me a product which can clean up—in an unbelievable way—any oil spilled in water. I am sure that if the opportunity is made available to him he will speak on it; but I have not seen anything like it in my life.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'd like to demonstrate it.

—He would like to demonstrate it. Indeed, if he had the equipment here we could immediately go through the process in a Barry Jones-style demonstration in the House. But he did demonstrate this product for me in his office the other day. When certain material is put on top of oil floating on water it literally lifts the oil out, leaving none in the water. It is the most amazing thing I have ever seen in my life and unless I had seen it with my own eyes I would not have believed it. I think the honourable member for Kooyong is onto a winner. I am sure that he will not have to depend upon his parliamentary superannuation to sustain him in a proper fashion in his post-political career because if he goes out and markets this product he will be a very wealthy man indeed. I hope that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority and other people with an interest in this area will take up the opportunity, as I did last week, of seeing the honourable member for Kooyong in action demonstrating his world-first product. I hope that this free plug bears some fruit for the honourable member for Kooyong.
—I hope it is not a joint venture with Elders.

—No, it is not a joint venture with Elders. Indeed, I am hoping that, out of the goodness of his heart, I might be on some sort of a commission here tonight. Its effectiveness will not be believed until it is seen first-hand. I am sure that, with his entrepreneurial skills, the honourable member for Kooyong will make it a very successful product indeed.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate the industry for being involved in this voluntary scheme. The oil companies have shown themselves to be good citizens in the way they have involved themselves in that scheme and in the way in which they are prepared to participate in this compulsory scheme the Government is now establishing through legislation. The Opposition will support the Bill for those reasons. We support it because we honestly take a sincere interest in doing everything we can to ensure that our maritime environment is as safe as possible for those who travel in it; that the risks of damage occurring are minimised; and that, if damage does occur, the cost to this nation is as minimal as possible.

This legislation fits within those guidelines and the Opposition is very happy to support it. Our shadow Minister for the environment, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), will also be speaking in this debate. For that reason, I will sit down now and give her sufficient time to speak. The Opposition supports this legislation because it protects our marine environment in one way or the other. For that reason we are happy to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on these Bills, and I am also pleased to learn that the Opposition will be supporting them. Indeed, it could hardly do otherwise. I make the point that on many of the shipping measures that have been in this House there has been bipartisan support. I only wish that bipartisan support could extend as far as cabotage, but maybe that would be pushing my luck a little too far. As has been said, the purpose of these Bills is to give effect to the International Convention on the Establishment of an International Fund for Compensation for Oil Pollution and the protocols of 1976 and 1992 amending the fund convention.

PARA.TAB: The Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Bill will require persons who receive in Australia, or in a Territory of Australia, by sea more than 150,000 tonnes of crude oil or fuel oil in a calendar year to contribute to a fund established under the fund convention. The Bill distinguishes between the two funds, the 1971 fund and the protocol of the 1992 fund established by the fund convention after it was further amended by the 1992 protocol. Both the 1971 fund and the 1992 fund will pay compensation for pollution caused by oil where the pollution resulted from an incident involving one or more ships.

In addition, the 1971 fund will indemnify shipowners for a part of their liability to pay compensation for oil pollution under the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority is required to provide information to the Director of the International Oil Pollution Compensation Fund, which is a United Kingdom based organisation established to manage the compensation regime, about persons who receive crude oil or fuel oil in Australia by sea, and the quantities received, in order to determine the liability of these persons to make contributions to the fund. Regulations may be made under the proposed Act to require persons who receive crude oil or fuel oil to provide information and documentation to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority.
The other three Bills impose contributions required to be made by the Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Bill.

For far too long Australia has regarded itself as isolated from major oil spills. I put to this House that the fact that the Australian coastline has not been polluted has been through good luck rather than good planning or good management.

As was mentioned by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) the pollution incident involving the tanker Kirki off the Western Australian coast in 1991 clearly demonstrated that Australia cannot be considered immune from large tanker spills. Had the Kirki been a total loss—and as he so rightly said, it was just good luck that there was not a massive loss—the damage claim could easily have exceeded existing compensation limits. Had the oil spill been as great as its potential, the crayfishing industry in the whole of Western Australia could have been wiped out.

Given the condition of many foreign flagships operating off the Australian coastline, I believe it is not a case of if but when the Australian coastline will be impacted by a major oil spill. Given the fact that most of the oil transported to Australia travels through our major tourist attraction, the Great Barrier Reef, it should be a matter of concern to all Australians. It is indeed a matter of concern to most Australians except, it appears, the environmental movement. During the inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure that led to the Ships of shame report, despite being contacted personally by me—I contacted every major environmental group in Australia and invited each to put in a submission—no environmental group thought oil pollution was worthy of its attention. The environmentalists think there is more publicity in hugging a few gum trees than there is in seriously facing up to the two major environmental pollution problems of Australia: land degradation and the threat to the marine environment.

Members of the committee of inquiry into ship safety were amazed at the condition of many foreign flagships coming to Australia. I hope, as a matter of urgency, the Government adopts the recommendations contained in that report.

That report has been hailed throughout the world as a landmark report but, if there was a shortcoming in the report, it was that, purely because of time constraints, there was not enough attention paid to oil carriers. That committee has been re-formed, under the able chairmanship of my friend and colleague the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), who is with us here. I happen to have also scored a place on the new committee. We have our first meeting tomorrow. Now that the committee has been re-formed with that high powered membership, I will be pushing for a further inquiry dealing just with oil tankers and oil pollution. There have been several seminars on this topic over recent years but no full inquiry. A full inquiry into oil tankers and oil spills is long overdue.

I listened with considerable interest to what the preceding speaker, the honourable member for Hume, said about ships travelling inside or outside the Great Barrier Reef. I am very much in favour of travelling inside the reef, for the very reasons that he mentioned. It is a safer passage. It is a well designated passage, and the sea is much calmer. That passage is also much cheaper. I worry that, if the ships went outside the reef, they would be in more uncharted waters. They would be in rougher waters and if there was an accident I think there would be greater environmental damage done.

Often people stand up in this House and say that there is compulsory pilotage through the Great Barrier Reef. There is only compulsory pilotage through part of the Great Barrier Reef, and that is the very northern part. There is no compulsory pilotage through the main tourist part at all.

The condition of many ships visiting Australia is an international disgrace: huge tankers, with poorly trained crews, lack of adequate language communication between bridge and rating—this is an issue that many people say was a cause of the Shetland disaster late last year—underpaid and undertrained crews. There are also too many greedy profiteers who see nothing wrong with putting our pristine coastline at risk in the never ending search for the quick dollar.

I support this legislation, but the answer to oil pollution is not compensation. How could the farmers or the tourist industry of the Shetlands ever be compensated for what happened there late last year? There must be much stricter control of shipping, much tighter inspections, much better training, better policed international conventions, all as recommended in the report Ships of shame.

However, I would like to point out that, as the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has said, compensation is not the answer when our environment is under threat. Our environment certainly is under threat from the oil tankers that circumnavigate Australia and the globe. Australia cannot compare with other waters, for instance the Mediterranean and the Middle East seas, with the amount of oil that is shipped, but certainly there is a considerable amount that goes past what are incredibly fragile and sensitive areas of our coastline. I read from Transport of hydrocarbons in the oil and gas industry the extent of this. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: these are the most recent figures I could find—

domestic coastal shipping carried approximately 17 million tonnes of crude and refined petroleum products around Australia. Coastal shipping carried the third largest share of hydrocarbons and is responsible for hauling tonnages nearly five times greater than those handled by rail.

This is a considerable tonnage going around our shores. Since World War II the size of tankers has grown considerably. At the end of World War II tankers were carrying about 10,000 dead weight tonnes; that is now up to 300,000 dead weight tonnes. If we think of the size of those tankers, what would happen to our coastline if there were an accident? We speak of the Exxon Valdez and the damage that it did to the Alaskan coastline, but that only let out 36,000 tonnes of crude oil. So we can imagine the damage that one of these very large tankers, coming down the Australian coastline with the amount of oil that they carry, would do to our beaches, our mangroves and our reef—a particularly sensitive area.

PARA.TAB: This danger is not just remote but very real. Accidents in Australian waters are rare, but they do happen. In a seven-year period between 1981 and 1987, there were 24 shipping accidents. Of those, 12 were groundings and seven were as a result of collisions. These incidents, fortunately, did not happen to oil tankers, but the potential for enormous damage was there. There was a warning when the Kirki disaster took place off the Western Australian coast. It is interesting that, when the Kirki started to break up, its bow—which was so rusted—actually fell off.

The oil fleet that is currently sailing around the world is ageing. The average age of a very large crude oil tanker is 13.2 years. On the estimates, no tanker should be allowed to sail after 15 years, yet here we have these very large oil tankers circumnavigating the globe with an average age of 13.2 years—some being considerably older than that. So there is enormous potential for an accident to happen off our coast.

The Opposition naturally supports this Bill. It would support anything that gives compensation for an accident. But compensation is not the answer. The Bill limits compensation to half a billion dollars. The cost of the Exxon Valdez disaster was $1 billion. That gives us an idea of the mess we could find ourselves in. That amount was just for the clean-up. When we get economic compensation and everything else, that money is by far exceeded. So there is no way that the compensation fund could cope with a massive oil disaster, although it would cover small ones.

We can all appreciate the effect of a small tanker disaster on the reef or on beaches, but there is also the potential effect of a disaster on the reputation of the reef. The reef at the moment supports a $1.6 billion tourist industry. Any damage or any suggestion of damage to the reef will keep away some of those tourists. The honourable member for Throsby, who followed the honourable member for Hume, referred to some consideration being given to shipping outside the reef. Both honourable members said that, because of a number of factors, this was perhaps not as favourable an idea as it may at first seem: it is calmer within the reef waters and the currents outside the reef would drive any oil spill onto the reef.

Be that as it may, I point out to the honourable member for Throsby that no study has yet been done of these factors. The Great Barrier Marine Park Authority is very keen to do such a study: to work out the danger to the reef from ships taking either a course inside the reef or a course outside the reef. The plain truth is that the money has not been given to the authority; it does not have the money to do the study at present. It is somewhat appalling, when we consider that there is a $1.6 billion tourist industry based on the reef, that we have not yet done that study to consider whether those ships should be travelling outside the reef or within the reef waters.

Other things need to be done to protect the reef. There needs to be a new navigation system for ships. The workshop that was held to consider the danger from oil spills on the reef decided that the main danger was from navigation. The Exxon Valdez disaster was caused by human error to do with navigation. The captain was not on the deck. The officer misread his directions and landed up on a reef. That could happen in Australian waters, especially on the Great Barrier Reef, where there are many difficult channels to negotiate. All the ships that go through the reef should have an electronic mapping system and the DGPS, the differential global positionary system, which the Government has not afforded to the ships that come through the reef. This high priority and inexpensive system uses satellites to locate the position of a ship. Once the electronic mapping which can be obtained from the Department of Defence is in place, every ship can see where it is in relation to the reef. That should be obligatory for ships of all sizes going through the reef.

I very much support this Bill, but I point out that there is a major likelihood of an accident on the reef that has not been catered for. I believe it is up to the Government to spend more than it is at present to care for the reef and to make sure that these spills do not happen. Should a large spill occur, the compensation fund is not enough in itself to cover the cost of the clean-up and the economic damage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join in this debate on the Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Bill, the Protection of the Sea (Imposition of Contributions to Oil Pollution Compensation Fund—General) Bill, the Protection of the Sea (Imposition of Contributions to Oil Pollution Compensation Fund—Customs) Bill and the Protection of the Sea (Imposition of Contributions to Oil Pollution Compensation Fund—Excise) Bill.
