PARA.TAB: The question of the Great Barrier Reef is one that is constantly put to us. The practice of vessels travelling inside the reef and the reasons have been explained to us. But it also needs to be emphasised that 80 per cent of the vessels passing through the Great Barrier Reef are bound for North Queensland ports. So it is not simply a matter of putting vessels outside the reef. It is a matter that needs to be taken into consideration.

In this package of Bills, we are dealing with what we do after an accident has occurred. We really need to do more about preventing the event occurring. A lot more emphasis needs to be given to prevention. Four out of five shipping incidents are the result of human behaviour, caused by a number of things: lack of attention, fatigue, sheer incompetence, and a lack of application to duty. The inquiry of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, the report of which is entitled Ships of shame: inquiry into ship safety, found one factor to be the condition of vessels. Also, not nearly enough is being done to ensure that people serving on the vessels do have the necessary competence; that their qualifications are genuine; and that the management of the vessel does lend itself to the safe operation of the vessel.

It is interesting that only about 15 per cent of tankers in the world are owned by oil companies; they have moved out of ownership of the vessels. Some 85 per cent of the independent tankers belong to an organisation called Intertanker, which is trying to clean up the game and to ensure the vessels it is operating are in good condition and crewed competently.

When talking about prevention, preparedness and clean-up, we need to recognise that only about eight per cent of oil spilled at sea is ever recovered; so it is very much a cosmetic operation. A lot is said about the recovery of oil, but the reality is that only about eight per cent of it is recovered. The rest disperses, depending upon the nature of the oil, depending upon the circumstances in which the oil is lost, the temperature of the water and the weather conditions. We need to understand that some 1,305 million tonnes of oil was moved around the globe in 1992. Some 3,250 vessels are engaged in the trade. It was put to us in the course of our committee inquiry that some 20 per cent of the tankers plying for hire do not meet international standards. That figure is accepted generally around the world. I go to the words of the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). The report entitled Ships of shame: inquiry into ship safety and its recommendations have been widely accepted and welcomed across the world. Australia has been commended for the leadership it has given on this issue. However, the issue has to be crew competency and effective inspections of vessels.

The Government is stepping up vessel inspections. If the countries—maritime nations and flag states—that register these vessels do not carry out their obligations, one thing is certain: other nations will go it alone and impose their own requirements, as the United States has done, particularly with the proposed provisions of the Oil Protection Act, OPA. The committee heard a great deal about those provisions, and the onerous nature of them. While the US Coast Guard and the other parties involved have not yet determined the rules of the OPA, there is a fair bit of clamour going on that exaggerates the imposition of provisions upon tanker operators and people transporting oil.

As I have said, the actual rules that will apply under that Act have not yet been determined. The negotiation process is still going on. Part of the process is the recognition that there should be a certificate of financial responsibility signed by the oil companies, or the tanker owners, transporting the oil. The result of all this could be perverse because the conditions require a level of financial responsibility that is difficult to provide for, whether through contracts, insurance, protection indemnity clubs, or whatever financial provisions or guarantees are available. While it is still too early to be proven, it has been asserted that the result will be that the better tankers—particularly from those companies with assets in the United States—will steer away from the United States because they do not want to be caught up in any action if the unthinkable should happen.

While we need to follow those developments closely, the important thing for Australia is to ensure that the tankers coming into our ports are up to the standards required under the international maritime conventions—and that relates to the inspection process, which is being stepped up here. It is also important to ensure that the crews have the required competency.

As I said earlier, four out of five incidents at sea result from human error, not vessel failure. A good crew can save a bad ship but a bad crew can destroy a good ship. While the Aegean Sea incident—which resulted in a vessel running aground, catching fire and destroying an area on the coast of Spain—may have been the result of mechanical failure, the incident involving the Maersk navigator occurred in circumstances one would have thought impossible: a new tanker and a 16-year-old tanker colliding in a wide-open stretch of water 40 miles from the nearest land. The background to that incident has yet to be proven but that is the thing that we have to concentrate on: ensuring that people are competent and that they can carry out their responsibilities.

I have a concern about going to increasingly sophisticated technology when it is evident, from our general inquiry, that crews cannot read and understand even the older technology on vessels. There is not much point having stress gauges and other sophisticated equipment when crews cannot read the language. That is not exaggerating the situation.

In the time available in this very important debate I want to emphasise that we have to concentrate on people. We were greatly heartened by the very strong and favourable response from the rest of the shipping world to the recommendations we put to the Parliament in our Ships of shame report. Intertanker's letter to the committee, which, as I mentioned, will be tabled tomorrow, states:

have made for the report, and for the very balanced and reasonable conclusions you have drawn.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF THE SEA (IMPOSITION OF CONTRIBUTIONS TO OIL POLLUTION COMPENSATION FUND—GENERAL) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Mr O'Keefe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Exxon Valdez incident in Alaska in 1989 caused the Australian oil industry to look very closely at the offshore transportation of oil. The industry concluded that the existing system and arrangements for controlling a major oil spill should be considerably upgraded. A working group was established within the Australian Institute of Petroleum, AIP, to examine the problem and to make recommendations. The major recommendation was to form the Australian Marine Oil Spill Centre as a wholly owned subsidiary of AIP. The Australian Marine Oil Spill Centre was opened on 5 June 1992 at Corio Quay near Geelong. Appropriately enough, 5 June 1992 was World Environment Day.

PARA.TAB: AMOSC is a world-class oil spill response and training facility. It cost the industry, through 12 participating companies, $10 million to establish. It is financed by the industry. An allocation of $9 million is directed towards materials and equipment. It has the equipment and training personnel to respond to an oil spill of up to 10,000 tonnes. Annual operating costs are in the region of $750,000.

It will be of interest to honourable members to know that AMOSC is on call 24 hours a day and can be at the scene of an incident anywhere off Australia's coast within 12 to 16 hours. Corio Quay in Victoria was chosen because of its good waterside facilities and its close links with air and road transport facilities. Geelong is close to Avalon and Tullamarine airports. I understand that another major factor in the siting of AMOSC was that Geelong is almost at the dead centre of oil movements around the Australian coast. AMOSC can respond to a spill in a wide area of the South Pacific—as far away as Tahiti—if required. Obviously, that area includes New Guinea and New Zealand.

AMOSC complements the oil spill response facilities already provided by the oil companies. There is now a total of $1.6 million worth of equipment in some 60 oil ports around Australia. This expenditure was another recommendation of the working group under the auspices of the AIP which actually recommended the establishment of AMOSC. It set out to tackle the problem of oil spills on a number of fronts. The $1.6 million worth of equipment allows those oil ports to cope with small or moderate spills in their immediate region. AMOSC, however, is a very large and centrally located facility, and it was established to respond to a major spill anywhere off the coast. It is a national facility.

The centre is heavily involved in the training of government personnel on spill and control techniques, and up to 300 government personnel attend training courses each year. The equipment at the centre is the best currently available anywhere in the world. The AMOSC team is highly trained and motivated. Many if not all, as expected, have a strong marine background with personnel being drawn from different parts of the world.

The risk of a major oil spill around Australia's coast is not great. I do not say that with any sense of complacency, nor would the industry, as evidenced by its establishment of AMOSC. There is a remarkable safety record. In the past 30 years over three billion barrels of oil have been produced and more than a thousand wells drilled. Over this time, the total amount of oil spilt offshore is 440 barrels.

As most honourable members would know, the citrus industry is facing a very serious situation with the price of citrus going down to only $45 to $50 a tonne. PARA.TAB: Many of the citrus growers are hedging their trees, or pulling the trees, because they believe that there is no way they can make a living at those prices. The problem is caused by the glut of citrus on the world market, and particularly with the frozen concentrated orange juice that is coming from Brazil. That country has over-produced and has caused a glut on the market. Although Australia produces only two-thirds of its needs, that low price is affecting not only the concentrated juice market in Australia but also the fresh juice market and the market that is being prepared for export. This is a tremendous problem.

People might say, `What is the present situation in regard to picking the valencia crop that has just finished?'. Valencias have to be picked and it costs up to $45 or $50 a tonne to pick them. If the growers are getting only to $45 to $50 a tonne from the processors for their produce, we can see that the other things such as water, sprays and other agricultural pursuits cannot be paid for, and this is placing the citrus growers in a terrible situation.

Before the recent federal election the coalition was pressing for the establishment of a task force similar to that set for the sugar industry to look into the citrus industry. The purpose of the task force was to see what could be done about the last harvest, and also to look at the future of the citrus industry. The coalition is not in government, but the present Government has set up a horticultural industry task force with a smaller committee to look at the problems of the citrus industry.

That task force is being headed by Senator Nick Sherry. He will be in some of the citrus areas next week, and I hope that he has wide and extensive talks there. He will be in Mildura and the Riverland, but unfortunately he is not coming to the MIA at this stage. This task force is supposed to report in six months time. Many of the citrus growers agree with me that this is just too long a period. I ask the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) whether the committee cannot bring in an interim report before the navel season comes in so that the growers at least have some hope for that crop. The tragedy with the valencias is that they have to be picked for the good of the trees, and also because we have problems in the area with fruit fly and other pests.

The interim report would be handy because that would give the citrus growers some hope and they would know where they were going. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Minister for seeing the Australian Citrus Growers Federation for talks before the federal election. Unfortunately those talks did not turn out as well as we might have hoped, and the ACGF would like to speak to the Minister again. After the visit of Nick Sherry to Mildura and the Riverland, I ask whether the Minister would take on notice the request of the citrus growers to meet with him, because I think it is very important that he understands exactly what the situation is. The welfare of those towns and villages and the areas where citrus is grown is very dependent on the citrus growers, and those who have not a diversified agricultural production find it extremely difficult. I ask the Government to take this matter seriously. I am pleased that the task force has been set up. I ask that the task force put in an interim report before the navel crop comes off. I also ask the Minister to meet the ACGF.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to mention a few things that affect my electorate, and therefore they will range over a large area. First of all, I would like to mention the Premier of Victoria, one Jeffrey Kennett, and what he has done to the residents of the electorate of Dunkley and all surrounding electorates. One of the appalling things that he has done is place a $100 land tax on everyone who owns a rateable property in Victoria. It is a tax that goes right across the board. If one lives in a million dollar house one pays $100; if one lives in a ministry of housing house one pays $100. It is a poll tax that has been imposed on the Victorian people because of Jeffrey Kennett's own blinkered view that he has to attack the average person in Victoria. He has increased fares on trains, buses and all public transport. He has cut down pensioner benefits for pensioner week. How mean can anyone be, to actually cut out free travel on trains and trams during pensioner week?

PARA.TAB: He has closed schools around our area, he has increased the size of classes, he has cut down on maintenance and he has sacked thousands of teachers. He is now after thousands of nurses. Things needed in the electorate of Dunkley that have not been addressed in the last two years include a child-care facility in the Chelsea Heights area. I will be lobbying hard to ensure that this child-care facility is built. I am writing to the Springvale council at this very moment to try and make certain that they assist the Chelsea Heights community centre to get a child-care centre.

Frankston Hospital is the major hospital on the peninsula and the casualty section is a disgrace. It must be upgraded. During the election campaign I went there with the former Minister for Health, the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe). We saw young children mixed in with the victims of road traffic accidents. TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to inform this House of a project in my electorate that has succeeded in developing in our children an appreciation of the uniqueness of Australia's flora and fauna. One of the most satisfying aspects of being a member of parliament is being able to witness the evolution of a local project into a valued community resource. The Cheltenham primary school flora and fauna sanctuary is one such project.

PARA.TAB: This project was initiated by Mr Jim Griffin, and principal, Mr Kim Brownbill. A support group known as the friends of Cheltenham primary school sanctuary group was convened. Parents, interested members of the community and of course children of the school are active participants. Over $7,000 has been raised via school fetes, grants and donations. The goal of the project is to foster in the community the knowledge, skills and motivation required to protect and conserve the environment.

To this end, a short story competition was conducted as an exercise in teaching the children how to express their feelings about the sanctuary. Over 70 per cent of the students at Cheltenham primary school participated and the winner, 11-year-old Christie Melissartos, won under the general category entitled `What the children saw as the value of the sanctuary'. Christie wrote:
Our sanctuary provides many things for us, and the native animals around us. It gives animals like possums, birds, foxes, bats and blue tongue lizards homes in their own environment.

The sanctuary also provides fresh air for us and a nice environment with all the native trees and plants around us. The sanctuary helps us learn about animals and plants of our area which is good for school projects.
We are quite lucky to have a sanctuary and that it was given to us to be part of our school by the Government.

I mostly like our sanctuary because it gives shelter for the animals and right now, we have to do as we can for them. It is important to have a sanctuary so it can keep growing and providing for us year after year for the animals in the environment and us.
In 50 years time I hope our sanctuary would have improved with all our help and most of all, I hope it is still there.

SPEECH.PARA: I know my colleagues will join with me in congratulating Christie and Cheltenham primary school on their efforts in making sure young Australians are aware of the environment in which they live.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a number of concerns tonight about the operation of the Civil Aviation Authority. I believe this authority has been floundering for some time and I think it is time that the Government took some strong action in that regard.

PARA.TAB: The Civil Aviation Authority, and particularly the Chairman, Mr Butcher, have shown themselves to be unresponsive to the needs of the public, the Government, the Parliament and, lately, even those of the pilots and air traffic controllers. The Civil Aviation Authority seems to be too interested in promoting its own particular interests. It seems to have become a fully self-serving organisation and it has lost all sense of public purpose. Now that the past CAA chairman, aviation expert, Dick Smith, has come out in strong opposition to the Civil Aviation Authority on a new airspace system, I think it is time that organisation was thoroughly looked at.

The air traffic services centre controversy of last year was absolutely amazing. I think the Civil Aviation Authority showed an attitude towards public accountability which was totally unacceptable in its process of tendering for its new air traffic system. In that instance, the Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, Mr Butcher, and an officer, Dr Edwards, displayed an alarming disregard, even arrogance, towards the Parliament, particularly the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. Mr Butcher even wrote to the chairman of that committee expressing his strong disagreement with the right of the committee or the public to even know the tender details.

I come to the question of the curfew at Kingsford-Smith airport. That curfew is under constant threat. It is hard to believe that the Civil Aviation Authority is not encouraging the situation. Prior to the election the coalition floated the possibility of lifting the curfew. I guess it was inevitable, given the success of commercial aviation interests in entrenching themselves at Sydney airport with the third runway decision.

If we are going to lift that curfew, let us lift it. At the moment it is being lifted by stealth. The Civil Aviation Authority is supposed to be monitoring the situation. Yet over the past few weeks there have been numerous cases of airliners coming in at 5 a.m. and earlier. This is in constant disregard of government statements. The public is just being treated with contempt. As things stand, that curfew is starting to disappear.

I turn to the proposed Sydney heliport, which is now being promoted by the State Government. One would think that the Civil Aviation Authority would take a hand in this but it is disregarding the whole situation. The authority is the body set up to monitor the operation of helicopters, yet absolutely no monitoring is taking place whatsoever.

There are no controls on flight paths and heights that helicopters are now travelling. This has the potential, like Kingsford-Smith airport, to affect the wellbeing of probably half a million inner city residents. This authority just wipes its hands of the matter and says that it is not responsible and that it will leave it to the Maritime Services Board. The Maritime Services Board is organising the heliport.

I turn now to the new airspace system. Dick Smith, the former chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, has come out strongly against the system recently announced by the authority. He has made a number of criticisms. He calls it a second-rate system. He says that the original plan introduced by John Wright and his team has been changed in a major way and that the new system has unique and complicated procedures. There is to be an abandonment of air traffic control service at 5,000 feet in radar airspace and 10,000 feet in all other airspace—in other words, over 80 per cent of all Australian airspace. No other country in the world does this.

In trying to compensate for the lowering of safety, the CAA has invented a new and unproven system. It is also highly complicated. The new system is not in harmony with best international practice. As a result, foreign pilots flying here will have to learn new procedures, and our own pilots abroad will have to do likewise. The equipment that the authority has chosen will have to be designed for the new system, which has potentially huge cost blow-outs and delays in commissioning. The operators of general aviation aircraft will incur substantial costs in fitting the transponder or radio equipment made mandatory by the CAA under its new system. Dick Smith's letter to the chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority states:

SPEECH.PARA: I am afraid that you and your fellow Board members do not appear to appreciate the high risk strategy you are allowing to be inflicted on Australian aviation . . .
It also states that the airspace system the authority is trying to introduce has never been tested anywhere else in the world and is potentially dangerous. The letter continues:
. . . you are placing your professional air traffic controllers in an almost impossible position—(Time expired)

They are very innovative programs that the Government has put in line. We need to continue that.

PARA.TAB: There has been a bit of discussion on the likelihood of funding being reduced in some of these areas. I will be strongly opposing loss of funding. These programs are put there in order to enhance the opportunities for unemployed persons to regain employment. Having been a provider of several of those programs, I can guarantee their benefit to the short-term and the long-term unemployed.

The second area that I am particularly keen to promote in this House is the extension of child-care funding for larger institutions. There have been two representations for child-care funding in the electorate of Bass. The first is from the Launceston General Hospital, which has a huge staff. Many of them, regardless of whether they are male or female, have children that need some form of child care. What is needed there is an on-site child-care facility.

The second area, as I have noticed from my local newspapers whilst I have been here this week, is the Launceston campus of the University of Tasmania. A Mr Robert Silver is very busy lobbying for that option for the university. I will be in contact with him to assist him with his work.

Another particular area of interest for me is the roads surrounding Launceston. At this point in time we have a couple of bypasses, but another is needed. I will lobby very hard for funding to be put aside within the next two to three years for the eastern bypass. It looks as though Tasmania will be acquiring B-doubles, the very large freight carriers. The eastern bypass that I am looking for will bypass some of Launceston's major suburbs, particularly Newstead that is now being inundated with large trucks carrying timber, for example. They come through the suburb which is a very high quality residential area. The roads there have definitely not been built for heavy duty traffic and are beginning to break up. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to address a matter dear to the hearts of many Australians—namely, the retention of stability in government by means of our present Westminster system based on constitutional monarchy. Judging by recent nervous comments reassuring us of his minimalist approach, the arrogant attempt by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to impose a republic on the Australian people is already beginning to founder, and not surprisingly.

PARA.TAB: There is no burning desire for a republic amongst the great bulk of middle Australians, regardless of party preference. If so, why was it not reflected clearly in the March election results? The Republican Party of Australia stood Senate candidates in four States. Genuine republicans would have voted for them and given their preferences to the major party of their choice. In fact, in Western Australia the republicans received 0.16 per cent of the vote; in Victoria, 0.17 per cent; in New South Wales, 0.13 per cent; and in South Australia, 0.44 per cent. House of Representatives candidates also received small percentages of the total vote. In other words, middle Australia was, and is, far more interested in jobs and economic recovery than in changing to a republic.

The burning desire for a republic emanates from comparatively few—mostly from the Labor Party—with the strong backing of some sections of the media. In the vanguard, of course, is the Prime Minister, who recently assured us of his minimalist preferred option. However, the Prime Minister's track record suggests that a minimalist republic might not last too long.

The speech by His Excellency the Governor-General on the occasion of the opening of parliament flagged this opinion when, after mentioning a referendum to enable Australia to become a republic by the year 2001, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is not opposed to examining other aspects of constitutional reform but these should be considered separately and on their own merits.

In other words, lull the people of Australia into accepting a republic first and then centralise power later. What particular constitutional reforms would these be, I wonder? Does it mean the abolition of the Senate? After all, the Prime Minister has arrogantly described it as `unrepresentative swill', and only today Queensland Labor Premier Goss confirmed that he considered the Senate to be unrepresentative also. That is a possibility. The abolition of State parliaments is another possibility.

PARA.TAB: The new Labor member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) in his maiden speech on 6 May represented one thread of Labor Party opinion on this matter when he spoke of:

SPEECH.PARA: My desire to see the abolition of State Parliaments . . . the States are an anachronistic relic of colonial times.
We now know what some members of the Labor Party think of the system of State and Federal governments.

PARA.TAB: Will the anglophobia of the Prime Minister and other Labor Party members extend to erasing the greatly respected Australian flag because it historically includes a Union Jack? That is another possibility. It is very clear from ALP policy statements over the years that the wider ALP agenda involves changing the flag, abolishing or curtailing the power of the Senate, and converting the States from sovereign elements of a federation to regional administrative units of a central government.

The republican putsch is not the manifestation of a great passionate desire emanating from the hearts of the Australian people. It is imposed by the few upon the many, led by the Prime Minister in order to centralise power in Canberra. I believe when Australians fully realise that the republican putsch is about removing the checks and balances to unbridled power, the referendum that we will face on this matter will be soundly defeated. I also believe, despite the polls, that that process of rejection has already begun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I came into the chamber to deliver this adjournment speech last evening but the drivel uttered by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) caught my attention instead. Tonight, however, I turn to another example of Labor folly.

PARA.TAB: The other morning I was flicking through the papers and noticed a sordid little piece attacking pro-British traditions in the Australian defence forces. Labor has commissioned a 270-page report to investigate the possibility that a cultural bias exists in services. One of its authors, Dr Robert Hall, came to the conclusion that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Defence Force is seen by a growing segment of the population—including those of non-English speaking and of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander background—to be anachronistic and of declining relevance to their lives.

What Dr Hall and his fellow social engineers—all growing fat on the public purse—have forgotten is that, believe it or not, the purpose of our Army, Navy and Air Force is actually to defend our country and not to be some kind of late 20th century social laboratory where academic fantasies can be acted out at the taxpayers' expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member. Top marks to the Returned Services League and its National President, Brigadier Alf Garland, who moved swiftly to describe the report as `a blatant attack on Australia's background and heritage'. The Armed Forces Federation, the union for service personnel, also rejects Labor's attack. Spokesman James Morris says:

SPEECH.PARA: We have to maintain our cultural ties—they don't harm the ADF and they shouldn't be taken away. If it isn't broke, don't fix it.

The report must be seen in the light of Labor's obsessive opposition to all things British. Honourable members would have shared my disgust at the politicisation of Anzac Day by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when in a particularly tasteless attack, even for him, he savaged the British while pointedly failing to condemn Japanese wartime atrocities committed against Australian prisoners of war.

PARA.TAB: One wonders what motivates Labor to seek to rewrite our history. Why is Labor so biased against Australia's British connection? The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) has blamed the Prime Minister's bog Irish attitudes, but that would be to reflect on the loyal contribution made by Irish Australians over the years.

No-one would doubt that parts of Australia now have a wide cultural diversity and that migrants have made valuable contributions to the community. Unfortunately, the Government's single-minded pursuit of the ethnic vote has elevated its version of multiculturalism almost to a state religion.While it quite rightly seeks to encourage non-English speaking migrants to maintain their culture and traditions, Labor manages to convey the impression that the values and heritage which have evolved from British settlers are somehow inferior; they are to be shunned, held in contempt and treated with disdain. Labor seeks to create a dictatorship of minority interests while dismembering Australia's own beliefs and national ethos.

The ADF ethnic study epitomises this attitude and fails to concede that robust Australian service traditions have developed this century creating a distinctive Australian military identity; thus the legend of Gallipoli and Anzac. Service traditions such as the officers' mess, dine-in nights, formal dress and portraits of the head of state prominently displayed are common to most armed forces throughout the world. Just because some of them are also British does not make them un-Australian.
I take strong exception to suggestions in the report that the ADF should help to give effect to the wider social agenda of the Government. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Large institutions with high public profiles like the ADF can help to give such policies the momentum they may need to achieve wider public acceptance.

In other words, the report commissioned by Labor suggests that the ADF should be an arm of the Government in power. This has horrendous connotations for the future, should this occur in combination with the Prime Minister's determination to impose a republic.

PARA.TAB: Labor's approach strikes hard at morale. Who cares what the family origin is of Australians who choose to join the services? Does it matter, as the report claims, that ethnic recruits are half the number the social engineers consider they should be? I could not care less, nor could the people of Australia.

A number of questions need to be asked. Who commissioned the ADF report? How much did it cost and what were the terms of reference? What submissions were made by the defence forces and their members? The Army, the Navy and the Air Force are there to do an important job. They do a fine job. They are in the business of defending Australia—nothing more, nothing less. The Government's agenda stands condemned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
